review: This is an old school game that I've been enjoying for 25 years. it is grid based strategic and has enough different levels and variety to be like a chess game with thousands of spaces and some low level graphics and animations that were amazing when they came out but don't compare to skyrim or other rrpg immersion games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151007717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 80612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 385, 'playtime_at_review': 80612, 'last_played': 1710768471}
review:
It's good for when I want to waste an hour thinking i'm only going to play about ten minutes.

I enjoy exploring the randomly generated world, which parameters you can predetermine. And then I enjoy dominating other nations while I secure my own nation. Or die trying.

I gradually increase the difficulty level (i'm at reagent +3) as I get better, no wait, more aggressive.

I prefer this to all of the other latest Civ games, except Civ four, with Leonard Nimoy saying "Beep, Beep, Beep, Beep" when you achieve space travel :D 

I wish Civ 4 was still available.

review:
[b]Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete[/b] to bez cienia wƒÖtpliwo≈õci rewelacyjny klasyczny tytu≈Ç z gatunku gier strategiczno-ekonomicznych (turowy) w kt√≥rej to gracz wciela siƒô w wielkich ≈õwiatowych przyw√≥dc√≥w, zadaniem kt√≥rych bƒôdzie rozw√≥j podleg≈Çej im nacji - przeprowadzenie jej od samej kolebki poprzez wielki bujnego rozkwitu, a≈º po wsp√≥≈Çczesno≈õƒá. RozwijajƒÖc dana nacjƒô wedle w≈Çasnego uznania, w kierunku w jakim uznacie za s≈Çuszny, opracowujƒÖc √≥wczesne technologie, odkrywajƒÖc czy tez wznoszƒÖc ku ≈õwietno≈õci cuda i monumenty realnego ≈õwiata ‚Äì jest to wspania≈Ça przygoda, kt√≥ra wch≈Çonie was na bardzo d≈Çugi czas i nie pozwoli o sobie zapomnieƒá.

Tytu≈Ç obowiƒÖzkowy dla ka≈ºdego fana klasycznych gier strategicznych/ekonomicznych. Nie bƒôdƒô oszukiwaƒá, powy≈ºsza produkcja to monstrualny ‚Äûzjadacz czasu‚Äù. Tytu≈Ç od kt√≥rego bardzo trudno siƒô oderwaƒá, przedstawiajƒÖcy bardzo rozbudowanƒÖ, choƒá ju≈º klasycznƒÖ strukturƒô rozgrywki.

[i]Ma≈Ça dygresja:[/i]

1. Jestem ogromnym fanem tytu≈Ç√≥w z gatunku gier strategii-ekonomicznych w tym seria Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization od samego poczƒÖtku istnienia znajduje siƒô na szczycie moich ulubionych gier w kt√≥rƒÖ zagrywa≈Çem i do tej pory zagrywam siƒô godzinami ‚Äì jak r√≥wnie≈º jestem szczƒô≈õliwym posiadaczem fizycznych egzemplarzy wszystkich dostƒôpnych na rynku tytu≈Ç√≥w z tej serii. 

2. Nie zwracajcie uwagi na m√≥j czas gry na platformie Steam, gdy≈º jest nieadekwatny z realnym czasem spƒôdzonym z tym tytu≈Çem (to tysiƒÖce godzin), edycja  fizyczna (pude≈Çkowa) gry ‚Äì nie wymaga ona rejestracji/ podpiƒôcia pod ≈ºadnƒÖ z istniejƒÖcych cyfrowych platform do gier. 

3. W odr√≥≈ºnieniu od podstawowej wersji gry, edycja Complete posiada w sobie r√≥wnie≈º dwa du≈ºe dodatki ‚Äì ‚ÄûPlay the World‚Äù oraz  ‚ÄûConquests‚Äù.

4. Wersje cyfrowe w tym Steam nie posiadajƒÖ spolszczenia  (tylko jƒôzyk angielski), jedynie wydanie pude≈Çkowe takowƒÖ posiada≈Ça (polskie napisy) ‚Äì kt√≥rƒÖ mo≈ºna nadal kupiƒá nowa bƒÖd≈∫ u≈ºywanƒÖ w Internecie, wystƒôpujƒÖcej w edycji  Kolekcja Klasyki.

[h1]Ale do rzeczy:[/h1]

Jak ju≈º zdo≈Ça≈Çem wspomnieƒá na samym poczƒÖtku tej recenzji mamy tym razem do czynienia z tytu≈Çem z gatunku gier strategiczno-ekonomicznych (turowy) w kt√≥rej to gracz wciela siƒô w wielkich ≈õwiatowych przyw√≥dc√≥w, zadaniem kt√≥rych bƒôdzie rozw√≥j podleg≈Çej im nacji - przeprowadzenie jej od samej kolebki poprzez wielki bujnego rozkwitu, a≈º po wsp√≥≈Çczesno≈õƒá. RozwijajƒÖc dana nacjƒô wedle w≈Çasnego uznania, w kierunku w jakim uznacie za s≈Çuszny, opracowujƒÖc √≥wczesne technologie, odkrywajƒÖc czy tez wznoszƒÖc ku ≈õwietno≈õci cuda i monumenty realnego ≈õwiata ‚Äì jest to wspania≈Ça przygoda, kt√≥ra wch≈Çonie was na bardzo d≈Çugi czas i nie pozwoli o sobie zapomnieƒá.

Podstawowa rozgrywka, jej fundament turowej zabawy pozostaje praktycznie niezmieniony wzglƒôdem poprzednich a nawet pierwotnych jej czƒô≈õci. SkupiajƒÖca siƒô na rozgrywce dla pojedynczego gracza, kt√≥rego zadaniem bƒôdzie zarzƒÖdzanie i rozw√≥j w szerokim tego s≈Çowa znaczeniu, dowolnie wybranej przez gracza jednej z wielu historycznych cywilizacji. A co za tym idzie budowaniu i p√≥≈∫niejszym rozwoju miast, dostosowaniu pod w≈Çasne potrzeby podleg≈Çych im teren√≥w, dbaniu o swoich mieszka≈Ñc√≥w w wielu sferach w tym og√≥lnƒÖ ekonomie, politykƒô, wojsko itp. Po czym doprowadzenie jej do wznios≈Çego zwyciƒôstwa nad innymi rywalizujƒÖcymi  z nami w tym samym czasie nacjami.

[h1]Dalej:[/h1]

Przeciwnik komputerowy nie jest g≈Çupi, wykorzysta waszƒÖ nierozwagƒô czy te≈º s≈Çabo≈õƒá,  nawet bƒôdzie u≈ºywa≈Ç podstƒôp√≥w aby zajƒÖƒá korzystne pozycje do ataku (np. podpisujƒÖc czasowy pakt o przemieszczaniu siƒô jednostek na waszym terytorium, zbli≈ºy siƒô do miast i wiecie co dalej‚Ä¶). 

W zale≈ºno≈õci od ustalonych pierwotnie zasad zwyciƒôstwa mogƒÖ one narzucaƒá inny charakter prowadzenia rozgrywki w tym r√≥wnie≈º rozwoju naszego spo≈Çecze≈Ñstwa  ‚Äì zwyciƒôstwo dyplomatyczne, kulturowe, naukowe, przez dominacjƒô, punktowe itp. Choƒá mo≈ºna je tez wszystkie wy≈ÇƒÖczyƒá i graƒá do momentu pozostania na mapie tylko jednego globalnego imperium.

Nie zabraknie r√≥wnie≈º mo≈ºliwo≈õƒá przeniesienia tej samej zabawy na poziom gry wieloosobowej ustawiajƒÖc rozgrywkƒô dowolnie, wedle uznania hosta lub preferencji biorƒÖcych udzia≈Ç w zabawie graczy. Dla bardziej wymagajƒÖcych zosta≈Çy przygotowane specjalne scenariusze (mini kampanie), kt√≥re odwo≈ÇujƒÖ siƒô do historycznych zdarze≈Ñ i pozwalajƒÖ graczowi wziƒÖƒá w nich czynny udzia≈Ç.

Co do oprawy audiowizualnej jest dobra, we≈∫cie pod uwagƒô ≈ºe jest to tytu≈Ç kt√≥ry ma 23 lata wiƒôc nie spodziewajcie siƒô wizualnych fajerwerk√≥w rodem z najnowszych produkcji kt√≥re i tak czerpiƒÖ gar≈õciami z tego w≈Ça≈õnie klasyka. Sterowanie jednostkami bƒÖd≈∫ obs≈Çuga interfejsu jest banalnie prosta, wrƒôcz intuicyjna ‚Äì w grze jest do≈ÇƒÖczony samouczek, kt√≥ry nauczy ka≈ºdego podstaw rozgrywki.

[h1]Podsumowanie:[/h1]

Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete to rewelacyjny klasyczny tytu≈Ç z gatunku gier strategiczno-ekonomicznych (turowy) w kt√≥rej to gracz wciela siƒô w wielkich ≈õwiatowych przyw√≥dc√≥w.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992969984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 23534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1057, 'playtime_at_review': 22538, 'last_played': 1710805236}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III has stood the test of time, remaining a classic strategy game even two decades after its release. While its graphics may show its age, its game play and depth are as compelling as ever.

One of Civilization III's greatest strengths lies in its historical authenticity. Each civilization feels unique, with distinct traits and units that reflect their real-world counterparts. Whether you're leading the Greeks to cultural dominance or the Mongols to military conquest, the game offers a rich tapestry of historical possibilities.

The gameplay mechanics are straightforward yet endlessly engaging. The familiar "one more turn" mantra still rings true, as players find themselves immersed in the cycle of exploration, expansion, and diplomacy. Every decision feels meaningful, whether you're managing your economy or negotiating with rival leaders.

Despite its ageing graphics, Civilization III retains a certain charm. The hand-drawn art style may lack the detail of modern titles, but it has a timeless appeal that draws players in. The game's interface is intuitive and easy to navigate, ensuring that even newcomers can jump in and start building their empire.

author: {'steamid': '76561198310362975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 292, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1710259742}
review:
Ne trouvant pas ici le 2√®me opus de cette franchise, que j'ai tant jou√© et ador√© √† une √©poque, j'ai achet√© le 3, et... c'est assez confus. Plus de conseil des ministres, apparemment, avec chaque ministre qui vous pressait de g√©rer le pays comme il le voulait (ministre des arm√©es qui voulait toujours que l'on ait une grande arm√©e, ministre de l'√©ducation qui voulait que l'on construise des biblioth√®ques et des universit√©s, etc...), on trouve d√©j√† ici des choses que l'on retrouvera dans le 5 et le 6, telles que des options de diplomatie bien + √©labor√©es que dans le 2, au niveau des n√©gociations entre chefs d'√©tats.

Le colon (settler) n'est plus "multit√¢ches", il fonde une nouvelle ville, et c'est tout. Pour b√¢tir les routes, irriguer les champs, faire une mine √† exploiter, vous utiliserez ici le "travailleur" (worker). Qui se trouvera + ou moins inutile une fois qu'il aura fait tout ce que vous vouliez, alors que dans Civ'2, on utilisait un colon, qui ensuite servait toujours √† faire une nouvelle ville. Les gal√®res ne peuvent plus servir √† combattre des unit√©s terrestres sur les plages, ce qui fait que j'en ai fait une pour rien, et surtout les villes, √† taille fixe (pas en nombre d'habitants mais taille sur la carte) dans le 2 √©voluent maintenant toutes seules.

Comme soulign√© par d'autres, le jeu n'est qu'en anglais, ce qui est assez d√©plaisant, surtout pour un frenchy qui a toujours entendu que notre langue √©tait LA langue internationale de la diplomatie. On parle quand m√™me ici d'un Civilization, pas d'un Command & Conquer (que j'aime beaucoup aussi, mais nulle diplomatie dans un C&C). Bref, n√© dans les ann√©es '80, j'ai grandi √† une √©poque o√π les dev' faisaient les jeux en 2 langues : le japonais pour le march√© interne √† leur pays, et l'anglais pour l'export. J'ai donc d√ª apprendre des bases, que j'ai ensuite am√©lior√© au coll√®ge, en regardant chez moi des films am√©ricains en V.O. et en discutant sur le net avec des britishs et am√©ricains.

N√©anmoins, pour les personnes "allergiques au rosbif", il parait qu'il existe un "patch" (ou "pacht", si vous √™tes corse). A vous de voir. Pour ma part, une √©val' apr√®s 4h de jeu, je suis d√©sol√© mais pas grand chose d'autre √† dire. Ah si : ma 1√®re partie n'est pas encore termin√©e ! Donc si vous avez une vie charg√©e qui ne vous laisse que rarement 30mn pour jouer, pas s√ªr que ce soit un titre pour vous. Mais sinon c'est sympa, les Civ' :)

review:
[h3]Quick Notes[/h3]

‚Ä¢ The best Civ of the entire series. Every Civ after has departed from this, which is a real shame. I would've loved to see some quality of life updates and a remaster. Still an easy recommendation.
‚Ä¢ The gamestudio mentioned wanting Civ to feel more like a board game. Civ 4 doesn't accomplish this, Civ 5 does so a little bit, Civ 6 absolutely does, but it's to its detriment. The uncomplicated nature of this PC game, that gets as hard as you like, makes it an absolute masterpiece.
‚Ä¢ Be prepared to play for hours on end, there's no such thing as a short game in Civ 3. You'll be saying: "One more turn" as the sun goes down, only to see the sun come up, feel tired all day, and do it again the next night.

[h3]Evaluation[/h3]

[b]Graphics[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198142592490', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1696791280}
review: Without doubt my favourite installment within the Civilization franchise. The fact that almost a decade after it still sucks me in like the first day is a testament to its ever lasting appeal. You only know when you start a game but you never know when you'll put it down or finish it; it's just so addictive unlike Civ V which has no lasting appeal. For me Civ 3 felt like digital chess. It's a game that has you continually thinking what your next moves will be and rewards handsomely forward-thinking and carefully planning ahead. I even like the graphics which are not as cartoonish as Civ IV. Along with Brian Reynold's Alpha Centauri, Civ 3 is my all-time favourite game. The amounts of hours I've poured into it can be tallied by the thousands. If you like 4X TBS games you owe it to yourself to play this classic. The Conquests expansion infused new life by way of historic scenarios which are fleshed out very nicely. Special mention goes to Rise of Rome and the Napoleon scenario where you relive the glory and bloodshed of the lost Empires. Civ IV has overshadowed its predecessor significantly but Civ 3 will always have a place in my heart and harddrive and I return to it at least twice a year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218479024', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 23761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 572, 'playtime_at_review': 20774, 'last_played': 1710517253}
review:
I have been playing this game for 20 years.   I still play it today.   Its probably the best of the Civ series.  You can still stack units.  This can lead to absolutely epic battles.   In my last game the computer was coming out with stacks of dozen or more infantry and my artillery and bombs slowly whittled them down.

It's ability to simulate WW1'esque long grinding wars were units are lost by the several dozens every turn makes it truly unique.  It's really something to watch a massive empire slowly fall apart over decades due to war fatigue, conscription, and artillery and bombers slowly pounding away at its infrastructure.

When they got rid of the ability to stack units the game went downhill.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008635322', 'num_games_owned': 2691, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1704146540}
review:
"Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete" is a comprehensive package that includes the original "Civilization III" game along with its expansions, "Play the World" and "Conquests." Developed by Firaxis Games and published by 2K Games, this edition was released to offer the definitive experience of one of the most influential turn-based strategy games. Set against the backdrop of human history, players lead a civilization from the dawn of time to the space age, striving to achieve one of several victory conditions through exploration, diplomacy, cultural advancement, and warfare. 

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Civilization III Complete" refines the series' formula, offering deep and engaging gameplay that balances empire management, strategic warfare, and diplomatic negotiations. Players must carefully manage their cities, resources, and population while exploring the world and interacting with rival civilizations. The game introduces unique features such as culture, which can influence borders and city loyalty, and more complex trade and diplomacy systems, adding layers of strategy not seen in its predecessors.

Strategic Depth
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The strategic depth of "Civilization III Complete" is immense, with a variety of paths to victory and countless strategies to explore. Each civilization offers unique advantages, encouraging players to adapt their tactics based on their chosen nation and the evolving geopolitical landscape. The inclusion of the "Play the World" and "Conquests" expansions further enriches the game's depth, introducing new civilizations, scenarios, and features that challenge even veteran players.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 7/10 - Good
For its time, "Civilization III Complete" featured detailed graphics that brought the world map, units, and city improvements to life. While the visuals may appear dated by today's standards, they retain a certain charm and clarity that contribute to the game's immersive experience. The audio, including the soundtrack and sound effects, effectively complements the gameplay, though it is relatively minimalistic compared to more recent entries in the series.

Replayability
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
The replayability of "Civilization III Complete" is outstanding, with virtually endless possibilities for different game experiences. The random map generation, diverse civilizations, and multiple victory conditions ensure that no two playthroughs are the same. The additional content from the expansions, along with the game's modding support, further extends its longevity, making it a title that players can return to time and again.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete" offers exceptional entertainment value, combining strategic depth, engaging gameplay, and extensive content into a package that appeals to both strategy enthusiasts and casual gamers alike. Its balance of accessibility for newcomers and complexity for seasoned players makes it a standout title in the strategy genre.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 8.8/10 - Excellent
"Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete" is a seminal title in the turn-based strategy genre, offering a rich and expansive gaming experience that has influenced countless subsequent games. Its combination of strategic gameplay, replayability, and the depth of content in the complete edition cements its status as a classic.

Highly Recommended for fans of strategy games and those interested in historical simulation and empire-building, especially of those who love Civ2. It stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of the series' formula, combining deep gameplay mechanics with the grand scope of human history, offering a timeless challenge to strategists and empire builders.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101613720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 615324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598262, 'last_played': 1708133265}
review: Been playing on Emperor level forever. Once in a VERY long while,  I actually win a game. But with the game so stacked against you (especially lagging woefully behind in Tech) , the game is almost impossible  to beat.  Temple of Artemis and then at least 6-10 armies is the best bet. But if you find ivory, then the game slows down your growth and besides, almost half the time  some other civ gets the Temple first. Armies are largely a matter of luck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253040073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 7036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7036, 'last_played': 1705803515}
review:
Teaboy's Basic(ish) Reviews....I read a lot of reviews when looking at games on Steam, and it quickly gets tiring ‚Äì those who write involved, down to the micron scale reviews, although helpful, end up like looking at War & Peace when you‚Äôve only got time for a quick 5 minute dump!  This is middle of the road and to the point ‚Äì not easy for me as I tend towards sesquipedalian loquaciousness!  Vociferously Verbose?  Alright, verbal diarrhoea.  (Although I hate panning a developer‚Äôs work and all the time, effort and love they put into designing these ‚Äì it is their life after all ‚Äì this is my honest, personal opinion of my level of enjoyment.  Sorry devs!).  

A note on time played:  My Steam clock does not seem to work properly, indeed, it even minuses time on occasion!  Plus, I have a tendency to wander off and leave games running at times, so time played may not be entirely accurate!  


Teaboy‚Äôs Tonsil Titillators or Toenail Titbits!  (Rating)  

Tonsil Tickler (Totally Tops):  The frenchy of which you always dreamt!  To quote a master, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs got a tongue like an electric eel and she likes the taste of a Man‚Äôs tonsils!‚Äù.  An absolute masterpiece and joy to play.  

The Tits (Terrific):  Everyone loves playing with these!  Not THE best bit, but such fun on their own you can be lost for hours....mmmm.  What most games you really like score ‚Äì perfection is so rare after all.   

Torso Teaser (Taker of your Time):  It‚Äôs a flat stomach....sure it‚Äôs nice to look at, run your fingers over, slobber on a bit, sometimes that bellybutton gets your motor running....but it's just basically the corridor between the two ‚Äògaming rooms‚Äô.  The definitive ‚ÄòMeh‚Äô - the middle ‚Äòsideways thumb‚Äô option for which everyone on Steam cries.  

Todger/Tadger & (scroTum) Taters (Tedious):  Is it an ‚Äòa‚Äô or is it an ‚Äòo‚Äô?  Who cares!  The meat can be fun to play with for about 5 minutes of your entire day, the rest it just hangs there and generally gets in the way of doing something else.  The main problem of course, is the two veg sticking to your inside thigh.  This is what this game feels like ‚Äì the occasional/rare bouts of fun, the rest bobbing like a 19th century British Policeman (now you know why!).  

Toenail Tornado (Total Toss):  A playthrough so appalling it‚Äôs like being trapped in a Turkish sauna with the ugliest, hairiest, fattest, sweatiest beast of a neolithic hominid who‚Äôs trimming his toenails using pliers and the splinters are reminiscent of a scene from the Normandy Landings.  My god how did this get released!?  


Teaboy Touts (Score):  Torso Teaser/The Tits


The Review:  

None of my overused exclamation marks for the score for this one, but you can have one here!  Reason being,the sheer frustration factor of RNGesus.  

Now this is a tricky one, a Really tricky one.  On the one hand, Civ was the first 4x game I ever played on the good old Commodore Amiga back in the early 90s, and BOY did I fricking Love the turd out of it!  But oddly, having currently played Civ 1, 2, 3 and 4 + BtS with 5 in library, I actually prefer 1!  Nowt beats the original, eh?  

1 had it all, and although the world is never big enough for my liking in any of the iterations of the game, 1 was just perfection.  2 was literally a carbon copy with Alpha Centauri tacked on the end as a 2nd world to play concurrently with  the 1st (Earth, obvs), but there was no civilopaedia so you had no idea what anything did and you were starting from scratch again with a single settler - I could never get anything going and quickly grew tired of it.  

Now we get to 3.  The last in the line before they changed what everything did in 4 - I hated this!  As in your city improvements effects all changed in 4.  So 3 is good for keeping the old style with a few changes, mostly extra stuff, but I noticed they got rid of supermarkets!  So a limit on your growth!  They also nerfed transport capacity - like Transport from 8 to 6, and Carriers from 8 to sodding well 4!?  Booo!  

However, these are just annoyances.  By far the worst is the literally offensive rng.  This has two parts also:  The fact that I always used to play on the easiest setting simply because I always wanted the longest game I could and the higher the level the sooner the game ended - however, even with the new facility to turn off ALL victory conditions, it Still ended in 2050 with a warning in 2030 that you had 20 years left....so just wrap up your civilization please, vacuum the floors and lock the doors on your way out of existence - wtf!?  

Anywhos....I decided to play on just the 3rdsetting.  Out of what....9, 10, a dozen?  I forget.  But that's besides the point, the point being that it was still on the 'piss easy' side of things.  AND YET....I started to pay particular attention to combat results.  It was glaring in its conclusion.  Seriously, 80% of Equal battles with identical units would end in a loss for my side regardless of attack or defence or terrain bonuses.  Even my F*&^ing Battleships would regularly be beaten by F!"¬£ing Cruisers, Destroyers ffs and Even SUBMARINES who suck!!  The latter only being good for their ability to target a specific ship - kill Transports!  And once enemy has Stealth Bombers your cities are fkd.  I had the missile defence improvement, 4 Jet Figthers and SIXTEEN missile units in 1 city and they killed 1/10.  They destroy everything but missile, factory, aqueduct and hospitals.  Kills all but 1 citizen.  All ships and planes and defending units last.  Wtf is the point.  Whereas my Stealth Bombers miss almost 50%.  

Sorry for the rant.  The 2nd part being the oddity of how the rng worked on a turn basis.  Very strange.  I saved and repeated certain movements.  Once the save slot is reloaded, the result was ALWAYS the same, yet different from original play.  I actually had an enemy unit next to my base which I attacked with about 6 units that ALL died, EVERY $&(¬£W*& TIME!!  I changed simply the square from which I attacked and hey presto, I killed it.  This is just F&^%ing warped.  

I wanted to finish this game before writing, but I was dealt a totally turd hand from the offset - I used archipelago so each nation would have its own land.  I got the second smallest island with a quarter of it at the south pole so all tundra and almost NO resources at all!  Literally I got Iron and Spices.  That was it!  No Saltpetre, no Coal, no Oil, no Rubber.  Come late game, without Oil/Rubber you are pretty much screwed.  (Note:  You have Settlers and Workers in this third iteration of Civ instead of Settlers who eventually evolved into Engineers and did everything.  You can now no longer change every square into whatever terrain you wish - tundra is useless and cannot be altered, also mountains cannot be settled and if you settle on a resource it does not provide the benefit, all cities give the same 2 food 1 shield with only the trade changing) 

Now, randomly new deposits appear, and some disappear - just as I build a city amongst another empire to try and get a deposit!  Unbelievable!  So way after Coal had passed its use, a deposit appeared on my land!  At least I could build railways.  I did get Uranium and Aluminium which are end stage game Resources.  However, they give very little benefit compared to Oil and Rubber.  E.G.  You are stuck with Riflemen whilst everyone else is not only beyond Infantry but building Mech Inf, or I've got TOW Inf compared to their Modern Battletank.  Coupled with the rng, I got massacred every time.  I could only build Nuclear Submarines and thankfully eventually Aegis Cruisers whilst the computer players are knocking out Battleship after Battleship (ironically they seem to prefer Aegis when they get them).  I actually got Oil just as I was trying to settle next to a deposit, again in enemy territory.  Again, unbelievable.  Or not, it seems.  But I never got Rubber.  

Continued in Comments

author: {'steamid': '76561197983387573', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 2509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1704585545}
review:
I didn't even know it was on Steam until I grabbed it for around 1$ on sale, what I believe is an insane deal.

Civilization III still beats a lot of modern titles when it comes to replayability and the gameplay loop fun-factor. There are also a lot of mods out there so you can easily change your world to e.g. Middle-earth, Warhammer Fantasy, Game of Thrones, or even Star Wars.

I honestly think this is the best purchase I've ever made on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024789559', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 59445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4098, 'playtime_at_review': 30474, 'last_played': 1710881309}
review:
I love that you can utilize the terrain tactically, and even strategically. The static defenses can tunnel the enemy into prepared killing zones.
I like how the ancient warfare differs from the medieval and modern warfare.
On the other hand, the diplomacy is well developed as well. You can maintain good relationships, for a while ...
The experience system of the troops is exciting: regular -> veteran -> elite -> leader. It makes you care about your units, to keep them alive. And it is always random, which gives the good vibes of a gambling :)
Of course the city management is the backbone. The annoying part is that the corruption is hardly explained. You get big troubles with it, if you have many cities. Try to read about Optimal City Number (OCN)!

review:
Shout outs to Suede and his youtube channel for teaching me how to play this game.
This is my first Civ game and indeed my first real strategy game.
I have wanted to get into this series since I was a teenager and Civ 4 came out, but it always appeared too deep for me to grasp.
But as of the date I am posting this I was able to beat the game on regent in only about 3 hours.
I now love and enjoy the game and will play many more similar titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042403034', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1700738627}
review:
Civ 3 was my favorite of all the Civilization series. I used to play it for hours at a sitting via CD back when first released.  Had I received exactly the same as I used to have on CD, I'd be very happy, despite the year 2000 graphics.

Unfortunately, the Steam version, though it says "complete" is not.  It lacks the editor which made the game such fun for me, trying out different scenarios of my creation.  It also struggles to start or work well on my Windows 10 Pro.  I'm never sure when the game will hang, and it often does around the Fireaxis screen when just booting up or after entering the new game conditions.  

I suppose it may be possible, if one was willing to take the time and effort, to install a Windows 2000 emulator and get Steam to work with it somehow, that the game might run smoothly.  You'd still be missing the editor, which kind of negates the title "Complete".

author: {'steamid': '76561199534206762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1196, 'last_played': 1698543392}
review:
Still playable and enjoyable after so many years. The mechanics are simple yet effective.
AI is [b]ruthless[b/], even in lower difficulties. It will send waves of units in an intelligent way, rather than just crashing and dying against a strong city they will pillage and seek weaker targets and gradually eat away at your territory. You will be the subject of joint declarations of war. You will be nuked. Sometimes multiple times. And just when you think you are winning, within 20 turns you will be on the edge of losing.

It makes the AI in later Civs (looking at you especially, #6!) seem like it's designed for infants. How they can get it right in 3 yet wrong in 6 really beats me.

Of course, there are some annoyances. The 'death stack' of endless AI units piling down on your cities and running unchecked through territory is irritating, and time consuming to deal with. To get ahead, you really need to micro-manage pops in cities. Pollution pops up too frequently and too early, being another micro-managed tedium. The wonders are bland, and are hard to get even on mid-difficulties. Even the wonder movies in 2 made them meaningful whereas in this it's just 'meh'. There's only one great person, a general, which you need to create armies, and you can win a ton of battles yet still be without one throughout the entire game. Golden ages might happen once or never. 

But that AI makes it a real challenge, and little things like the palace and city views are what they should have kept in later versions.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989995299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 91341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91341, 'last_played': 1697701455}
review: Short: Frustrating, unfair, not buying any of its successors. Long: That would be such a great game, but already at lower diffculty level ("Regent", level 3 of 8, with 8 being the hardest), out of 20 attacks (reload saved game, free random generator), the same modern tank loses 19 times against the same much weaker unit, before it wins: Modern Armor, Attacking power: 24, Infantry, Defensive Power: 10. That means that the effective defense power of that Infantry would be more accurately correspond to 480 (20 times the 24 Attacking power), which of course is completely absurd. This might be an  "interesting"  challenge in the higjhest of the 8 difficulty levels, but at that level 3 (Regent), this is just frustrating as hell. With this, of course there is no interest in buying any of this games successors.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991608920', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 954, 'last_played': 1698879222}
review:
This game is the gambling addiction of civ design.

Less features than the newer ones, but also less fuzz.

Simply one more turn.


To get this game running in your desktop resolution. Find conquests.ini in the conquests folder (*\steamapps\common\Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete\Conquests)
and add:
keepres=1

If you require a custom resolution, also without potentially changing your desktop resolution with the above ini line.
Use this:
https://www.bcheck.net/apps/reso.htm
I recommend 1600x900 for 16:9 on a 24 inch monitor. The city menu will be 4:3 regardless, but I don't mind. There are custom menus and stuff over at civfanatics.com

This game's music can glitch out, stuck in a loop, and with no music for leader negotiations.
Here's a fix:
https://www.indirectsound.com/
Extract the two files into the conquests folder.

Source:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_psi0Lxoh2E

Lastly, a quality of life mod for beeing able to browse leaders in negotiations (similar to the newer games), better unit stack management, fix for AI to use artillery and much more:
https://forums.civfanatics.com/resources/c3x.28759/

:D

review:
I have been experiencing several crashes to start a new game.  To play Civ 3, first of all, you must configure the System display mode into 1366 x 768, or 1360 x 768 to be capable of seeing the starting menu. From there on, every time I start a new , the game crashes in the "configuring barbarians". I have tried all advices from this community and others, like:

C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete\Conquests
=conquests.ini
KeepRes=1
StartIntro=0

Also, cutting off the line 86 "unknown" and leaving it blank (C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete\Conquests\Conquests\Middle Ages\Text)

Furthermore, on the Steam app>library> right click> Properties > Installed Files > Verify Integrity of game file. And the "configuring barbarians" continues to crash.

Eventually, after running old saved games, and starting anew; it may work. Seldom it does. 

It sucks!

review:
I played this game years ago, and even though I did have some fun playing this game again, I cannot recommend it. It runs very poorly on modern computers, and is filled with audio and graphical glitches. The game also has problems of crashing to the desktop. It often crashes during the introduction cutscene, and crashes much of the time when you finish a game (and doesn't record the victory or score). Even discounting these game-breaking glitches, the gameplay has not held up after all of these years.

The classic Civilization game that has truly stood the test of time is Civilization IV. Get that game instead of this one. Or if you want a 2D classic experience similar to Civilization II / III, but more refined, then play Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri. You can buy that one on GOG. It has an excellent story and compelling premise, and many features in that game are implemented in Civlization IV. 

TL;DR: Play Civilization IV or Alpha Centauri.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044524317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1617894341}
review: For me, this is the original - the OG of PC strategy games. I know Civ2 was big before this but this game took the fundamentals of what made Civ a fun series of games and turned them up to 11. I could wax poetically on the impact this game had on my life but it's interesting how a game made 20+ years ago still has game mechanics that could be considered timeless. I still think that Civ5 is the best game of the Civ series, but this game is a close second which is insane considering how old it is. Game mechanics aside, this game also has one of the most underrated soundtracks of any game from any era. For a few bucks, you can experience PC gaming history and if you're anything like me, a nice stroll down nostalgia lane is included.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070923587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10840, 'last_played': 1689323715}
review:
Civilization 3 is a game that many people remember fondly but time has revealed how awful it is. It is famous for its absurd difficulty, but in actuality its difficulty upon deity and sid is actually impossible, which is incredibly poor game design. 

Cheats and exploits are required when it comes to winning on Diety or Sid. The strategies players employ to win here include - re-rolling the map until you get an amazing start, using "army" units to pillage and block AI lands (they are programmed not to attack an army), Great Library strats (building this thing is a cheat unto itself; it lets you set the slider to 0 and tech for free through the Middle Ages, further if you gift the city to an AI before teching education and taking it back later), RoP r*pe (abusing right of passage to cripple an AI as you declare war, can be coupled with Great Library abuse to get dozens of free techs), spamming workers so you can slave them all in one city to avoid the happiness penalty, piling workers into a disordered city so you can work taxmen and scientists for free in corrupt cities, manipulating the predictable AI in general (you can always get the AI to join wars and dog pile the top ai with a measly few hundred gold, or sue for peace and declare war the very same turn to get free techs), just using armies in general because the AI never will build one, pre building wonders because the AI will never do it, pillaging enemy resources using a glitch which extends the bombard length of siege units infinitely (press G then B, now you can bombard any square that doesn't have a unit or city on it) - the list really does go on. And if you would trust the writer who spent much time learning the tactics from old civfantic forums, everyone who has beaten Sid uses some mixture of these exploits, while at the same time arbitrarily declaring other exploits as "cheating." 

Why would you want to invest time into a strategy game who's greatest challenge is designed only to be beaten through cheating and exploiting? Because of this, Civ3 will always leave you unsatisfied, even when you win. Revisiting this game has made me appreciate the difficulty levels in the modern civ games, which are actually winnable without gross exploits. 

There is one more thing which makes Civ3 really an unfulfilling experience - the heavy RNG combat. No, the random number generator isnt cheating against you, but it is far too random and unpredictable. In fact, its unpredictability is so terrible, that one must use every trick in the book to maximize unit production to obscene heights in order to secure a predictable outcome from a war. This contributes towards players using exploitative strategies to be able to win wars, and war is unavoidable in higher difficulties. The unit balance is simply too mild. One bad dice roll can decide the whole fight because each fight typically consist of only 3-4 dice rolls. It leads to unexpected results every game - its unintuitive. When a perfectly executed attack with overwhelming odds falls flat due to a streak of bad luck, It starts to feel more like a game of dice instead of a strategy game. And what do most players do at this point? The most popular exploit - reload and issue your moves in a new order to escape the bad string of RNG. 

The RNG tends to favor the AI, not through rolls, but by the very nature of the game itself. The player must always be offensive, and the AI enjoys the comfort of playing defensively on high difficulties. Bad luck doesn't hurt the AI nearly so much on defense, with their hundreds of free units, and good luck isnt too useful for you on offense because you will be stacking the odds in your favor anyway. The result? When you get boned by the RNG on high difficulties, you will be ALT-F4ing because the game is lost, immediately, due to RNG despite your best efforts and perfect moves. 

Some mods fixed the combat in this game by increasing the health of units and increasing the health difference between the ranks of units (conscript, regular, veteran, elite.) Why this was never incorporated officially into Conquests, is beyond me. It appears to me that the developers were more concerned with protecting the AI from losing than creating a satisfying and rewarding experience for the player. 

The last thing to remark about Civ3 is how heavy a role micromanagement plays in its strategy. Top play will have you reshuffling worked tiles every turn, reassigning specialists, managing whips, routing units, checking in with every single AI every single turn to see what you can trade before they trade it away with each other... the whole game is essentially micromanagement. Many of the required exploits for Deity and Sid increase the micro load by 10. The game also suffers from poor UI. If you are a veteran of Civ4 you will be greatly frustrated by the missing quality of life features that remove much of the useless micromanagement.  It feels like a game for retired accountants. 

Is there a good game here some where? Yeah. Its called Rhyes of Civilization - a mod collection which heavily inspired Civ4, possibly the best Civ game in the franchise. I'm sure there are other good mods, but that's the one I played and pretty much every improvement Civ4 made to the game can be found to some extent in this mod. The fact is Civ3, as is, was always a bad game. I highly recommend, if you choose to play, to stick to Emperor difficulty and below. Exceeding this, you enter a very frustrating and unrewarding place that can truly waste your time undeservedly. I've beaten Deity and it wasn't worth it. I could win Sid, but I've already  wasted 100 hours too many.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156701926', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1689270189}
review:
I tried it in 2023 for the sake of it, and to put it bluntly it's not worth the hassle. It's not a bad game, but despite all my tweakings it crashes often, and the 'manual' supposedly included isn't available anymore so I struggle and stumble a while to remember the most basic things (like how to talk to the other civs, or even how to embark units on the sea, lolsob).

It's still a fun game, and actually a nice transition from the very first Civ I played as a child, to the modern ones. I might even come back to it more seriously one day, out of nostalgia.... but for now, I'll skip it and I advise you do to. It's just not worth the frustration with the more recent ones available and more stable/adapted to today systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013182175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 8828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8828, 'last_played': 1682436940}
review: Still my favorite of all the Civs, even all these years later.  Hated IV, and admittedly like V quite a bit (still haven't done VI enough to comment), but none of them scratch that itch quite like III does.  From IV on, the focus of the series seems to have turned more into "building tall" than "building wide".   And sometimes I want to build REALLY wide, dangit.  In fact, even this game has a hard-coded limit for cities and I... uhhh... have hit that limit multiple times, and I still wish I could go bigger.   III has that balance that later versions seem to have missed.  IV and V introduced new things that, while they are cool, also tend to sometimes bog the game down a bit more.  Sometimes those details are good, otherwise Paradox Games wouldn't be a thing.  But sometimes you don't need to go THAT deep and just want to build, develop, and conquer.  And this game does that ever so well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042651621', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1705940374}
review: Normally i woul recommend this game, as it is great, ithout the DLC. But seeing as this is the complete edition and that you cannot simply choose to play without, it's actually worse. The DLC changes a whole lot, and most clearly the difficulty. If you want to re-enjoy some good old fashioned CivIII, you shouldn't try with this, as you won't enjoy it.

review: Yes, it's a older style of gaming, but there is enough randomness in the world creation generator to keep you busy solving logistics balanced against forming a strategy. So many variables within the game as to allow it to have subtle nuances, even if you play the same world twice. Although Civ 2 is my favorite of all of the CIV product line, it is impossible to play now, even with a 16 bit emulator, so a close second is Civ 3. Typical game lasts 12 hours.

review: This is the best Game that was ever made. Its graphics have aged like fine wine and it‚Äôs still horribly addicting. My favorite strat is playing as the Vikings on archipelago, first I build the Great Library, this is easy even on higher difficulty levels since other civs do not prioritize researching literature, if possible I will also pick up the Great Lighthouse‚Ä¶ Once literature has been researched the science slider is set to zero, and all I do then is to build galleys and archers, the latter are ofc upgraded once the Berserk is available, using the gold saved thanks to the Great Library. Then the fun begins:)) Its also important to have some defensive units to protect newly conquered cities... Ah it seems I‚Äôm going to start a new game now. uwu ~ I'll use my GOG version tho!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198818784856', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 40992, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 165, 'playtime_at_review': 38076, 'last_played': 1710380415}
review: Its CIV III, not much else needs to be said. Its easily the best of the series for a few simple reasons. For one its graphic style still holds up surprisingly well, sure its not as advanced as VI which arguably has the best graphics, but it doesn't look weird like IV. It moves at a very fast pace and doesn't have a ton of glitches or slowdown like the later games do. Its more simple and doesn't add unnecessary elements to the game, and best of all. Its only $5 for the entire thing, no extra DLC or some rip-off leader pass, in fact you can actually customize your leader and be any civilization you can think of, or some made up civ like an alien race if you have the imagination. Easily top tier and brings hundreds of hours of enjoyment!

author: {'steamid': '76561198123681667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 11342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11048, 'last_played': 1692423151}
review:
I've played this game for over 10 years, playing off a CD rom until it came out on steam. It's one of the first games I ever played, and I still play it. 

It's a deep and engaging 4X where nearly all the interactions between systems is clear and logical. Unlike some of the newer civ games, which can paralyze you with the number of options, unique civ bonuses, and new systems, this is a tight experience without stripping out strategic complexity. 

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a good boomer 4X, and it's definitely alot cheaper than modern Civ.

author: {'steamid': '76561199153256518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1689251516}
review: I didn't grew up playing this game. I bought it recently and played it a bit with some of the easiest settings to get the hang of it and it's already very  fun. BUT WHY force me to use a dumb turn limit with no option of turning it off and have dumb stuff like this tell me that I failed in EVERY SINGLE playthrough very late in the game despite removing them every time ? Dumb idea and I wouldn't even care to rant if it was MANDATORY with making me choose only until 1000 turns with the default being just 500 !

author: {'steamid': '76561198034539026', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 44852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42706, 'last_played': 1699797433}
review:
Jedna z lepszych gier w serii Ciwilizacja. Owszem - sƒÖ nowsze gry takie jak Civ VI. SƒÖ bardziej rozbudowane gry pod wzglƒôdem system√≥w politycznych jak Civ IV. SƒÖ prostsze gry takie jak Civ II. SƒÖ bardziej zwariowane gry takie jak Civ Call 2 Power 1 & 2. SƒÖ interesujƒÖce xera z Civ takie jak Mankind. Niemniej jednak za CivilizacjƒÖ 3 przemawia kilka pozytyw√≥w:

- na dzie≈Ñ dzisiejszy jest to czƒô≈õƒá serii do kt√≥rej mo≈ºna znale≈∫ƒá (np. w serwisie CivFanatics) NAJWIƒòCEJ mod√≥w, dodatkowych jednostek, nowych grafik, scenariuszy, kampanii, patchy nieoficjalnych itd. Do ≈ºadnej innej gry tyle nie ma. Nie wiem nawet czy w og√≥le do jakiejkolwiek innej gry z poza serii jest tyle materia≈Ç√≥w stworzonych przez fan√≥w?

- prostota rozgrywki - zasady w tej czƒô≈õci Cywilizacji sƒÖ jeszcze w miarƒô nieskomplikowane wiƒôc je≈õli kto≈õ nie lubi skomplikowania systemu z Civ V i VI zar√≥wno pod wzglƒôdem gry jak i edytowania ≈õwiat√≥w - to to jest w≈Ça≈õnie ta czƒô≈õƒá Civ kt√≥ra jest dla niego.

- gra nie wymaga zaawansowanego sprzƒôtu ≈ºeby dzia≈Çaƒá; co prawda wiele os√≥b mo≈ºe raziƒá izometryczny rzut kt√≥ry tylko udaje tr√≥jwymiar (rze≈∫ba terenu i jednostki by≈Çy wyrenderowane w 3D ale gra pokazuje je jako grafiki 2D i animacje typu flicker) ale zaleta tego jest taka ≈ºe nie trzeba kupowaƒá nowej karty graficznej i procesora ≈ºeby gra dzia≈Ça≈Ça p≈Çynnie.

- Complete Edition zawiera od razy wszystkie DLC, nie trzeba jak w nowszych Civ kupowaƒá 10 dodatk√≥w, ≈ºeby zagraƒá w pe≈Çne zasady gry i mieƒá np. dodatkowe cywilizacje. 

- unikalne zasady gry kt√≥re nie zosta≈Çy niestety skopiowane w nastƒôpnych czƒô≈õciach, nie wiedzieƒá czemu. Mamy lƒÖdowe i morskie jednostki kt√≥re mogƒÖ atakowaƒá konkretny typ wrogich jednostek - wybierajƒÖc kt√≥ra jednostkƒô chcƒÖ zniszczyƒá tzw. stealth attack; jednostki kt√≥re szturmujƒÖc miasta mogƒÖ za darmo dodatkowo zniszczyƒá jego udoskonalenia np. mury; jednostki kt√≥re potrafiƒÖ po wykonaniu skutecznego ataku produkowaƒá tzw. niewolnicze zaciƒÖgi - statki pirackie mogƒÖ wykonaƒá aborda≈º kt√≥ry zako≈Ñczyƒá siƒô mo≈ºe przejƒôciem wrogie statku i pojawieniem siƒô darmowego statku pirackiego za kt√≥ry nie musimy p≈Çaciƒá koszt√≥w utrzymania, wojownicy po zabiciu wojownik√≥w wroga mogƒÖ zamieniƒá ich w niewolnik√≥w, robotnik√≥w pracujƒÖcych dla nas za darmo; jednostki powietrzne majƒÖ mo≈ºliwo≈õƒá wykonywania atak√≥w broniƒÖ inteligentnƒÖ - co pozwala im niszczyƒá umocnienia i udoskonalenia miast zamiast broniƒÖcych ich jednostek; czƒô≈õƒá jednostek specjalnego przeznaczenia posiada tzw. ZoC, strefƒô kontroli, kt√≥ra pozwala wykonywaƒá im atak na przechodzƒÖce obok nich wojska wroga bez anga≈ºowania siƒô w bezpo≈õrednie starcie - z jakiego≈õ powodu wiƒôkszo≈õƒá tych unikalnych zasad nie zosta≈Ça przeniesiona do kolejnych czƒô≈õci gry, co powa≈ºnie je zuba≈ºa ;-(

Niestety gram ma te≈º swoje lata i to widaƒá, bowiem wychodzƒÖ na jaw pewne wady:
- s≈Çaba optymalizacja; gra jest zrobiona proceduralnie zamiast obiektowo - jak nowsze czƒô≈õci a to oznacza, ≈ºe musimy po kolei zatwierdzaƒá ka≈ºde okienka wyskakujƒÖcych powiadomie≈Ñ albo gra nie ruszy siƒô dalej z turƒÖ, co jest denerwujƒÖce je≈õli w≈Ça≈õnie przerabiamy turƒô 32 cywilizacji a chcemy i≈õƒá sobie po kawƒô :P
- niestety mimo prostej grafiki nawet najnowsze procesory mogƒÖ sobie nie radziƒá z bardzo du≈ºymi mapami przy du≈ºej ilo≈õci cywilizacji i tury czasami potrafiƒÖ trwaƒá parƒô minut; gra≈Çem w tƒÖ grƒô jeszcze na PCtach z jednordzeniowymi procesorami i powiadam wam: tam tura czasami potrafi≈Ça trwaƒá p√≥≈Ç godziny xD
- gra ma ograniczenia zwiƒÖzane z powy≈ºszymi punktami - mo≈ºna mieƒá tylko ograniczonƒÖ liczbƒô cywilizacji - np. pobierajƒÖc mod z cywilizacjƒÖ Polska nie mo≈ºemy jej sobie "dodaƒá" - zastƒÖpi ona kt√≥rƒÖ≈õ z ju≈º istniejƒÖcych cywilizacji; to samo dotyczy miast na mapie: gra ma zakodowany na sta≈Çe maksymalny limit 256 miast co na gigantycznych mapach mo≈ºe byƒá za ma≈Ço i szybko ogranicza zdolno≈õƒá rozwoju nie tylko nas ale te≈º naszych przeciwnik√≥w, przez co wiele po≈Çaci lƒÖdu mo≈ºe pozostaƒá niezasiedlone - istniejƒÖ nieoficjalne patche znoszƒÖce te ograniczenia ale wtedy gra mo≈ºe przestaƒá dzia≈Çaƒá stabilnie;
- po dzi≈õ dzie≈Ñ nie naprawiony zosta≈Ç tzw. Warrior/Pikinier rush - jest to odmiana zerg rusha gdzie AI komputerowych graczy zaczyna produkowaƒá absurdalne ilo≈õci najta≈Ñszych i najs≈Çabszych jednostek tylko po to ≈ºeby zarzuciƒá nimi przeciwnika, co czasami bez save/load game taktyki mo≈ºe spowodowaƒá wyczerpanie i zniszczenie nawet najbardziej zaawansowanych obro≈Ñc√≥w; stƒÖd wziƒô≈Çy siƒô memy o w≈Ç√≥cznikach niszczƒÖcych czo≈Çgi w Civ III ;) nowsze wersje gry rozwiƒÖza≈Çy ten problem kontrowersyjnƒÖ zasadƒÖ ≈ºe mo≈ºe na 1 polu przebywaƒá tylko jedna jednostka wojskowa i 1 wspierajƒÖca - wiƒôc je≈õli kto≈õ tej zasady nie lubi to w Civ3 musi siƒô liczyƒá z tym, ≈ºe AI bƒôdzie robiƒá rushe :P
- gra ma bardzo ograniczone mo≈ºliwo≈õci modderskie - kod ≈∫r√≥d≈Çowy jest na sztywno oprogramowany w przeciwie≈Ñstwie choƒáby do starszej Civ Call to Power 2 czy nowszej Civ VI nie pozwala na obs≈Çugƒô skryptowych jƒôzyk√≥w programowania, przez co nie mo≈ºna zmieniaƒá, dodawaƒá i modyfikowaƒá nowych zasad gry jak to ma miejsce w najnowszych modach do najnowszych wersji serii - przez co modowanie sprowadza siƒô tylko dodawania nowych map, jednostek, cywilizacji i ew. zmiany parametr√≥w ju≈º istniejƒÖcych zasad
- gra ma bardzo ograniczony, w por√≥wnaniu z nowszymi wersjami, system awansu jednostek - nie pozwala te≈º na tworzenie armii morskich - czyli flotylli i armad jak w Civ VI, dostƒôpne sƒÖ tylko armie lƒÖdowe.

Pomimo wszystkich wymienionych wad zdecydowanie grƒô tƒô polecam - szczeg√≥lnie je≈õli chcecie jƒÖ wykorzystaƒá jako platformƒô dla mod√≥w do uniwers√≥w SF i Fantasy - poniewa≈º w≈Ça≈õnie do Civ3 jest ich najwiƒôcej - sƒÖ unikalne mody robiƒÖce totalnƒÖ konwersjƒô Civ3 do ≈õwiata mi. Warhammera WFB i 40k, Lord of the Rings, Game of Thrones, StarGate, Star Wars, Final Fantasy czy nawet Fallout.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989766649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 2386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2386, 'last_played': 1679855271}
review:
As old as time itself and about as archaic in its crude simplicity. Anyone picking up a 22 year old game in this day and age either has a fondness for unrefined and quite clunky game or a heavy dose of the memberberries.. However in the case of old Civilisation games the graphics have truly not altered that much of the core gameplay that will be very familiar to enjoyers of the later Civ-titles. Personally I picked this title up to game through the ‚ÄúMiddle-earth: Lord of the Mods‚Äù pack that truly transformed the generic Gandhi vs Attila gameplay into a more mellow fantasyesque theme where you can shoulder the mantle of Theoden, KING! in an all out struggle for domination against the forces of darkness.. 

The base game is fine and has aged quite well, however there are alot of players reporting issues with compatibility and getting it to play smoothly. This is the pure bane of retrogaming these days and though I had no problems with my arguably ok-ish rig your mileage may vary. If you truly enjoy the other civ-titles this is more of the same, and if you, like me, was there 3000 years ago, bashing in barbarian skulls and taking names, you might find a strange familiar feeling when booting up this relic of a bygone past. 

I recommend it, but I assume I'm already preaching to the choir.. Who in their right mind would pick up a 22-year old Civ title on a whim? Well, in that case, good on you kind fellow, we will make a deity out of you yet!

author: {'steamid': '76561198156050893', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1681561127}
review: While I loved this game when I first played years ago, I can't in good faith recommend trying this outside of the nostalgia. The game feels like a mess compared to modern standards, and has aged extremely poorly. To even get the game to run at all on most modern pcs/laptops, it requires you to jump through hoops like editing .ini files which is something an average player should never have to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120390333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 12058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12058, 'last_played': 1679875735}
review:
Es la experiencia central de la saga de civilization, con un poco de micromanagement al momento de manejar las ciudades, pero en donde en general es la estrategia √©conomica lo que est√° en el centro del exito de cada partida. Una expansi√≥n veloz en el numero de ciudades por lo general va a ser la mejor manera de lograr el triunfo. Lo que es lamentable ya que la estrategia exitosa va a primar por sobre las sutilezas y fortalezas de cada civilizaci√≥n, por lo que al final, aunque hayan algunas que faciliten uno u otro estilo de juego, si se corre por la victoria de dominaci√≥n o viaje espacial, que parecen ser las dos canonicas, las estrategias exitosas ser√°n siempre similares. A pesar de esto el nucleo central del juego adem√°s del concepto general de controlar una cultura y civilizaci√≥n desde los primeros acentamientos hasta el futuro, pasando por guerras, epidemias, hambrunas, √©pocas doradas y descubrimientos magnificos es tan atractivo, que a√∫n con las limitaciones de esta versi√≥n del juego, sigue siendo uno de las experiencias m√°s adictivas y placenteras del medio.

Como modo secundario hay una serie de campa√±as que van desde el poblamiento del crecente fertil hasta la campa√±a naval en el pacifico de la segunda guerra mundial. Aunque el concepto es interesante y poder Civilizar a los europeos manejando el califato de cordoba o crear un futuro mejor evitando que Napole√≥n se enrede en rusia y en vez enfoque sus energ√≠as en Inglaterra y Austria, en general estas campa√±as siguen siendo la historia escolar de occidente, de mesopotamia a la grecia minoica, roma, una europa dividida y una conquista de una america casi despoblada. Solo dos de las campa√±as no se concentran en poderes occidentales, una en meso america previo a la conquista y una segunda en el periodo de guerras civiles del jap√≥n que llev√≥ a la conformaci√≥n del shogunato. Lo que es lamentable porque a pesar de que se presenta la versi√≥n "occidental" de la historia, la saga ha tenido desde sus origenes otros pueblos milanarios, como china, india y Persia o grandes figuras militares como shaka zulu. Por lo que no incluir campa√±as que reflejen esos sectores de la historia que generalmente son olvidados parece un desperdicio. El segundo pecado de estas campa√±as y realmente el peor en terminos de jugabilidad, es que en su mayor√≠a se enfocan en el aspecto de guerra, lo que creo que es uno de los m√°s debiles de los civilization hasta que se deja de permitir el stack gigante de unidades. Sobre todo en la campa√±a de mezo america, donde tanto los Incas como los Mayas fueron civilizaciones con econom√≠as muy complejas y estados guerreros muy ritualizados que contrastan duramente con lo que pasaba en europa y asia en epocas paralelas. 

Una experiencia para cualquiera interesado en los juegos de estrategia o la historia de los videojuegos en general. Si solo quieres jugar un Civ, te recomiendo que partas con los modernos, pero si ya has jugado varios y quieres ver como la saga se fue construyendo poco a poco este es un buen principio antes de escarbar por las versiones de DoS.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076834296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 243560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235037, 'last_played': 1707528052}
review: If you ever liked any strategy game, this game is a must have... I played, probably, more than 15 000 hours and still going strong. There is no better entertainment  value, for money, out there. I would pay not 5 bucks, that I payed, for this game, but 1000$, if I had to...  It is the best, Civilization game, in the series, by far, as Civ 4, has been destroyed, by nonsense such as artillery, "trowing" itself, onto the opponent to do damage, no lethal bombardment for planes and few other things. The only three things, that Civ 4 has, is health in the cities (making a game richer), "live" in-game editor (must have, for this kind, of long games), and great peoples concept. But Civ 3 Complete, has the most comprehensive editor, of any game, I ever played. That is why I was able to play, for 20 years, and still be entertained. I created 200 additional units, from strategic bombers, to static bunker defences, and I found an Icon, for each, on Civ 3 Fanatics, web site. So. now I have everything, from hummer, to Suhoi Su 35, as part of the game, that works (there is a web link, on Civ fanatics site, that explains how to do this). I also created a scenarios: from my infantry scenarios, where you can build modern infantry units, even from ancient start to the game, to my modern scenarios, where AI starts with bunkers, over all of his strategic resources. Also you would think that bombing (modern me, all others ancient start), the ancient enemies would get old, but trust me it is great fun, with locked alliance option, you can have 31 enemies and fight them, all at once...Note: If you want to use editor, you need to find it first, in the Civ 3, directory and then use help menu to teach you what is what. It is the best help menu I encountered anywhere (not just gaming) , but still far from perfect. Anyway enough said, buy a game and play on easier level, as playing, Sid difficulty, without the editor, is not much fun. AI gets 3 settlers (to your one) and advances 2.5 times faster than you, in technological age. I played a game now-days, without editor and with all my knowledge of the game, all AI had tanks, while I had swordsman's. But, with editor, I created games, in which only I can build, all the Wonders of the World. Lol. It is about having fun, not adhering to, Mr Data's, sense of justice. It is all about abundance and only then, realism - only when it is fun to do so...I also deleted coal, from the game, in order to delete, railroads as they are, too unrealistic, with its infinite movement, on those railroads. So, game, with just roads, is way more entertaining and realistic, at the same time. But, even without editor, Civ 3 is so much better, than Civ 5 or six, and I have never completed, either Civ 5 or 6, but played, Civ 3 instead, even though I own all three games. In Civ 5 and 6, they destroyed the game, by not allowing to place, more than one unit, per hex. I spent more time, trying to place units, on the map, than playing the actual game, overall. Civ 4, on the other hand, I played, 1 to 50, compared to, Civ 3. That tells you all you need to know about this franchise...Civ 3: graphics, concept and editor, is the best, in the series, so you can not go wrong. There is some issues with interface, as it is poorly done, in a sense, that automatic unit activation, is all over the place, and it makes game harder to play. Also AI, does not use artillery, armies or sea invasions properly, but every game's AI is still like that, even now-days, and if you are looking for perfect computer game - you end up playing none...Enough said - have fun, anyway, and good luck....

author: {'steamid': '76561198065384645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 79139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36813, 'last_played': 1690476593}
review: I've owned this game since it was released, some 30 years ago.  It's a diversion from complicated things in the real world that gives me an opportunity for diversion as I mull over what needs to be done next, for real.  There's the aspect of discovery of new lands, continents and what resources that your civ has available nearby. The race to discover and build wonders before other civs manage to do so. Managing your civ's citizen's happiness.  All-in-all, a pleasant diversion that doesn't require my shooting somebody up.

7/10 - GOOD!

First Civilization game I ever played. Blew my mind when I was a kind and I was instantly hooked on the genre and "one more turn" mentality. Countless sleepless nights playing this gem. Nowadays, it's rather outdated and you will be much better served by Civ 5 or CIv 6.

review:
I used to play Civ I (alone) and CivNet  / Alpha Centauri with a friend. 
With all its limitations (especially the square tiles) we greatly prefer Civ III to later Civ games (and to ENDLESS games) because of the uncluttered, readable map and the lack of added bloat.
We care for gameplay, not for show. Civ III is a perfectly balanced game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033429287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 72784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61777, 'last_played': 1697082788}
review: Civ 3: Complete is the perfect medium between all the Civ games.  Not too simple to be boring and repetitive, not too complex to be bogged down and confusing, this installment is TBS perfection.  Each civilization is different in approach and play style, and the AI is surprisingly adaptive for a game from the early 2000s.  Easy is still fun, and the higher difficulties can be incredibly challenging.  Overall one of my favorite games, 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561199055204376', 'num_games_owned': 1514, 'num_reviews': 635, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1675972197}
review:
I've never played any of the Civilization games apart from Civ VI, which i found very confusing and overwhelming. The idea of the Civ games is really appealing to me so i wanted to try Civ III because it looks a lot less intimidating and more managable.
From the little i've seen from the game that does indeed seem to be the case (there are a lot less options and things to keep track of) but there is no tutorial and the guidebook you can click on in your library leads nowhere. This is really a bummer as i imagine that the Civ III can be a lot of fun if you are giving a fighting chance to understand the rules. it sadly seems to be a "figure it out yourself" kinda thing, which is really a pain in the a** when talking about a strategy game. :/

review: A pretty addictive and entertaining game, with a few really annoying flaws (strategic resources that can be nearly impossible to get, boorish AI relative to predecessor Alpha Centauri, cultural conversions/depositions that can wipe out your entire army, etc) that mostly affect players like me who can't help but torture themselves by playing the higher difficulties, and prefer tiny maps because the bigger ones take FOREVER (ok when you're 20, not so much when you're 35).

review: I'm sure the dedicated fans, and fans of older strategy games will love this, and maybe I'm completely wrong. But the user friendliness of this game isn't the greatest and for new players, it will take a great deal of time just trying to figure out basic concepts and mechanics. Even with tutorials online I've struggled heavily with those. It is, however, a decent game with all of that in mind. I'm sure a lot of these issues are due to how dated the game is.

author: {'steamid': '76561199000484929', 'num_games_owned': 16, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2893, 'last_played': 1707596196}
review: Sid Meier's Civilization III: Complete is just simply an amazing game. It goes through history, allowing players to simulate being a world leader in the past. Personally, I really like exploring the map and completing the tech tree, but players can become whatever they want in the game, whether that is a mad scientist like me or a warmonger. While the game is old, it plays very well. The animations are great, and it even includes multiplayer. Overall, it's a great game that you'll play for hours on end without realizing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198811408155', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3163, 'last_played': 1686586979}
review: This is my absolute favourite Civilization game, I have played it for years (I own all of the mainline Civ games, and a few "offshoots"), and it still runs with few issues on my Windows 10 machine. It is easily moddable, great new concepts added, and I have played countless hours of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122156630', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1894, 'last_played': 1703127399}
review:
Over 20 years later and this is still a fantastic game. An overhead strategy game that allows for a surprising amount of creativity, variation in play and replay value. The world editor that comes alongside it is an amazing addition that makes it very difficult to get tired of. 

Whether you want to sit in one little spot and grind til your wrists break, expand outward and conquer the map, try a unique challenge, or utterly decimate every last rival until you're the last one left on the map, this game gives you a huge amount of customization both in gamestyle and winning conditions. It's also fantastic how after so long this game still has multiplayer support, meaning even friends across the world can wage war with each other, whether you want to do it turn based or simultaneously.

I do dock a few tiny points for how slow multiplayer loading can be, but given it's such an old game and only the third installment in a huge franchise with multiple spinoffs and is grinding up toward its 7th mainline title, I can fully understand how and why the internet and LAN options are not entirely optimized.

Especially considering that nowadays this game is only 5$ for the complete package including all the DLC originally released, I HIGHLY recommend this one to anyone who likes strategy games. Sure, the later games have better graphics, different strategies and may add some features that make this one fairly outdated in comparison, it's still an absolute blast to play and worth giving a shot if you haven't already, or coming back to if you've been ignoring it for awhile.

Love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031709258', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 34169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34169, 'last_played': 1672939833}
review:
I have played this game ever since it came out. In total, I should have clocked around 4000-5000 hours on Civ 3 Vanilla, Play theWorld and Conquest. This game is very satisfying. I can allow myself to share the following about Civilization 3: Complete edition:

1) You can allow yourself to play with mouse only. This is not only very convenient but it is also a testimony for an almost perfect GUI.

2) Well arranged icons, buttons and menus. Everything is exactly where you expect it to be.

3) This version, the complete edition is the best you can have. Each civilization in this game feels unique and each special unit feels special. With Conquest and this Complete edition, they finally managed to find the balance.

They finally managed to fix the issue with the Great Person: it really provides +20% Scientific Output. Although, you might want or need to spend it on a Wonder?! You never know, as no two games are the same.

Always play in such a way, that you use the specific bonus for your civilization. When your special unit wins in battle, you will have a Golden Age! Never forget about that. If you are a peaceful builder, then build wonders, which triggers Golden Ages for your specific type of civilization.

Stack all "Double Scientific Output" wonders in one city.

Always try to produce an Army, which to be victorious. Then, you can build more armies and after the Pentagon, you can have 4 units per Army. After you produced the maximum amount of Armies, you can disband the oldest ones (with older obsolete units) and build a brand new one, full with the latest and deadliest units.

Do not go for dead-end research (Steam Engine, Fascism, etc.), especially if you have a small scientific lead, so that you can gain an even bigger margin. Never underestimate the power of the carrier! Always try to get Philosophy first (one free Technology), then the Great Library and then Republic. If you meanwhile manage to get some resources and roads, plus save yourself from conflicts, then you will win later in the game. If not, then Monarchy/Feudalism is the right way, especially if you will not have any luxury resources. In such scenarios, you can skip researching Republic, as there is Democracy down the line. Also, if you do not have luxury resources and nobody to trade with, then Sistine Chapel is a must.

I might one day write a "how-to play civ" manual for all civ games with the most optimum strategies for each game, according to the amount of resources, the terrain you are on and the neighboring civs around you, as per turn 10 or 15. Remember, every turn counts and sometimes games are being lost for 1-2 turns.

Never-ever underestimate Espionage! Never!

I love this game! One more turn for life! One more turn till I die!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057734042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 38830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 908, 'playtime_at_review': 20530, 'last_played': 1710811369}
review: So I am a poor old man and I cannot afford a nice computer right now. Life. I can play CIV III on my little weenie hp laptop. I have CIV VI, and played it a great deal, but CIV III it is until I get a computer with the guts to run it. What I have found is this: the older versions are far more combat oriented. I suspected as much, as religion became more important in later versions, as did diplomacy, with the addition of city-states. The simplicity of the earlier versions lends to conquest victories, as cultural and diplomatic victories offer little in regards to actual gameplay. These victory types seem much more passive in CIV III. But I love this version, because the AI is brutal and unforgiving. You cannot make mistakes, you always pay. I believe that makes these versions a tad more realistic in feel, though low reward visually.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089787824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1672436513}
review: Civ 1 and 2 are way more customizable, the map choices suck considering civ 1 had the real world map as an option and this game doesnt. There is a map seed system but there is no way to browse the seeds, the game has a ton of limits that dont exist in 1 and 2. You cant even play forever the game ends after a maxed out 1000 turns so you cant just keep playing forever to get max tech. I didnt even get past the menus and i knew the game would suck compared to 1 and 2. So far my favorite civ game is still the SNES game after all these years. The lack of map options is unacceptable considering this game is like 50x bigger than the SNES game and they couldnt even put planet earth in the game. Also the game keeps crashing, its not fully compatible with modern PCs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198844146206', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1701880681}

author: {'steamid': '76561197967255834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2717, 'last_played': 1686268898}
review: I grew up on CIV 2 and have puts 100s of hours into 5/6 as an adult.  I decided to jump in the wayback machine and give this game a spin as its one in the series I missed... boy does it not hold up.  I'm a competent civ player and can usually win up 2 difficulties from medium in modern civ games, without too much trouble. I'm playing this one on EASY and every other AI has declared war on me despite me having a strong army, getting wonders is a struggle, combat is an endless slog despite the dumb AI throwing units away.  Compared to modern games the UI sucks, the music sucks,  the combat sucks because its incredibly RNG dependent and one unit will always die (unlike modern games where there is RNG but usually well positioned units won't die to a single attacker).  I'm sure it was revolutionary for its day but this one does not hold up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063463096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 12693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11496, 'last_played': 1671339639}
review:
i got civ 6 for free on epic and was playing it and enjoying myself until i realized the game is broken in that the computer never builds any army (even on the hardest difficulty) which makes the game pointless i decided to try 3 again which i loved back in the day on CD and man this game is just so much more balanced so much more fun, music and presentation is top notch and AI is smart. before i just face checked swordman and  tanks now i am using all the different types of units and they work so well together. This game is so much better than 6. If you've never tried this game its 5 dollars and will be well more than worth the money.

BTW this is an old game and has minor non game breaking issues on steam, to skip the opening cut scene after booting do not click, instead hit escape or your game will crash. There used to be different music when trading depending on the time period and mood of the civ leader but its not there now which is a very small non gameplay thing. (your only in that screen for a few minutes a game). lastly when when you complete the game you'll go through the awesome post game screens i think its when the barbarian hits the carnival meter with the hammer to tell you how much you suck, again do not click or it will freeze hit escape i believe. That all i have encountered.

I CRASHED??- there is an auto-save feature so don't rage quit if the game crashes on you which even used to happen on the disk version too i've crashed 3 times in 180 hours so not too bad all you need to do is load game and there should be an autosave tab you will only lose a turn or 2.
