author: {'steamid': '76561198012473463', 'num_games_owned': 4062, 'num_reviews': 417, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1587092500}
review:
[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Sid Meier's Civilization III holds classic status for a lot of people, and for good reason. Given its age, it holds up suprisingly well. If this review was only comparing it to its contemporaries, Civilization III would get a perfect score. Unfortunately, when compared to later Civilization games, it begins to falter. The biggest knock against Civilization III isn't really an issue with the game, its just that later games build on its foundation so well. Now that we are on the 6th game in the franchise, there is an entry for everyone. If people want the most modern, sleek, and optimized version of Civilization, they can play 6. If they want an old school feel they can play 4. And if they want a sort of middle ground, the 5th game does a great job balancing those 2 elements. For Civilization III, it plays a lot like Civ 4 but with some pretty popular mechanics missing. To me, Civ 3 doesn't really have a niche that it excels at, and that's why I can't recommend it. Every feature is done better in a different Civ game, leaving little reason for me to revisit it 20 years later.

5/10
[quote]
Visit our [url=https://www.mmmreviews.com]website[/url] for more in-depth reviews and recommendations
[/quote]

review: okay so i have played age of empires, red alert, sudden strike, crusader etc.. this is like those titles.. in the beginning its UI is not very user friendly like those other straight forward titles.. but one tutorial video for like 5-10 min on youtube and i was well on my way to grasping the rest of the things myself.. and i have to say it was rewarding.. so yes dont be put off by its not so user friendly UI.. first start playing peaceful difficulty to learn the conomics of things and go from there..

author: {'steamid': '76561198278020954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 40432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6799, 'last_played': 1709050308}
review:
I'll be honest, I only play this on the easiest difficulty because I like building cities all over the map in much the same way some people enjoy coloring in coloring books. The newer Civ games have more complexity to them but don't let you do that as easily, and this is the one I grew up playing the most, so I like it. 

If you feel the very specific urge to paint the world your color, then pick this up, I guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561199005486044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1693430728}
review:
As good and funny game as always but so bad input controls for the user, I wish it would be easier to build and move by using groups of workesr and troops, certainly stack system  helps a lot but it is still not enough, despite of that it's a Classic of Strategy for me and I could play it always. 
The real problem was after installing it and trying to play it at a suitable and good resolution on Windows 10, fortunately the answer was given by noikeee on this post: https://steamcommunity.com/app/3910/discussions/0/864979455450106599/?ctp=3 

Post Quote: 
Hello, i just fixed the problem for me with 1920 res monitor.

I use windows 10. Videmode=1600, Playintro=0.

I think the trick for win10 users is to :
rightclick civ3conquest.exe, preferences, Compatability, Overide high dpi scaling behaviour. Scaling performed by Application.

review:
I like the building aspect of the game mostly. I prefer cultural wins the best. Well and of course Alpha-Centori SPACE WIN is the ultimate win. 
I don't like when you get ganged up on and can't progress because of war. 
Or if you can't get at least a couple Wonders built.
I also don't like when the game is like 1890 and we have machine guns.  I prefer the advances stay in pace more with the age period/

review: Wonderful turn based game, if not for the glitch I'm about to talk about it'd be 10/10 from me, even with the glitch it's still a 7-8/10. The only problem with the game is that if you attempt to click during a cutscene the game will not work and you will be forced to close the game, which wouldn't normally be a big problem except if you get into the game and forget to save for a long time, then win (what happened to me), if you don't click on the x then the wheel of death will appear and the game will be unresponsive and you'll be forced to go all the way back to your last save, which again isn't a big problem if you remember to save often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313270715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 11675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1597440132}
review: Civ 3 was the breakthrough for this classic turn-based strategy franchise. It's just detailed enough as to be intuitive, while not getting overly complicated as the later games in the series. Easy to pick up; hard to put down. Civ 3 was a childhood favorite that occupied hours at a time, and picking it up again after 10+ years is a real treat. It takes small storage and downloads in minutes (hooray for old games!). The graphics and AI are poor, but the nostalgia stands strong. As long as you can bear with the occasional crashes (it maybe didn't age so well? save often!), you'll get a great experience with a most excellent game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198798153901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 77263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3764, 'last_played': 1690609673}
review:
There really should be a neutral option for whether or not you recommend a game, this one is ok, and if it's on sale then maybe you should get it.
It can be fun building cities and expanding to build a vast empire, but the strategic turn based combat is seriously broken.
The game has 8 difficulty levels and on the easiest it's too easy, but if you're one notch above the lowest setting you're REGULARLY going to lose a lot of fights that you really shouldn't be losing, and by that I mean you'll have veteran 3/2 units losing to regular 1/1 and 1/2 units, it completely kills the fun factor of the game for me when my superior units keep losing to inferior ones.

review: I grew up playing Civ III so it's nostalgic for me. Has all the core mechanics of later civ games, but it's boiled down to just enough that you can jump right in. I like that you can stack combat units (not a feature in Civ 5) which felt more realistic than battles spread across a dozen tiles, but the stacks are easier to manage than the 'stack of doom' mechanic present in Civ 4. Very fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158630769', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1584304823}
review:
Pfff.... El juego es bueno. Tiene detalles muy interesantes y siendo uno de los primeros de la saga hay que tener en cuenta el legado que ha dejado pero la realidad es que se hace increiblemente tedioso. El hierro y los caballos (los dos principales recursos que debes encontrar si quieres hacer algo en early) son tan jodidamente escasos que puedes llegar a recorrer el mapa de una punta a otra sin encontrar ni uno ni el otro. Esto provoca un problema serio dado que no puedes enfrentarte en combate a civilizaciones que si tienen estos materiales, ademas de dejarte tecnologicamente estancado y el hecho de encontrarlos o no es pura suerte, yo por ejemplo he empezado 6 partidas seguidas tratando de encontrarlos al principio y no ha habido forma. 

A√±adido a esto no hay forma de customizar la partida para hacer estos recursos tan basicos mas comunes, sinceramente me parece un fallo de dise√±o serio dado que te da otras mil opciones para personalizar el mapa que son completamente inutiles.

3/10  Es triste que por un detalle tan simple el juego se vuelva tan aburrido.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993023804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 1294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1294, 'last_played': 1583583390}
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#267 out of 612)... it's time for Sid Meier's Civilization III.

Arguably the most important, if not the best, entry in the venerable Civilization series. While today Civilization 5 may be the definitive version of Civilization, Civilization III used to claim that spot, and is still very much worth revisiting today--especially if you're looking to play Civ on an older PC that might groan and creak under the strain of modern games.

Civilization III is incredibly polished and boasts an enormous amount of content, especially with regard to mods. The 2D visuals still look gorgeous today and a modern CPU can bruteforce its way through that usual murderer of Civilization playthroughs, the late-game slog. Be warned, however, that Civilization III is a very old game, and it shows its age. Mostly this manifests in the UI, which is considerably less intuitive and clear than we're accustomed to these days--and, perhaps most problematically for new players, there aren't any tooltips. If you've never played a Civilization game before, you're in for a steep learning curve. And if it's been a while since you've played Civilization III and you're looking to revisit an old favorite, well, unless your memory is much greater than mine, odds are you'll have a fair bit of a learning curve to muddle through as well. Who'd've thought the most important innovation in the 4x genre over the last 20 years would be something as simple as tooltips?

Well, anyway. It's Civilization III: one of the finest turn-based strategy games ever produced. In many respects it falls short of its successors, most notably the wildly imaginative expansions of Civilization IV and the perfectly polished systems and mechanics of Civilization V, but it remains an excellent title nonetheless.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116287864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 35269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 221, 'playtime_at_review': 13051, 'last_played': 1710894989}
review: Civ III makes you feel like you're actually in control of everything. It's also pretty cool, how despite that, it also depicts a realism in the defenses of others, no matter how small they may seem. Projecting how our intellectual war, space race, politics of keeping people happy within our own country, are much more of a conflict for us all than an external attack. True freedom, comes when one realizes that God puts no burden on us at all. It's only when we strive after the devil's world of greed, riches and badness, that the act of doing things we know are wrong are what put boundaries and chains on ourselves. God never limits us. You can do anything and all things good until you're blue in the face and pass out, and he's cool with that. But when you start doing bad things, the limitations come because it's not acceptable by the others around you, even others doing bad themselves. They don't like an unfair advantage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198936698845', 'num_games_owned': 24, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1582404139}
review:
The game is very clunky and the 'tutorial' mode offers no help with most of the issues. The biggest problem i had were with an apparent unbalanced scaling in how the AI nations behave, even in the easiest mode. THey expand continuously with apparently no concern for territory or money. This further creates a problem when they settle cities between yours and comlain every time your troops move through the region as they HAVE TO DO to go anywhere. 
Another issue is lack of clarity in how to or ability to deal with internal issues such as civil disorder. The corruption mehanic doent mke a lot of sense and there doesnt see to be anything the player can do to minimize it except literally build all your cities directly around your capitol, which while strategically may be ideal, seriously limits expansion prospects. Building roads is a suggested mitigation move, but it doesn't appear to actually do anything. it's also apparently impossible to actually maintain or affect where the money in your cities goes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100098549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3138, 'last_played': 1514640413}
review: A classic 4X game and a good product of its time. A bit outdated in graphics (though it still holds some charm!) and mechanics, but it's fun nonetheless. I would recommend it to fans of the Civilization franchise that wish to play an older game for whatever reason; it is definitely outclassed by its more modern sequels.

review:
CIV III is the best of the lot.   An upgrade from Two, and the later versions are cosmetic tweaks only.
This one will keep you occupied conquering the world and will still leave you with some cash in your pocket.
My favourite version.   The only one that tops this - Alpha Centauri.   A game lost to time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127777663', 'num_games_owned': 70, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 100068, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93121, 'last_played': 1674533112}
review: Greatest game ever.  Only 2 real issues that I have ever had problems with.  #1  Automated exploring is idiotic.  If you send two units out they always end up in the same area or retrace their steps for 10 turns to make it back to one overlooked square they missed earlier instead of continuing into unexplored areas.  #2  Sometimes battles against vastly inferior opponents ends up with them winning.  E.G.  4 units with attacks of 4 go against 3 units with defenses of 2.  The attackers are wiped out.  This consistently happens in Civ, where a vastly superior unit is defeated by a vastly inferior unit.  I just sing a diddy, "the impossible last stand, the spearman defends his land, against waves of swordsmen, it's the impossible last stand."  That's how often it happens, I made up a silly song.  Other than that, I've never played a game more in my life.

review:
This is an old school game written by one of the greats in the industry. It is heavy on strategy and number crunching capability. Less so on cute graphics. I tried the newer versions, but find they are stuffed with flashy high res graphics and animation, but actual game decisions and movements are very slow. 
Not for everyone, you should probably skip this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198425637852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 22320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1707693202}
review: Amazing Game! Best instillation in the franchise if you ask me! A fun RTS with many factions to pick from (I believe it's 31 to be exact)! Enjoying making my own maps and playing them. Accessing the editor is a little difficult at first because you don't open it through steam, but your file browser instead (There's forums for this if you're interested)! The game is built upon many aspects which gives it a unique play-stile where you get to manage your Economy, Culture, Military, Diplomacy, Science/Technological advancements throughout the Bronze age, Midieval era, the Middle ages, The industrial era, the Modern era and beyond! Definately a 5/5 for me! And it certainly takes it's place among my top 10 game franchises along with The total war series, Halo, Call of Duty, Fortnite, Tomb Raider, Uncharted, Resistance, Men of War, Command and Conquer, and Star wars Battlefront! Definitely worth the money! Enjoy folks! Oh, and also, the difficulty varies significantly with the eight or so different levels, so for those of you who love a challenge, this game's for you! For those who want to easily walk all over their opressors, this game's for you! And for all of those who love their games so hard that all they ever do is get their butt's whooped, This games for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198089472337', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1579142090}
review:
I wish I could recommend this game, but it has changed so much. I played the "normal" edition (less playable civilizations, simpler mechanics, etc) of Civ 3 for 100s of hours as a kid. This game was a big part of my childhood. But, I do believe there must have been some digression and tweaking done for the "complete" version. 

The game seems very unbalanced, there are some bugs when talking to other civilizations (Windows 10), and it was just genuinely harder than it used to be even on the easiest settings. The combat mechanics bring a lot of unbalanced struggle to the game, unfortunately. It is frustrating to lose a majority of your army to one or two enemy units. It didn't used to be like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030803647', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1605727017}

review: This is still my favourite iteration of the Civilization franchise. It may not be as deep or flashy, but it has the aesthetics and epic atmosphere that I expect from a game of Civ. This Complete edition offers the most broad and fine-tuned edition of the game yet, and all passionate Civ fans owe it to themselves to give it a try.

Gerade die Erweiterung Conquests ist sehr gut gelungen, durch Kampagnen mit ver√§nderten Spieloptionen, mit dem Fokus auf historischen Schlachten.
Auch heute - trotz drei weiterer Nachfolger - ist das Spiel immer noch ein Blick wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017792109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 225604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92450, 'last_played': 1704762975}
review:
This is a fantastic strategy game against "fair" AI player, until one of the civilizations suddenly acquires "cheat" level power and wealth. All countries were similar within reason. I just quit after a long "building process". One of the opposing countries suddenly advanced to high level mechanics. My horse cavalry was being attacked by aircraft, automatic weapons, and tanks. No fun. Very disappointing. Happens every time. Too bad, otherwise a great game with simple, responsive graphics. Later versions have "silly", cartoon-like  graphics and are not as responsive.

Tried once again. After advancing into the industrial age, my AI opponents suddenly gained huge advances. Once again, found my horse cavalry defending against mechanized armored units and aircraft. When I viewed their technology, a few rounds earlier, we were almost even in terms of advancement. Very frustrating to work so hard, only to have the AI civs cheat! May try the cartoon style later versions, but they are not as nimble as the older version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198163737903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 102370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22932, 'last_played': 1701053670}
review: You can change the variables of the size of world, the climate, the hostility level of barbarians, and so much more.  Lots of strategic turn-based fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198820886609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1605999135}
review: This is NOT the Civ III that you used to play. The "complete" version turned the game even on the easiest setting into an impossible mess. As soon as any AI meets you, they instantly hate you and turn on you, regardless of the settings, even least aggressive. No such thing as "friendly" or "polite". It's just "OH! It's YOU!!!", then they usually demand something outrageous, and then they declare war and attack you with swarms of units there is no way that they actually built. You can have units that are 3 generations ahead of another player, and it will take 3 of them to make even a dent in 1 of theirs. 1 of their warriors will take out several of your medieval infantry without a problem. Doesn't matter what land your tile is, you get no defensive bonuses. You could have any fortified units on top of a mountain, and a warrior will happily tear through you like you're made out of tissue paper. Not to mention they can build whatever they want regardless of resources, and they don't have to fund or pay for units, so 1 city can create dozens of units every couple of turns. No matter how good you are, you can't withstand a swarm of several dozen units that are overpowered, and have the strength of industrial era weapons, attacking your cities each and every turn from the very beginning. And that's on the easiest settings!!! I'm all for a challenge, but at least make it a realistic challenge that is even remotely in the vicinity of fair. Might also be nice to be able to focus on other areas of the game like culture or science, as opposed to the game just always being one big, neverending melee set to the tune of Slayer's War Ensemble. So go find a disc version that's not this Complete one. The "Complete" means "Complete Garbage".

author: {'steamid': '76561198444031442', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1763, 'last_played': 1649787896}
review: Hab die deutsche Version ca 10 Jahre lang gespielt und bin dann irgendwann auf den f√ºnften teil umgestiegen und es wieder angefangen, das ist Nostalgie pur.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202260368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 9960, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1702585299}
review:
Timeless and perfect.

Much different from the newer Civs in my opinion. Civ 3 feels like an epic board game: ridiculous numbers of units (on the same tile!) and sprawling empires with dozens of cities. A great option for micro-managers, but you don't have to make it complicated to have fun. The soundtrack is phenomenal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198341572113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1579368807}
review:
...Well, on a sale of 1 to 10 in difficulty, I place it roundabouts a 8.5, because, and I actually have played longer on another account, in the 3 years I've been attempting to beat "Easy" mode, I have done so exactly 0 times. Maybe Im a terrible player, but, warning issued. Prepare to be stymied.
 One complaint I might have is the balancing mechanics between AI and the Player. Unless you go aggressive expansionist, or seclude yourself from the rest of the AI, you will be dominated swiftly. Is there really any chance of success if you spawn next to an AI? No. They will get out 12 Archers before you can build One measly Warrior.
 Otherwise, it's a great game, but If you'd want more winnability, try out CIV5. If you're a "do or die" Masochist who wants to prove their strategic genius, may the odds be ever in your Favor. This is the game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115243927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5915, 'last_played': 1591027590}
review:
Definitely viable in 2019, at least for a person who never played the newer ones. Combat can be extremely annoying in that its outcome is sometimes way more random than it should be, but apart from that Civ 3 is very entertaining. The game is relatively simple after you understand all the little details, but it offers great strategic depth with how everything is interconnected.

Do not approach if you don't have much free time! A single game can take twenty-something hours if you're the type who plays slow, analyzes, and wants  to micro-manage a lot.

review: The AI is a cheating bastard, Spearmen can beat tanks in battles, Hannibal has muttonchops in the modern era, the late game music has a serious 90s vibe. This game is my childhood; even all these years later it's still one of the best, if not the very best 4X game ever made in my opinion. Sure, it lacks some polish (no put those hussars away, I said *polish* not *Polish*), but it is still immensely playable even 20 years later.

review:
Awesome Civ game from before they got too mixed up with stupid add-ons: no religion, no princesses etc. Just the core aspects to make a really fantastic game...

Also, Play The World is incredible: a massive map with a huge number of nations, all modded to be slightly different. When the game first came out it would take my old computer about 20 minutes to work through the computer's moves but on a modern computer it plays like a dream.

review:
CI gioco da 20 anni e non smette mai di piacermi. A differenza degli altri CIV che magari hanno una grafica molto buona e molte piu tecnologie e unit√†. Mi rendo conto che CIV 3 √® quello fatto meglio. Perch√® permette battaglie assurde e da veramente l'idea del numero e della sostanza di un vero esercito. Poi ce maggior controllo della mappa e si riescono a capire piu facilmente certi concetti.
La pecca √® la ripetivit√† delle partite, a volte manca un po di novit√†. Con le mod ci si diverte ma sono difficili da installare. Ho sempre sperato che Sid Meiers riuscisse a rifare un CIV 3 HD con piu potenzialit√†, perch√® la base era veramente buona ma temo non succeder√† mai. Ormai da CIV 4 in poi i modelli di gioco sono cambiati radicalmente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067201396', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1576416724}
review:
The gold standard for Civilization games. I've put in many hours in the newer versions and this one (Civ3) still delivers. Graphics are dated, but it runs on everything including the newest Windows 10. I lost my old cd, so it is nice that you can pick it up on steam.

First ten minutes:
- lost my worker to a barbarian.
- Incas wanted a tech. I refused.
- Incas declared war.
- Incas warrior kills four spearmen.
- Civil unrest erupts in Rome.

Oh baby, we are back.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198272085658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 14967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9952, 'last_played': 1704690234}
review: Civ III is simple, some of the game mechanics are broken, but for a 2001 grand strategy game, this is right up there with the best. Some incredible mods go a long way -- Worldwide (for general gameplay balance) and MEM II (for an amazing Crusader Kings style game) are my favorites. I've probably logged well over 1,000 hours back when I owned the disk version. Love it quite a bit.

review: An excellent turn-based city building game that is nearly always fun, outside of standard maps such as Earth there is a random seed. Be warned though there are some issues with some of the cinematics that can lock up the game. Personally I have had issue with the space-race victory and need to skip the victory summaries or risk the game freezing, there may be some fixes just haven't spent the time to check. Also there is an excellent selection of mods for the game ranging from textures to maps and scenarios although they must be sought out on  other sites. Now if only there was Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri on Steam always wanted to play it atleast once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043023267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1604012203}
review:
Desde que compr√© Sid Meier's Civilization II en una tienda de segunda mano soy un fan de la saga Civilization y me he propuesto jugar todos los juegos de la saga poco a poco. Habiendo jugado a Civ II, Civ 1, Civilization Revolution y Alpha Centauri, decid√≠ adquirir el Civ III cuando sali√≥ de oferta en Steam. No me arrepiento de la compra, pero tengo claro que otros juegos de la saga me gustan m√°s. Para m√≠ (de mejor a peor de entre los que he jugado): Alpha Centauri>Civ II>>>Civ Revolution>Civ III>Civ. Tengo entendido que el Civ IV es muy bueno, y ser√° el pr√≥ximo que compre.

PUNTOS FUERTES:
-Gr√°ficos. Los gr√°ficos 2D han envejecido muy bien, y son mucho mejores que los del Civ II y Civ I.
-M√∫sica. Tiene la mejor m√∫sica de los juegos de la saga que he jugado. La m√∫sica del Civ II es muy b√°sica y se hace cansina, mientras que la del Civ III es m√°s elaborada y resulta mucho m√°s agradable.
-Fronteras. En Civ II es muy molesto cuando el enemigo construye sus ciudades en tu territorio. Esto fue corregido en Civ III con la adici√≥n de fronteras para delimitar los territorios controlados por cada civilizaci√≥n (aunque esto ya exist√≠a en Alpha Centauri).
-Diferenciaci√≥n de civilizaciones. En Civ II todas las civilizaciones ten√≠an las mismas caracter√≠sticas y se jugaban igual, pero en Civ III cada civilizaci√≥n tiene sus ventajas y desventajas (otra vez, Alpha Centauri lo hizo primero).
-Diplomacia mejorada. El trato con otras civilizaciones en juegos anteriores era muy b√°sico. En Civ III hay muchas m√°s opciones (derechos de paso, embargos, protecci√≥n mutua, ...). No obstante, los l√≠deres no parecen tener tener personalidad propia como ten√≠an en Alpha Centauri.
-Interfaz poco intrusiva. La interfaz ocupa poco espacio en la pantalla, tiene todas las acciones a mano y muestra toda la informaci√≥n necesaria. Es mejor que la de Civ II y, sobre todo, que la de Alpha Centauri.

PUNTOS D√âBILES:
-Combate. Al igual que en Civ 1, una unidad tecnol√≥gicamente atrasada puede vencer a una mucho m√°s avanzada (no es lo m√°s probable, pero a√∫n as√≠ ocurre bastantes veces durante una partida y resulta muy molesto). En ese sentido, Civ II era mucho mejor.
-Ritmo lento. El juego parece tener un ritmo m√°s lento que los juegos anteriores, aunque la cosa mejora mucho si se desactivan las animaciones.
-Mejoras del terreno. No hac√≠a falta tener tantas opciones como en Alpha Centauri, pero es que Civ III tiene menos mejoras del terreno disponibles que Civ II (donde despu√©s del regad√≠o se pod√≠an hacer granjas, adem√°s de tener las tecnolog√≠as "supermercado" y "autopistas" para mejorar la productividad). La consecuencia es que cuando la partida est√° muy avanzada, hay poco que hacer en el terreno con los trabajadores.

CONCLUSI√ìN:
Para jugar un Civilization en 2D, Civ II y (sobre todo) Alpha Centauri son mucho mejores opciones que Civ III. Si quieres un Civilization m√°s complejo que Civ II, quiz√° Civ IV sea mejor opci√≥n, salvo que Civ III est√© mucho m√°s barato.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025260266', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 8738, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3142, 'last_played': 1672257355}
review:
Recensione dell'installazione con Steam:
Il gioco presenta GRAVI PROBLEMI DI RISOLUZIONE, di malfunzionamenti e di crash improvvisi. Assolutamente urgente da sistemare. Problemi da Windows 10 in poi, problemi con schermi di risoluzione 2k o 4k.
RECENSIONE NEGATIVA PER QUESTO MOTIVO.

Recensione del gioco
Assolutamente il miglior civilization di Sid Meier. Nonostante la sua et√† rimane un pilastro della serie. Gli altri successivi hanno perso molto rispetto a questo, sia in dinamica che in funzionalit√†. 
Nonostante la sua miglior semplicit√†, rimane un gioco godibile e longevo. Sicuramente migliore di tutti gli altri civ successivi, che io tra l'altro posseggo ma che non mi hanno mai entusiasmato. La differenza pi√π marcata √® che nei civ successivi hanno ampliato tutti i men√π e le opzioni di scelta di ogni cosa (militare, economica, politica etc.) ma il tutto √® risultato un minestrone inutile. C'√® davvero bisogno di avere ulteriori effetti e opzioni  premendo dei pulsanti in pi√π per avere un'influenza politica sugli altri leader? Voglio dire, in civ 3 con la cultura puoi mostrare la tua magnificenza agli altri e quindi avrai rispetto, sugli altri civ successivi questa √® diventata invece un'operazione molto pi√π complessa dove richiede costantemente l'attenzione del giocatore per riuscire ad avere successo. Sommate poi tutte le altre cose che vanno sempre seguite in civ 5 e 6 in particolare, la finirete a non riuscire a ottenere granch√®. 

Critiche:
Per l'epoca ci sono pochissime critiche. 
Sarebbe bello se riesumassero questo gioco rendendolo moderno senza l'uso di dlc o altri pagamenti aggiuntivi.


Il gioco:
Il sistema si basa sulla fondazione di pi√π citt√† possibile sul continente per poi decidere, a seconda del popolo preso, se condurre una partita culturale, scientifica o militarista. 
Prima di avviare una partita, che vi consiglio di mettere tutte le impostazioni su casuale, assicuratevi di avere su "Limiti gioco" le regole che vanno bene per voi. Altro consiglio √® di mettere "Regicidio" attivo. 
La CPU √® molto audace e intelligente in guerra, assicuratevi di entrare in guerra solo se strettamente necessario e ponderate questa mossa molti turni prima. Manovrare un impero su Civ 3 pu√≤ essere un'operazione complessa che richiede molti turni. 
E' importante che controlliate tutto e che il vostro esercito sia ben equipaggiato e forte. Per quanto riguarda il sistema di combattimento ho notato che bisogna fare estrema attenzione a quali truppe far attaccare, perch√® rischierete spesso di perdere la guerra se sbagliate poche battaglie. 
Comunque, altri modi di vincere sono di costruire una fiorente civilt√† scientifica con appunto le trib√π votate alla scienza, inoltre il gioco da la possibilit√† di concentrare gli sforzi solo sulla scienza senza toccare gli edifici che danno felicit√† e cultura.
Ci sono poi i forti, utili per bloccare l'ingresso a eserciti indesiderati.
Questo e molto altro regalano le partite su Civ 3. Assolutamente il migliore, ma da capire.
A riguardo infatti potrete trovare in internet il manuale in italiano Civilization 3 Pi√π Civ che mai per imparare a fondo il gioco.

review: Gut, das Spiel ist jetzt schon ein bisschen in die Jahre gekommen, aber wer zum Beispiel ein PC der √§lter ist hat, hat bestimmt grosses Gefallen an diesem Meisterwerk der Spiele - Branche von Sid Meier. Ich habe schon in den 90'er Jahren Civilization gespielt und kann es nur jedem empfehlen. Dieses Spiel hat nicht die beste Grafik von heute und die neueren Versionen  (VI - 6 ist denk ich verf√ºgbar) sind bestimmt aber empfehlenswert f√ºr heutige Spieler mit modernem System und den n√∂tigen Ressourcen (CPU, Grafischer Durchsatz etc.). Da kann sich manch ein Entwickler von Computerspielen wirklich was abgucken, den Civilization (hier III) ist auf jeden Fall die Norm. Hoffe, meine Bewertung hat euch geholfen!

review: It's a lot different than the other Civilization games in the sense that it's not as easy to quickly take over every other nation in a quick genocide run. In Civ 3, you need to actually build up before you can even be SOMEWHAT ready to go to war. There wasn't as much effort on the soundtrack as there was in Civ 2, so you kinda unconsciously get annoyed at the game. Other than that, it's absolutely wonderful and addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198368099358', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1630382586}
review:
[h1] Sid Meier's Civilization III: Complete [/h1]

[b] A Mechanically Ancient Classic [/b]

[b] Sid Meier's Civilization III: Complete [/b] is not a welcoming addition to the Civilization franchise, certainly not with the way the franchise itself has evolved in more streamlined gameplay. All of the right pieces are there in order to make a compelling 4X strategy title, but the final product was too clunky, vague, and unintuitive for me to enjoy.

I normally do not knock older titles on presentation and visuals, but this title is a bit hard to look at. Not by any technical or graphical standard, but by a sheer lack of cohesion with the user interface. Menus feel bloated, clunky, and look drab. Character models and cities feel a bit washed out with the background environments, and the terrain itself has textures lower than you might expect. Granted this title came out twenty years ago, but it doesn't look very good nowadays.

However, my biggest issue with this game was its tutorial, or real lack of one. 4X strategy titles are generally complex in nature, and despite being an older title in the genre there are still loads of mechanics and details to become accustomed to. Yet [b] Civ III [/b] decides to essentially throw you into the world with a bloated rulebook to take alongside you. There is an unhealthy amount of trial and error in this title, and most actions have confusing and uneventful consequences (at least, visually). I found myself confused as to how to play a Civ game, and I've played [b] Civ IV [/b] and [b] Civ V [/b] before!

Music is decent and has a nice, bouncy beat to it, but the overall presentation and gameplay package was too much of a headache to process. I didn't spend much time with this one, and I do [b] Not Recommend [/b] you do either. This is a title that should be saved for older, more hardcore fans of the franchise that grew up with the game, but the newer titles do a much better job or translating Civ's classic gameplay loop to newer generations of gamers.

[h2] Final Verdict: 1/10 (Terrible) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37542043-ADHD-Reviews

review: it has amazing attention to detail, and has a beautiful picture. though be careful. make sure your graphics are set to the recommended level or you are going to be "laggin' like a dragon". Very slow and hard to do anything. so keep graphics low and you should do fine. the only other thing that erks me is when you load the game for the first time. It takes FOREVER to load. the game on the first time after installing it. Final note. remember this is a big game so don't get to angry if and when it slow (the first time). thank you and enjoy. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198027737668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1573645388}
review:
Game fails to run.

It fails to run SO spectacularly, in fact, that Steam can't even force it to end process. Nor can Steam tell when the process has been forcibly ended through Task Manager. In fact, Steam continues to think that the game is running after being closed and restarted, forcing the entire computer to be reset just to be able to uninstall this garbage.

Literally malware.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276592266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 41707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 38, 'playtime_at_review': 20031, 'last_played': 1710702835}
review:
I love playing civ type of games - specially with the OG Sid Meyer's Civ games.

For me the upgrade "Test of Time" was at the time a real thrill - it really leveled up the gameplay. Earlier on I even had put up a local network for to computers to play the Civ II Net with my spous.

Nowadays I play the game "Sid Meyer's Civilization III : Complete" at least once a week. In a word it's just a lot of fun - compared to other civ type of games.

Growing on, both my sons were impressed and intrigued seeing me play Civ games. 

Today we play co-op games online, thanks to Steam.

review: I love this game. I have played this since i was 5. I had the original CD but had lost the CD key so i could only play it on my old laptop. Then when i saw it on steam i bought it without thinking twice. I love the CIV series but this still remains to be my favorite.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130624838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 26629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12565, 'last_played': 1708327094}
review:
A fantastic gem of 4x strategy gaming! An underrated title that's more simple than the later iterations, yet still has that addicting "one-more-turn" aspect to it. I'm a little biased because I grew up with this one, I'll admit, but it's still my favorite to this day. Great selection of Civs for an older game, and there's a decent amount of ways to customize the map and settings to fine tune everything the way you want it, without being overwhelming to new players. If you get bored of the regular game, there's a variety of scenarios to play, all of them unique and interesting. There's also special maps and scenarios that were submitted by fans and included in the game, definitely worth a try. 

The biggest issue I have with this game is the AI. It's not very smart when it comes to trading, and it often blatantly tries to rip you off with one-sided deals, but it's quick to get upset if it thinks you're doing the same, not to mention the fact that it heavily favors trading with other AI players over the human. It also likes to move units through the human player's territory without permission, and on higher difficulty levels will not hesitate to declare war on you for simply asking them to move their troops out. Another thing that bothers me is that the AI does not get smarter on higher difficulties, they only start out with more settlers/workers/warriors etc., which forces the human player to pick Civs with very specific traits as they reach the hardest difficulties if they want a real chance at winning. 

Overall, I'd still highly recommend this game, despite the outdated AI. It's a great buy at such a low price, especially if you like the other Civs, or if you're a history buff (and if you're both, like I am, what are you waiting for?).

review:
I got this game originally on a disc back when it came out! I had played Civ II before and loved it. Civ III is even better, it's just so much fun exploring, building new cities and doing research. I'd recommend getting the Prima strategy book guide, it'll really help you whether you're into a peaceful path in the game or a more military path. It gives a list of the research paths to take for both.

"Just one more turn" has kept me playing... :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198328515568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5972, 'last_played': 1708959372}
review: This game has saved me 15/25/55 dollars, as I have no desire to purchase a newer civ game since playing this. I played for years as a kid on CD, so the 100 hours I have is more like 1000. The one knock on this game is that its very easy to snowball and very hard to come back from losing a war, even if you get out of it quickly, so unless you have the patience to build the units and take all the cities required for domination, the game sort of loses its fun at about 1700AD give or take. This game has provided me with hours upon hours of boredom prevention and excitement since I was about 7 years old and my uncle gave me and my brother this game on CD. Definitely recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198428468622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1592800855}

author: {'steamid': '76561197982225800', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 318, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1708884075}
review:
Like the other Civ games I've played, Civ III's mechanics are unique enough to differentiate it from the other games in the franchise, which makes it by no means "obsoleted" by its sequels. The interface and mechanics are also somewhat cryptic at first, but with a bit of time, it reveals itself to actually be rather simple. For the most part.

So on one hand, I think it's worth playing for its mechanical differences from other Civ games, but on the other hand, games like Civ IV, and especially Civ V, have made absolutely [i]huge[/i] interface and quality-of-life improvements (tooltips!) that just make them so much smoother to play and to discover their mechanics and learn how they work.

Since I've never played the Civ games growing up, my first experience with the franchise only started with Civ V a few years ago. So, no rose-tinted glasses here for me when I say that I think Civ III is still a good, rather addicting game, but the sequels just do so many things better and more intuitively.

Stick with Civ IV, V, or (gasp) even VI.

author: {'steamid': '76561198431926174', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1603989294}
review:
I used to own this game years ago, and the disc ended up scratched beyond repair from so many years of use, so I grabbed this title. Still the same game I remember, but with three changes:

1) The game locks up and crashes, likely due to it not being properly patched for Windows systems after XP.
2) There is no access to a level editor that I can find.
3) Cannot change anything about video.

I'd say get this game on Humble Bundle for cheaper, and enjoy it for what it's meant to be; a simpler game from a previous decade.

EDIT:
After repeatedly trying to finish a game, and failing every time, I've come to the conclusion this game simply cannot be played on Windows 10, as it stands. Maybe an emulator will allow other people to play the game without it breaking as soon as you threaten to get a science win, but nothing has worked for me.

After playing through twice on Monarch difficulty, I will never play this game again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015833539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 11686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4576, 'last_played': 1706472262}
review:
il gioco √® il classico CIV III
Se lo state cercando perch√© ci avete giocato in passato e volete rispolverare una vecchia perla √® ampiamente soddisfacente.
Presenta per√≤ alcune pecche fastidiose a mio avviso, il gioco essendo in 32 bit (si c'√® la compatibilit√† ma non permette di utilizzarla) tende a crashare se tentate di fare pi√π azioni contemporaneamente (esempio cliccare sui consiglieri mentre si svolgono le azioni automatiche dei  lavori e/o truppe).
A completamento partita anche li c'√® il rischio di crash del gioco per motivi apparentemente ignoti.
Non √® chiaro il perch√© quando ho acquistato questa versione dava la possibilit√† di pi√π lingue ( come nel cd all'epoca) invece evita nell'installazione la parte della scelta della lingua e di default si installa in inglese. 
A parte queste pecche il gioco funziona perfettamente ed √® divertente da giocare.

review:
Civilization es una de las sagas de estrategia que m√°s tiempo he jugado, junto a Age of Empires. 

Ya modifiqu√© el archivo conquests.ini y las propiedades de Civ3Conquests.exe para que funcione a pantalla completa en Windows 10/11 y desactiva la intro. El problema es al ganar una partida, se traba y hay que forzar el cierre.

La mejor forma de jugarlo sin problemas es usar una PC/laptop viejita o una m√°quina virtual con Windows XP.

review: I forgot how hard this gamer was.. Civ 5 has spoiled me.. I used to be so good at this too.. eitherway.. i love a challenge and the game still delivers that 10-15 unit stack fun I looked for. if you like the newer civ games and want to test the tougher older ones.. this one will get your head going.. AGGRESSIVE AI O_O

author: {'steamid': '76561198073729843', 'num_games_owned': 138, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 1907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1708459407}
review:
"Mummy, please, just one more turn..."

STRICT ALERT!!! The game is going to cause dependency/addiction to it.

Only play if you have many hours to spend on it - don't even start if you have less than two hours of free time!

Shame it still lacks HD resolution support, just like it doesn't have actually ANY graphics settings - although when it got released in 2001 it didn't look bad compared to its age being an isometric 2D-game. Still, some lags/AI thinking times might occur, which I cannot say agreeable looking at its graphics level...

I think this entire game should get an HD remaster - newer than Windows XP operating systems can have serious compatibility support issues with the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036536255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1214, 'last_played': 1528382694}
review:
This is still my favorite Civ game because of its simple, to-the-point, yet quite appealing art design.

You don't get any flashy animations or stylish ui choices that ultimately just hinder you from enjoying it to its fullest.

It is the perfect game for an after-work cooldown session and remains as addicting as ever.

Oh and it scales to modern resolutions quite well too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169055269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 1590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 729, 'last_played': 1667448457}
review:
Don't get if you hate strategy.  How you got here if you have to listen that advise I have no idea.

So much time wasted on this game in my youth.  But this is the accumulation of civ games from the first generation, and I have heard they had to reset the franchise cause of this game.  But it is a classic 4X, if you don't have it get it.  It is 5 bucks for the base game and all the expansions, yes I said expansions, not that dlc crap that replaced expansions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032914146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2963, 'last_played': 1663942857}
review: One of my favorite games of all time. I spent countless hours playing Civ3 back in the day (and have a few in the Steam version). I highly recommend it to anyone who likes strategy games and hasn't played it yet. Also, the game originally came out in 2001, so by today's standards, even an old PC should be able to easily handle it (unless you're somehow still running with a PC that predates Windows 2000/XP, I guess).

author: {'steamid': '76561198017420220', 'num_games_owned': 480, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 4105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3814, 'last_played': 1639585277}
review:
Don't be fooled by the number above, I have more than 3k hours played at least. On the the review now:

I've been playing on and off since it's release. I've learned a lot of history and English terminology through playing this game as a kid. The game play is not the best: the next games are superior game play wise. However they eliminated the endless combat that reigns over Civ 3. It is one of these games, uniquely so, that you can hoard military units, stack them up near the enemy's borders, declare war and take 5 cities, big or small, before the enemy gets his turn. Although a lot, A LOT, of micromanagement is required to pull off this kind of tactic, it is really rewarding if somewhat tedious. The technology system is fine, it's slower than later games, but you have more time to play between eras. Most unique units are well-designed. A lot of Wonders are broken (Statue of Zeus, cough cough) and can allow you to cut through early eras like a knife through butter. Early eliminations are common and wonder fights are exciting. 

The OST is BONKERS. I still listen to it, so many years later, even without playing. Jungle sounds, mesoamerican music etc. Really well orchestrated.

Overall, I've been enjoying this game for so many years. It's my childhood darling so I may be a bit far from objectively measuring its pros and cons.

review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III is all about land grabbing, scientific and military expansion, and patience. You start with a single settler and are expected to carve out a civilization that is capable of withstanding the trials of time while competing with domineering neighbors for the possession of Wonders and military might. 

I am enjoying Sid Meier's Civilization III very much. I recommend it to all strategy game lovers due to the depth of the world and the complexity of game itself.

review: Can't get enough of this game since 2001. It was so huge with long global scale maps that were played for days. It has some concepts implemented (like corruption) that were since lost in subsequent installments of Civ series. It supports resolutions up to 2560x1440 and works perfectly fine on modern machines. If you want some thoughtfull, meditative, old school strategy experience go grab it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979881961', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 46656, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 71, 'playtime_at_review': 20842, 'last_played': 1710666756}
review:
First of all i play this game since it came to market. It's a great game and makes still fun to play. I prefer it to the newer versions of civilization. 

The graphics are still good even after so many years and it is very balanced. It has no 3d graphics and that's what i like about the game. It gives me a better overview and in my opion 3d is not needed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990562257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1558895179}
review: Each time I started the game to check on some detail, six hours mysteriously vanished. Perfectly captures the epic sweep of the previous games but adds a bunch of new features that improve upon an already brilliant concept. It's superior in every way to "Civilization II". The interface is much better implemented this time around...To make a long story short, Civ. III is a worthy heir for the franchise and a definite must have for any strategy gamer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198200925711', 'num_games_owned': 605, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1563165847}
review: The UI is difficult to understand (especially unit amounts/strength/health), and the internet will be of no use to you in terms of tutorials, but otherwise it seems like and okay game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198421223046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 25907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7037, 'last_played': 1590090419}
review: old school

author: {'steamid': '76561198044472061', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 21377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15734, 'last_played': 1679483186}
review: Incredibly biased opinion since this is based on nostalgia (still have played a lot even now) but I love this game to death. Later civs really try hard to develop things like diplomacy, religion, social policies etc. but I'm out for global domination which is very possible in this game unlike later ones where they make it much more difficult and I'd say they actively discourage it. The later ones feel almost like accounting games with all the things you have to consider but this one is simple enough and straightforward. Old game but always a blast to make stacks of death and mow down every civilization you find. When on sale you can get it for about a dollar. I'll take being able to play this over a mcchicken any day.

I heard good things about this game.

review:

Personalmente recomiendo Civ 4 a cualquiera que no haya jugado esta saga, sigue la misma f√≥rmula que el 3 pero las mec√°nicas se sienten m√°s pulidas

author: {'steamid': '76561198112173506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1556134727}
review:
I played this for untold hours off my CD, likely from the base, or close to the base version (note, 
 I bought this as a backup copy, what does that tell you?).  I couldn't recommend it enough back in the day, but it's a bit older, and thus the graphics aren't as high.  The later editions added things like vassal states, which you can turn off, but I never liked, and I like to play with all rules on.  This older version has all the main features, and later editions try more and more to make complete conquest of the map harder and harder so players don't get frustrated by being knocked out in multiplayer, but it takes away from the global domination that most old players aim for.  So, in that case, older is better!

****NOTE:on Windows 10, always hit space bar when it starts up to skip the login screen, or an error will make it crash when the "2K" animation ends.  This is a super old game.

review: Marred by a buggy release in 2001, a couple of expansions really helped flesh it out. Although I'd probably consider it the worst Civ game, it's still really good. There are some crashes, but games from this era often have issues on modern machines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070286216', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 13758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10745, 'last_played': 1706495514}
review: The only Civ that I ever truly enjoyed. Played it on and off for 10 years, enjoyed every minute of it. Some game mechanics are old/silly but are still enjoyable. And for the price of 5 dollars, you will get hundreds of hours of entertainment, if you are willing to learn the dated mechanics of course.

review:
Ich habe Sid Meiers Civilization III damals in einer schicken Kisten verpackung mit CD zum Geburtstag von meinen Eltern bekommen.
Daher hatte ich aus Nostalgischen gr√ºnden sofort zugeschlagen als ich gesehen hatte das es sogar eine Expansion daf√ºr gab.

Leider ist das ganze Game auf English, was dem Nostalgie Faktor etwas hemmt. 
Au√üerdem ist mir aufgefallen das man keine Felder um die Nahrung aufzubauen bauen kann, in der deutschen Version auf CD die ich hatte konnte man dies schon recht fr√ºh machen.
Nur ich h√§nge da spiele Rom und kann das nicht? 

Ich kann nur Stra√üen und Mienen bauen, ist das vlt. ein Bug?
Zumindest ein Bug der weitreichende Konsequenzen mit sich bringt und daher dieses Spiel leicht zerst√∂rt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009250344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 908, 'last_played': 1551119372}
review: Coming from Civ V as my first Civ game - well, technically it was Civ Revolution but let's pretend that didn't happen -, I found this game enjoyable. In my limited experience so far though, there seems to be less things to do, however the present mechanics are on a larger scale. For example, there are no social policies but a few government types, religion only in the form of a few religious buildings I guess but nothing customizable and so on. Though on the other hand, you build far more cities and mass produce units, often the same things over and over. It's the same things with workers, for the most part you build roads and either irrigation or mines on the tiles. Overall, the core experience looks like it's the enjoyable same, but a simpler zen-like experience. I could also run the game on both Windows 7 and Windows 10 both x64 just fine, resolution is also ok.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116137351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 1053, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1556896204}
review:
I'll keep this short and simple - you shouldn't get this game for really really playing it. A nostalgic kick, sure, but as a Civ-series game, nah.

This game is pretty much a downgraded version from Civ V, which is in my opinion the best game of the series. Worse graphics, worse AI, worse everything really. Which is to be expected, of course, since this is the 3rd installment, V logically being the fifth. 

All in all, looking to play Civ? Get the fifth one. This game's a 3/10, Civ V is a 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156193725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2408, 'last_played': 1701014774}
review:
My first and favourite of all CIV games, CIV 3 is a lovely experience. It has some fairly annoying combat mechanics (tanks sometimes losing to barbarians, etc) but its simple and effective interface is a stark contrast to the later installments of the CIV series.

Despite its occasional flaws, Civilization 3 remains my favourite product of the entire series. I fully recommend it to anyone who might be interested!

review:
This review is in English and Slovak language:
T√°to recenzia je v Anglickom a Slovenskom jazyku:

I have been playing the mother of all strategies continuously since 1993 and gradually I went through all her titles and subtitles to V. part. Civilization III. became my longest playing heart affair and I was very reluctant to say goodbye to it as I slowly moved on to the V. part. Personally, I think that III. the part is far better than IV., V. and probably VI., but it is a bit outdated and does not offer such a range of gameplay options. What makes it unique, however, is that this is the last Cvilization where you have the opportunity to create truly gigantic empires with countless armies on large maps.

review:
Bueno, no es un Age of Empires o algo parecido, eso es claro, pero no por eso es malo, es el primer Sid Meier¬¥s Civilization que juego y es, dificil adaptarse, ya que no habia jugado un juego asi, al ser en el idioma ingles y yo poseer solo los conocimientos necesarios para saber de que iba la cosa, fue practicamente cosa de intuicion, por no poseer un tutorial y ser algo complejo al principio, pero al agarrarle la onda se hace muy agradable.
P.D. No subestimen los caminos

review: I have chosen to write another review for this game after another playthrough and choosing a new style to play. I think this game is a classic in every way its just something about those plastic looking faces and the pixelated graphics that makes me feel happy that many still play it theres so much to do in this game and it adds so much to the politcal and espionage aspects of the game that lets you be any kinds of leader you want from a backstabbing snake to a kind peace loving sage. even a war mongering tyrant to a soviet opressor.

review:
Tips:
Add the following lines to the ini file in the Conquests folder to play in your native monitor resolution and to skip the intro on startup:
KeepRes=1
PlayIntro=0

With KeepRes=1 the menu will appear small with black borders but once you start a game the map will use all available screen space.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076378579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 293, 'playtime_forever': 154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 154, 'last_played': 1545877625}
review: I have played every Civ from the first. They all progress in many ways, while regressing in others. I have to say after replaying Civ III after having played CIV V, this confirms it. Terrain looks so bland, there is no popup that estimates the percent of success in a battle, the UI is clunkier, etc. But for the price of a good cup of coffee, I will not complain. I love all the CIV games (so far 1 to 5). I would hate to know how many thousands of hours I spent on them, certainly enough to be fluent in Russian or some other difficult foreign language. 6/10.

it was a nice insight into my first CIv game though to me its just unplayable and broken, like Its certianly peaked my intrest, but I cant play it due to issues with the UI, which to me is confusing and somewhat broken (trying to click on options it just ends up in a contuious cycle of Yes or no)

author: {'steamid': '76561198005282571', 'num_games_owned': 571, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 4578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2836, 'last_played': 1554380053}
review:
civ3 creates an impression that is it much more designed for robots than humans

it seems as well AI acts with perfect knowledge of map (which is nearly the only strong way to heavily cheat on this without some quadruple bonuses to everything, however all those are a thing on top difficulty i bet; and in those old civs you pretty sure are not winning in this absurd case)

it seems AI doesn't really try to unite against you in case of lead (though maybe does get furious at riches), yet is overly happy to try silly backstabs / 'surprise attacks' or else; it may even try to assault clearly later era stronghold with simple hordes that would almost never win there

oh and there's the quite massive downside in old civ - combat is literally random, so much that it matters almost endlessly, since there are massive terrain bonuses as well and ancient spearmen could very well beat tanks; it's not even a weird and rare case - hopelessly outdated AI hordes may just jump onto your mountains anytime and become unmovable force

there is a lot of inconvenience with units such as limits to upgrading, mostly no true way to skip tons of unit movements and such (maybe in case of railroads it becomes sort of that), while there are tons of units and often clumsy or limited control over them - and then 'same continent' is breaking minds of automated workers, there was a case where they literally rushed through many foreign borders and large lands that are hostile - to sometimes work on nearly or actually foreign volcano that recently exploded - and then instantly all die to yet another explosion, while they stand right on top of volcano

AIs for some reason barely ever wish to cooperate anyhow equally, even if it's them who often try to ally their weak nation to much more advanced one - even if it's exactly they who backstabbed you and awfully need protection now - of course it's you who always should pay army's worth of upkeep in protection treaty; then there's both positive and strange moment - bots can be (furious) at you yet still seriously try to ally and get protection

civ3 is somehow quite confusing and unintuitive i suppose, even when simultaneously tools available + core mechanics are ridiculously simple (but even pacing is very strange); it also seems to take massive time to playthrough even a bit - and without much management i guess (spammy) AI and all those older type mechanics can result in a quick death of civilization

it did have some nice ideas but the rest can simply create rather stupid spammy - defensive-favoring (and as well ruining that for YOU the player, because you lack any extra automation possible) grind, starting even from most ancient times where first of all units can be massed and rushed by population that generally anyone has and some do in massive surplus

overall civ3 has either too serious or too numerous problems to be offset by a few good moments; i'd say in practice it is easily nearly unplayable, inconvenient and quite mindless - while serious business going on against you won't let you be mindless one (or there you could lose on the easiest setting possible); it is possibly not even really challenging since maps feature very inhospitable lands (full of mountains not to even settle or ever grow anything) while as well rich and useful plains

so from the start it seems about all factors are against you; that's somewhat interesting but not for long (and that's a bit too much patience still)

since it is often not even easy to survive - some a bit casual or even a much later civ5 player will likely be plainly outspammed by ruthless AI if they miss about anything in proper setup and management (and when unfamiliar, there must be a lot to miss)

author: {'steamid': '76561198206886068', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1553362874}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III is the de-facto greatest game in terms of basic graphics and gameplay-wise, especially in the entire Sid Meier's Civilization series. It brung more things the other two didn't implement, such as animated leaders, advisors, and updated isometric view, and brand new land graphics simulating the real world, and even coastlines.

This version, however, is the greatest buy I have ever accomplished. You got editors, and other civilizations bundled with this! It has all three expansions, and adds a functioning multiplayer! I love this game and it even competes with my love for Civilization IV. I just love it, and you guys should get it at any opportunity, such as sales and special events.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972538083', 'num_games_owned': 970, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 28240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17821, 'last_played': 1705193424}
review:
This game is a good starting point for newcomers to the Civilization series and currently the best value for money. It is fully compatible with modern systems and still worth playing today. The visual aesthetic of the game is one of its best features, and I still consider III to be the best looking Civilization game, due to its appealing artstyle and readability.

Civ III lacks some of the sophisticated gameplay mechanics introduced in the later games and I consider the combat in particular to be a weaker point of this game, as it usually amounts to just mindlessly building more units than your opponents. Despite this, Civ III gets the job done simply and effectively, which is why I always come back to it over the other games in the series. The Conquests scenarios are an interesting addition to the game and I have replayed them countless times. There are also numerous custom scenarios and mods available. If you have an interest in history and like strategy games, I would fully recommend Civilization III.

review: I grew up playing Civilization II but never tried any of the subsequent games. When I saw Civ 3 on sale I decided to give it a go, a decision I would happily make again. An interesting and fun game that has areas of complexity mixed in with simplicity, I easily lose track of time playing this game and would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys strategy games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198309847540', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1524984514}
review:
[h1][b]The Good[/b][/h1]
The delightful simplicity even with the complex nature of the game. The Civilipedia is very insightful, and helps you a lot when playing the game. Graphics is good (although not excellent) and music is catchy. The way that it makes me THINK like no other game EVER managed to do is remarkable!

[h1][b]The Bad[/b][/h1]
Slowness of AI turns during the latter stages of the game was a bit bad, but not bad enough to prevent me from becoming a total addict.

[h1][b]The Bottom Line[/b][/h1]
All I can say is that if you don't know about this game yet, you're missing out on the most important of all computer games EVER.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037469371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1077, 'last_played': 1542510232}
review: I absolutely hate this game. I've played Call to Power 1 and 2, Sid Meier's Civ 5, 6, and this. I see all these reviews about how this is still the best Civ game, and I just do not see what they're seeing. In Civ 5 and 6, the enemy AI will at least kill and absorb far weaker AI. They will at least every once in awhile do little pretend wars where they attack another equal AI's city (not take it, but just damage it ). The enemy AI in this game will always be permanently allied against you, even if you pick for them to be the least aggressive they can be (useless option). The combat is the most frustrating, rng-based, tedious, time-consuming, micro-managing ****fest I've ever seen. You can have many units occupy a tile, but they can only attack 1 at a time. You would think that means combat would at least be better than Civ 5 and 6, but like I said, the rng is so stupid that you have to make sure you have an advantage of 5x or more, unless you want to just load half the time and try the battle again, cuz you will fail half the time at a 2x advantage. And what I mean by that is this - You can have a unit with twice as much attack as they have defense, they can be wounded, sitting in a grassland/plain, not fortified, not across a river, and there's still a good chance you will lose if you attack him. In addition to that, you can NOT fully kill an enemy by bombarding. This means that you have to rely on rng attacking to actually kill any enemy military unit. Call to Power 2 sucks because you can't set up a scenario where the AI put up any threat (they won't attack you with anything more than a few units ever), and this game sucks for the opposite reason, because the AI only wants you dead and they have huge advantages even on low difficulties. It especially doesn't help that the maps spawn such few horses and iron (even though you NEED them to get anything past starting units in this game), seems to always put them near the AI and far away from you, and punishes you greatly if you build a town far away from your own (through waste/corruption penalties), in which, you would need to connect that town with a road in order to build those horse/iron units in your other towns. If you don't connect that town to your civilization, then like I said, the waste/corruption is so bad that you won't get to build ANYTHING in that town. The enemy AI also destroys your lonely roads in no time. I'm uninstalling this game and never considering it again. BLIZZARD, PLEASE PUT CALL TO POWER 1 UP FOR DIGITAL DOWNLOAD, SO I CAN ACTUALLY HAVE FUN AGAINST AI AGAIN!

author: {'steamid': '76561198047290897', 'num_games_owned': 1042, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1623288840}
review:
I learned more about history playing this game and reading the in-game encylopedia than I ever would have from history classes. The game is fun enough for me to put many many hours into it (this is my third copy, having lost 2 physical discs) and then looking up why the game works the way it does (and why each Civ acts the way it does) can easily be compared to Schoolhouse Rock (only aimed at older audiences)

THIS is edutainment done right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214367808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1542058153}
review: So, yeah, the graphics aren't what we're used to now, but this is still a great game.  Far and away better than the one that comes next, Civ IV.  FAR better.  Enjoyable, not easy to win -- I lost my first two games...mostly because there's no tutorial that I could find and the buttons are not exactly intuitive.  Heck, the game I won I didn't do all that well on.  Still, fun.  It's certainly not 5, but it's a nice change if you like old-school games.  Well worth the incredible low price.  Plays like a champ for me, no glitches at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198811091243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1330, 'last_played': 1705444165}
review:
This is The Best version of "Civilization" in series. The new "comic look" they started in Civ4 gives me eye cancer. So lame look since Civ4, which probably appeals only to 4-8 year kids. This is why I stick with The Perfect Civ3.

P.S.

Runs perfectly on Linux (Ubuntu 16.04 with 2560 x 1440 resolution monitor).

P.P.S.

To run in Linux:

a)
On a steam client go to "Steam > Settings > Steam Play" and check option "Enable Steam Play for all titles".

b)
Run a game first time - it probably won't start if You have large resolution monitor like me, but thats alright - the first run will create a conquests.ini (~/.steam/steam/steamapps/common/Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete/Conquests/conquests.ini) file.

Put these lines in that file:

KeepRes=1
PlayIntro=0

Save changes and play now till you drop dead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035332846', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 15508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2145, 'last_played': 1685241636}
review:
So I first started this game in the third grade, I distinctively remember one day I woke up early Saturday morning  the sun was rising and I started playing, what seemed like a moment later I looked up and night was upon me. This is one of my all time favorite game series and in my opinion the best for those who prefer playing wide as well as fighting wars. The AI will frequently cover the map in cities and if you're not quick to the punch you will be struggling trying to capture the iron you need to survive the game without cowering in fear of your enemies at every threat. I love the brutality and cuthroat play of the AI in this game and to top that off there are little things added to this game that can change your gameplay in little ways. For instance global warming, technology trading, volcanic eruptions, disease and my personal favorite cultural conversion. While the late games have made many changes they also stepped back in many areas in content from what this series use to have. To top this off this game processes turns for me far faster than the later games. (Did I mention the scenarios also kick ass?)

All in all you have to play it and fail at it for a few games before you're going to find your playstyle, to me this game is a masterpiece. It won't be for everyone but if you're a warmonger such as myself this game will sate your bloodlust and then some. 

P.S. The soundtrack is amazing and evolves with you.

review: I still think this is the best Civ. It has the largest scale and even lets you automate certain things. They should release a remastered version that lets the engine use more resources to get rid of the end game lag and improve some of the UI elements. Honestly Civ VII should be based on this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010090927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1449072632}
review: While the graphics are very dated now, this is still one of the key games on the timeline of global conquest games.  It is well worth a play as it highlights why systematic brilliance can easily replace modern flashy graphics.

review: I used to play this game a lot with my friends and a bit of singleplayer play. review: This is the video game that started it all for me, back maybe around 2005. Every video game after that (and especially turn-based RTS) I thought was just a knock-off of this game. Truly fantastic in every way. It has not aged as well as its following games such as Civ IV, but is nonetheless a classic. A must-have in all Steam libraries.
