author: {'steamid': '76561198060482338', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 66454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 224, 'playtime_at_review': 4955, 'last_played': 1710782410}
review:
Classic strategy in randomly generated maps against various factions from the earliest days of mankind to the modern era.

The good:
- Strategy
- Music
- Gameplay mechanics such as: diplomacy, resources, luxuries, war, trade, exploration, technology advancement, and more.

The bad:
- (opinion) Complete edition introduced some unnecessary changes to the game. Default edition was better
- Late game units are arguably unbalanced

review: Unit stats don't seem to matter at all: just lost 20 crusaders (def 3) to 20 attacking numibian warriors (attack 2). Similar experiences in the past as well. In other aspects it's a great game but unit stats are in a critical role so it's ruining it for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198292701601', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 35025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3463, 'last_played': 1707498262}
review:
This game is actually pretty good and a nice way to pass the time, but I don't understand why you can't have infinite turns to have that alternate earth timeline atmosphere that it takes place in your own version of Earth where your Civilisation can further go through its ups and downs with no sight of any kind of game victory in any horizon, but instead the best we can get is 1000 turns, which in my opinion is pretty displeasing since I was able to get a cultural victory with 1000 turns in just one go, on a small island surrounded by sea, in a very large map. I don't know if you CAN continue to run your civilization after a victory, because the 2 times I did get an endgame and went to click "OK", my game immediately freezes and stops working, making me have to quit the game.
Overall, it's a very fun game for you to pass the time, but it's going to be a quite the downer if you want to fully invest in your civilization for as long as you want (which would usually be "forever and ever" in some cases).
Overall, this game is a 8.5/10 in my opinion.

*Edit: I found out about the infinite turns, I was just stupid

review:
Eh beh, il mio primo Civilization, come si fa a non amarlo. Questo √® uno dei migliori Civ della storia ed uno dei migliori RTS a turni e 4X della storia. Questo gioco regala ancora emozioni e in alcune cose √® molto piu in avanti rispetto al V o al VI (ad esempio con il passare degli anni il vostro capo diventera piu vecchio sul III, oppure il fatto di poter vedere la vostra citt√† dopo che avrete costruito determinati edifici sul III si pu√≤ fare, sui nuovi no, insomma dei dettagli che fanno la differenza).

author: {'steamid': '76561198061164965', 'num_games_owned': 1278, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 5601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4936, 'last_played': 1708615246}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III is a turn-based strategy game on where you can play as one of many nations/countries and play on various maps which would be the "Earth" for that map. This complete edition concludes of the base game, Civilization III, Civilization III Play the World & Civilization III Conquest. We have many scenarios in this game with examples of them being Rise of Rome, World War 2 Pacific and even Earth type maps which you can either have true starting locations as your desired nation or have the spawn randomized. 

PROS
- CIv 3 has the biggest maps out of any other Civ game.
- We have no limitations on units like we had on every sequel. Units can stack which gave a much more war feeling to the game.
- If you want a game to last at least a week or even a month. On this game you can make it happen.
- For an old game it still runs smoothly.
- Multiplayer still works, so you can play with friends and/or family.
- Gameplay is simple, but you can make mistakes easily and the enemy will take advantage of that 

CONS
- Dated graphics (can be a + or a -)

Overall
This is and always will be my favourite civ 3 game, the sequels are all about fancy graphics and less war. If you want to actually feel like you have a civilization then this is the game for you. If you want the ultimate experience, on an earth map and the biggest map you can dream of. Then pick this map. TETurkhan Test of Time. This comes with various game types that include of spawning with pre-made cities like earth is today with the available civilizations in the game, true location start which allows you to where your country's first capital was. Or have it randomized. So you could have England in India or the Japanese in Africa. This is the biggest map the game has to offer and with the size of it. You are talking at least a couple of weeks to finish, if you plan to go with a total domination game. Well I'ma say it'll take you a little over a month.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032877737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 239141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2369, 'playtime_at_review': 32825, 'last_played': 1710488344}
review:
Long story short: I bought Civilization 6, it bored me, I went back to previous versions till I found the Civ III CD. I forgot I had it, I forgot I used to play the game, the CD didn't install on Win 10, I went back to Steam and invested $1.49 on a download version... WOW I remember this game... that dick Alexander! The Cavalry, the awesome advisors, the incredible balance of resourses that keeps them relevant and even vital throughout the game. The expansion of territory and number of cities that increases your gold and power and access to more resources and luxuries instead then weight down your empire sustainability.  Best Civilization Ever!!!!

And if you are in for a change of pace... play Elimination.... build a small empire on a huge scale world and wait (with 6 or 7 offensive units) for the AI players to spam their cities near you and raze the newest most undefended one, rinse and repeat.
It never gets old.  :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197966944858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 174612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64594, 'last_played': 1703554229}
review: I've been coming back to this game year after year.  Civ IV, V, and VI have tended to streamline play and take on a more multiplayer-oriented mindset, which is great if that's what you want; but I keep coming back for Civ 3 for its month-long games, detail, and versatility.  I'll concede the vanilla game isn't the best (though the built-in scenarios are fun), but over the years I've edited the default scenario to a point that fits my playstyle: more resources types, greater differentiation in terrain, more divergent unit types, more engaging naval forces, and a modern era that holds a bit more interest.

review:
Loved this many years ago & it is still an excellent strategy game in 2018

Info: Windows 10 users will need to do a few tweaks to make this run correct & look as it should on a modern HD monitor, first find the configuration file conquests.ini, open with notepad, scroll to the bottom & add the line "keepRes=1" to run the game at your display resolution, next find the file civ3conquests.exe, right click & in properties select to run both as administrator and in windows XP SP3 compatibility to fix a bug where the game freezes at the end of a game.

You're welcome & enjoy this classic ^_^

author: {'steamid': '76561198153016478', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1531207739}
review: I spent a great part of my childhood playing it along with Age of Empires, and today I'm happy to say that I have no regrets about it. Even though this isn't the kind of game that tracks my attention anymore, I still have fun playing it after so much time. Civilization is a legendary series of games and anyone who likes Strategy in Turns should try it at least once. If you are a Total War fan like me, don't be afraid to give it a shot. It might not have the RTS battles, but it is compensated by the extremely well produced variety of strategies in game, and it's always fun to interact with legendary leaders or seeing Gandhi starting a World's Domination plan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033818893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 8651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7371, 'last_played': 1673204122}
review:
It is really hard to choose a Civ game, as all of them are pretty darn good. But it is safe to say that Civ 3 is the best among the 2D entries, being the most streamlined one, gameplay-wise. It changes some things from its predecessor, eliminating unneeded units and techs, among other things. The game offers amazing replay value, and is certainly on par with the series' fame. Graphics are ok, as is the music.

This Steam version is good and working on Windows 11 (I tested myself). I recommend it to everybody, but specially those with an older PC, as it can run on almost anything.

review: The people that rate this game poorly because of the tank/spearman issue likely do not know how to play the game. The game does not determine battle outcomes by icon, it uses a number system. So in the case where a spearman is attacked by a tank: Spearman (in city, fortified, on a hill, across a river, etc. etc.) will be pumped up quite drastically and make it feasible to beat a tank. Awesome game, endless fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032096578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 77, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1533583288}
review:
I played CIV2 a lot many, many moons ago when it first came out. One of the features I miss from CIV2 was the debug menu where you could add and remove pretty much anything - city mprovements, tech, etc. I used to enjoy building up a civ in CIV2 then using that debug menu to strip everything away again back to stone age levels to prolong the game and really for laughs. CIV3 doesn't have that feature. It's still a good game but, I find that missing that feature results in a lot less horsing around. 

CIV2 game play time - probably ~1000 hours over the yerars. I don't expect to get to that level with CIV3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198267000910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1073, 'last_played': 1528683209}
review:
[h1]La mejor franquicia en juegos de estrategia[/h1]
Muy adictivo y con una complejidad que puede agradar a los que buscan retos. Aun en la dificultad mas baja te costara al menos un par de partidas poder conseguir una victoria.
Corre en PC con especificaciones muy basicas al 100, Igualmente funciona perfectamente con un equipo con windows 10, perfecto si cuentas con un computador muy basico o de mas de 10 a√±os de antiguedad, podras tener un gran juego de estrategia, muy ligero en peso y con miles de horas de juego, ademas de su bajo coste.
Todo un clasico.

review: Very good game. If you don't care about graphics then this is definitely the Civ to get, not to mention the price point. It can get slightly repetitive, however it is not a game to pay all the time. Instead it is a game that, once you've got over the honeymoon period, you play once a week for a few hours. Lots of options to change difficulty, size of map and number of opponents. Don't buy if you expecting a multiplay experince as it doesn't exist anymore.

review: Civ III may be old but it's still gold, It's quite different to civ v but there's good stuff. author: {'steamid': '76561198018450069', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 587, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1558722951}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III, and all the remain franchise games, are all that a turn-based strategy game should be. For me, as a fan, they are a reference to the genre.

I played a lot more than Steam registered because I played before Steam, a physical copy that I bought in 2001 when the game was released. Old ages, physical copies, games in CD, no one remember them...

But now, in 2018 I replayed it, and without noticing the passing time I almost played 10 hours in a row. I still loved it. 

Of course the CiV V is for me the pinnacle of the franchise, but for the 2001 game, it is still better them some other games of the genre. I get a few resolution issues but nothing serious for a game of this age, totally understandable.

Fully recommend it, it's a classic for a bargain price, a "must have" to any Steam collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037427689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 2710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2710, 'last_played': 1527303547}
review:
I wish there was an easy way to review a game that plays the "but it's old so it's okay!" card so much. This game isn't terrible but it's not great. The biggest issue is with the combat(which I'll put at the end of this review) but only because it makes other parts of the game horrible, such as the monotony of the game.

This game has no discernible story. There are fixed campaign maps(e.g. Mesopotamia) but for the most part I only did random quickplay games.

The music irritated me right away but that may just be me. In these types of games, I just tend to turn off the music and put on a podcast or music in the background and then just play. The sound effects are very annoying and this is one of those games that has an irregularly loud volume compared to literally every other fucking game ever. It's like comparing a fog horn to a bicycle horn.

Graphics are standard for its time. Not much to say there at all. I suppose the palace and the city view are neat.

So, the gameplay is kinda fucked. I'll give you the basics. You start out with a civilization(each has its own individual bonus, traits, and starting technology), a single settler, and a worker. You build a city, you use your worker to build roads, mines, and irrigation. You then wait turn after turn for your city to build something because this game is 100% turnbased. You have two turn-based aspects of a city. Improvement/unit(referred to as "product" from here on) production, and population production. Population requires food, product requires shields aka materials. See, the immediate issue some people might think of is "Surely, as is obviously the case with all turn-based games, it takes a lot of micromanaging and waiting to get anywhere in this game!" First off, my name's not Shirley(ha. ha.) Secondly, you're not wrong. The city-building part of this game is monotonous and you'll most likely spend a huge amount of time in larger-scale games micromanaging city happiness, food, shields, and money and science funding. It wouldn't be such a big issue if you didn't have to deal with other problems in the game that cripples your own personal growth.

There's science research but it becomes annoying quickly. Unless you fund science almost entirely, then you'll fall behind. AFAIK AI focuses science funding 100% indefinitely.

I played on the easiest difficulty myself to figure out mechanics and get the most out of the game(aka not lose in 5 minutes and see 5% of the game). One of the bigget issues with the AI is how stubborn it is. Examples: Constantly starting war regardless of how many units it has and because of stupid reasons. e.g.: 

-if a nation refuses to leave your borders, almost always unless you're significantly stronger, they'll just declare war. Funny enough, if you enter their borders they immedietally ask you to leave as if you have no right. Privilege these days, sheesh!
-Constantly trading and requesting gold or demanding stuff in trades but never accepting the trade if you do the same, regardless of your military strength, or otherwise, in the game. This results in many wars if you refuse and it just wastes time.
-AI spamming units and, from what I understand, regularly resulting in 0 gold in their treasury, but unit spam continues. This becomes an issue when the AI will just run past guarded cities with horsemen only to specifically target undefended cities. The reason why this is an issue is both the unit spam the AI does(which results in cities empty of improvements when capturing AI cities, because they spend no time building improvements) and the fact that it's not really preventable. You can have units surrounding a cavalry(3 movement points mid-game) and it can straight up go around them to either attack a city to then capture it, or just capture an undefended city despite units being present around it. Maybe you took units out to fight this cavalry and due to the shitty combat you lost so now it's undefended. Well, too bad jackass!
-A recent issue I found out that has to do with 'local seeds' in the game. It's an option you can turn off, and I suggest you do so as it can result in a problem where combat results are the same regardless of how many time you load a saved game. Basically, combat results become fixed every new turn.
-AI constantly teaming up on the player but, from what I've experienced, never going to war with eachother.

I don't exaggerate on the stubborness either. The AI has NEVER accepted a fair deal with me that wasn't a peace treaty. This is an issue because if you don't trade with nations, they start to hate you. In dickplomacy, I've never ONCE been able to get anywhere past a peace treaty in the game, but I would always see enemy AI factions teaming up against me and never telling opposing AI factions to leave their boundaries.

The other part of the gameplay is the combat, and it's easily the worst part about this game. The bad but understandable part about it is that it is way too "gamey". Yeah, it makes sense because it's a fucking game but an example is any unit being able to take down units such as artillery or, get this, a fucking cruise missile. I've heard horror stories of a tank being taken down by a spearman. You may ask yourself "How is that possible and how does it make sense?" First off, it doesn't make sense. Secondly, it's possible because the combat is entirely dependent on probability. You add the attack of the attacking unit and the defense of the defending unit together. You then take the attack and divide it by the total number. Repeat with the defense. When attacking or defending, combat goes round after round (unit A attacks, then unit B attacks, repeat)until either it has lasted too long or one of the units dies(with armies it consists of several units, so battles lasts longer).

An example would be the spearman vs. tank scenario. A tank has 8 defense, a spearman has 1 attack. That's a 1/9 vs. 8/9. That's an 11.11% chance vs. 88%. While 11% doesn't seem like a lot, a tank can still lose a fucking battle to a SPEARMAN(bronze age weaponry vs a giant moving metal bunker). It is ENTIRELY dependent on % chance. The combat system is a lot more of an issue with looking at how units are balanced. An example would be the offensive/defensive units right into industrial age, the cavalry and the rifleman. The cavalry has 6 attack. The rifleman has 6 defense(and 4 attack but I'll get to that). That's a 50-50 chance on either side. Another example : Medieval infantry vs. longbowmen is 33% vs. 66%, respectfully. It's the same situation with virtually all units. When you calculate in the 50% bonus with city walls, and then the bonus given depending on the size of a city, defending vs. attacking(aka expanding and growing your nation) is heavily unbalanced. That being said, in my experience the AI always seems to have the upperhand, even in 50-50 battles. Very early, the combat is an RNG wall but even by medieval era, it's way too late and too unbalanced to think about how much time it would take to make enough soldiers 

Listen, I don't fucking know how to fix such a glaring issue as this. It's just not a good combat system. Everyone who's played roguelikes such as Darkest Dungeon can attest to how terrible and unfun random chance can be and, as far as I'm concerned, it's never ever ever been done in a productive, effective, and, most importantly, FUN way. It completely ruins the momentum of a game when a nation decides to wage war because you refused to give them something for absolutely nothing, only to have 30+ cavalry storm your borders in 3 turns because, why the fuck not?

A comment I read on another review has stuck with me and it's made me reflect on other games that I find myself not enjoying because I lose a lot. "The point of the game isn't to [b]win[/b]. It's to [b]play[/b]. I agree wholeheartedly. Buy this game if you want to experience it and can put in the time to master it but I personally don't think it's worth it.

review:
lmao this game really needs a tutorial, or someone making an explanation on it. I had no frikin idea on how to play this, so i was figuring it out for 3 hours. Little do you know, I was about to get gangbanged by the Americans, and like two other randoms.

Pros:

-Cheapest version of Civilization avaliable on Steam

Cons:

-Too confusing
-No tutorial
-Nothing makes sense
-Every civilization I make goes bankrupt some how
-Never enough food
-Game always tracks scouts that are exploring for every turn
-Production menu is confusing
-City menu is confusing


In total, 

Just buy Civilization 4 if you want a cheap civ game. It's so much easier and 
better, and not a confusing headache.

review:
Este Juego, desde su primera edici√≥n fue de los primero que jugue con un Computador, y realmente este estilo de juegos me encantan. Civilization I, II y en esta ocasi√≥n el III tiene unas mejoras increibles frente a su versi√≥n inicial que aun juego. Lo recomiento al 100%, ya pronto voy a adquirir las siguientes versiones y a opinar sobre los cambios que noto. Para mi es una forma espectacular de pasar una tarde frente al computador mejorando mi civilizaci√≥n.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027851183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 106375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7499, 'last_played': 1658717451}
review:
What makes Civ3 stand the test of time? Combat. The only Civ that can compare to Civ3 in terms of combat is Civ4. Every Civ after 4 wants you to play with a handful of cities and no army. Civ3 is literally about taking over the world with massive armies of 500+ units. Even 4 reigned this in because in 4 you need siege units to take cities. The unit sound effects in Civ4 don't sound like battle hardened bad asses like they do in Civ3. Civ3 is not a perfect game but it is solidly designed game, built by solid PC game designers, prior to the corporatization of video gaming. 

The later Civ's don't improve on the flaws on the previous versions, they are completely different games with new flaws, and in my opinion they do not provide a good experience for military conquest of the world, while Civ3 perfectly encapsulates this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006138667', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1550712098}
review:
I think this is my favorite Cic game, I only  have a few hours played, but I had it before I got it on steam.  This was a huge improvement over Civ 2.  The ability to turn other factions cities in the middle if you empire thanks to culture was a much needed improvement.  Hex also made for smoother  movement, in addition managing where citizens worked in a city was supper easy, its also the last on to stop being that easy (not sure about Civ 4, i skiped that one).  For the most part units are the same as Civ 2, except now each civ has a unique unit, some more useful than others since some are only useful on the "BC eras" while other are far better in the "modern era" (a chariot vs F15).  Each civ also has bonuses to various stats, such as faster navel units or a science research bonus. The xpacs add some nice content, but to me they seem t make the game end faster, but that could just be from being engrossed in the game. 

Civ 5 and Beyond Earth are good (as  is Civ 6 Im sure), each has their own things that make it better, but in the end Civ 3 is at the top of my list, even if i dont play it as much as the other ones right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132995625', 'num_games_owned': 1399, 'num_reviews': 753, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1520669216}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete
Im deutschen Original von 1999.

Die hier vorliegende englische Version von 2004 enth√§lt die 2 DLCs und es ist wiedereinmal ein deutsches Spiel, dass es nicht auf deutsch gibt, hier auf Steam. Englischkenntnisse sind eigentlich nicht n√∂tig um es dennoch zu spielen. Civ. III besteht aus 3 v√∂llig unterschiedlichen Programmierungen, die alle spielbar sind. Leider gibt es den Weltenbauer nicht dazu, dieser war wirklich herausragend und voll funktionsf√§hig.
Das Jahr 2001 und dies war das Jahr an dem die Macher von Civ. der Welt gezeigt haben, was alles m√∂glich ist, wenn man gewillt ist etwas au√üergew√∂hnlich gutes zu programmieren. Riesenhafte Karten (dagegen ist Civ. VI geradezu winzig), 32 Nationen und den St√§dten kann man beim wachsen zusehen, da man die Stadt aufrufen konnte. Dieser Teil ist vor allem f√ºr all jene gedacht die gro√üe L√§nder aufbauen wollen inclusive der ben√∂tigten Ressourcen daf√ºr. Civ. III ist eindeutig von der Spielbarkeit, das beste Spiel seiner Art. Ich habe damals eine Realistik Mod mit dem Weltenbauer programmiert. Mit der gr√∂√üt m√∂glichen spielbaren Fl√§che, allen Nationen, vielen neuen Ressourcen und Tonnen von zus√§tzlichen Geb√§uden und Einheiten. Nach 2 Jahren war sie fertig. Leider wurde mir der PC und auch die Sicherungskopie gestohlen. Trotz dieses unsch√∂nen Ereignis, spiele ich die hier vorliegende Version sehr gerne. 

S√§mtliche Civ. Reviews zu allen existierenden Civ. spielen hier:
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/hoi4deu

Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete
In the German original from 1999.

The present English version from 2004 contains the 2 DLCs and it is once again a German game that is not available in German, here on Steam. Knowledge of English is actually not necessary to play it anyway. Civ. III consists of 3 completely different programs, all of which are playable. Unfortunately there is no Weltenbauer, it was really outstanding and fully functional.
The year 2001 and this was the year the creators of Civ. have shown the world what is possible when you are willing to program something exceptionally good. Huge maps (on the other hand, Civ. VI is downright tiny), 32 nations and the cities can be seen growing, since you could call up the city. This part is primarily intended for all those who want to build large countries including the necessary resources. Civ. III is clearly the playability, the best game of its kind. Back then I programmed a Realistic Mod with the Weltenbauer. With the largest possible playable area, all nations, lots of new resources and tons of additional buildings and units. After 2 years it was finished. Unfortunately my PC and the backup copy were stolen from me. Despite this unpleasant event, I really enjoy playing this version.

All Civ. Reviews on all existing Civ. Play here: 
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/hoi4deu

author: {'steamid': '76561198273167321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 338566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5781, 'last_played': 1705958320}
review:
In my mind, Civ III was the best version of the game around.  Many fans produced Mods and customised scenarios fellow players could take a run at.  I lost interest in IV and V ... Starships was a joke as far as I am concerned.  BE was a good version that I have played and enjoyed a lot.  I have not even tried VI.  Maybe if it hits the 90% discount sales.

I do not know if anyone produces new MODs or scenarios for Civ III these days.

I would highly recommend the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123513396', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 21735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7443, 'last_played': 1623718949}
review:
I've played Civ3, Civ4, Civ5, and Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri (also known as SMAC).  Civ3 and SMAC are still the best of these to me.  I wish Steam had the full version of SMAC, cuz I never was able to get the expansion pack for that one.

I got THIS version of Civ3 as part of a package deal.  I already had a CD-ROM of the original game and played that a lot.  I had plans to hunt down the expansion packs for it as well, but then Steam came into my life.

I compare playing Civ3 to a Poker tournament.  It's pretty easy to learn how to play, and hard to win in the long run.  Despite all the hours I've put into it, I've never won a game, even when I thought I was supposed to.  The point isn't to win, though; the point is to play.  Every time I've done that, I've learned something else.  I've also quit many games due to the fact that it was obvious I had been dealt a losing start.  Replay value approaches the infinite due to the sheer number of variables that go into a game, most of which are customizable, and some of which are procedurally generated (including the map, which will make or break you most times).

I was hoping that Civ4 and Civ5 would prove to be closer to this game and SMAC combined.  That turned out not to be the case.  Because of my love for this game and SMAC, I've found it difficult to enjoy 4 and 5 for what they offer.  They didn't feel like improvements on the formula, TBH.  I say that cuz, well, Civ3 is just that frickin' good.

For me, Civ3 is a fine, and also somewhat extreme, example of how gameplay is superior to graphics.  I can't say that pining for the days of sprites is in everyone's best interest; but sometimes, awesome polygonal renderings are just too much, or they wind up being more of a hindrance or distraction.  That said, Civ3 is not particulary known for its awesome sprites, either.  Still, you know what is what in this game.  Plenty of people made mods for the game as well.  I've seen Lord of the Rings mods, and one or two intended to improve how terrain features looked.  I never got into these, myself, although I do wish some things were easier to see due to design.

If you like strategy games, or are looking to try one, give Civ3 a shot, or let it be your introduction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128621592', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 15217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7291, 'last_played': 1700030066}

author: {'steamid': '76561198303913226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1520, 'last_played': 1654366072}
review:
I absolutely love this game... It is my favourite Civilization game, even though I have 4 and 5 as well... It's the simplicity of this one that can engage me for hours on end, and I can easily play it on my laptop when traveling or whatever... I've owned this game for years and spent many hours playing it... I liked it so much that when the PC CD-ROM accidentally ended up in storage last year, I bought a second copy on steam...

So yes, I really like this game...

It looks like shit, has some bugs when I allow for the space victory (at least when I'm playing it) and it can be very generic, but I like that it's uncomplicated, that you can just build up the world, and that when you mess about with the ini file, you can basically do whatever you want in choosing if you even want ANY oponements...  It's just very good and fun to play... Trust me on this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198117109804', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 13856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10373, 'last_played': 1545045041}
review:
Great and one of my favorite games, but it is definitely not for everyone.

Infuriating mechanics! The RNG combat is the one glaring flaw that keeps me actively recommending this game to anyone. It sounds cool in theory that a single guy armed with a stick with a rock taped to it can defend a city from bombers and an army of cavalry, sure, but not when you're on the losing end of that deal. It makes conquest victories a real pain in the behind. 

The entire game is very largely decided by your starting location which will tie in to how fast you'll be able to spam settlers. If you don't have a certain number of cities by 100 AD you're just not going to win. There's a lot more chance going on than strategy to the point to where sometimes it feels more like a dice rolling simulator. 

Despite everything, I still love this game and can't stop playing it. If you're a fan of the franchise like me or enjoy a challenge then I think you'll have a good time with 3. Otherwise give it a hard pass and shoot for one of the newer releases with more balanced mechanics.

But, the main defect I think, is the WRONG weight algorithm during the army fighting. For example, in a round, a regular Javelin Thrower (2/3) of AI killed an elite swordman (5/5) and a veteran swordman (4/4) on the same terrain, plain, and without rivers among them. Accoding to the Civilopedia, Javelin Thrower: attack,2; defense,2; movement,1; Swordman: attack,3; defense,2; movement,1; Also you could blame me that I don't know the Javelin Thrower. What about this? A regular warrior of AI (3/3) guarded the city which is on the plain and has no walls no rivers around and it killed my two regular Medievil Infantries (3/3), two regular Pikemen (3/3) and a regular Spearmen (3/3) in three rounds. Accoding to the Civilopedia, Medievil Infantry: attack,4; defense,2; movement,1; Spearman: attack,1; defense,2; movement,1; Pikeman: attack,1; defense,3; movement,1; warrior: attack,1; defense,1; movement,1; I was crazy and so is the game. I don't know how the game works, but I believe that the warrior from the late Stone Age got the Maxim Gun and killed them all. So shame, huh? So I don't like to recommend. The epic can not depend on the random artificial probability.

I would argue it's the best way to blow 2-4 hours (especially if the internet is down).

author: {'steamid': '76561198097827137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4562, 'last_played': 1587299707}
review:
This game is a gem.. it delivers a unique atmosphere and enjoyment that no other civ managed to equal, not even civ 6. 

PROS
- Each era contains its unique soundtrack, and nore of them are as boring as the soundtracks of civ 5 and civ 6. 
- You want to conquer a city? Go for it, send in a ton of units and take it.. your offensive units vs your enemy's defensive units, no insane bonus for defending a city and no ridiculous penalties for capturing as many cities as you want (looking at you civ 5). 
- The fact that you can stack as many units as you want on a single stack was a vital mechanic that civ 5 should have never taken away.. it makes the game clunky and unnecessarily limitating.
- All units have 2 values, an offensive one and a defensive one, allowing for more complex strategies and making every units a lot more unique and specialized. 

CONS
The AI will be unforgiving and sooner or later, every single one of them will swarm you will armies aimed at ending you.. it can be very challenging for players who like to simply give up when things get difficult, because they will. They progress very quickly with science, just to make things even more difficult. For this reason, i strongly suggest new players to choose the easiest level of difficulty at first, or maybe the one after it for players who played a lot with other civs. 

CONCLUSION
Every mistakes that civ5's developpers made, the ones that we hoped were going to be fixed in civ 6.. well, this game will give you an experience of a vastly more satisfying and authentic civ game. after playing this game and enjoying it, you'll feel like civ5 took the wrong turn and civ6 will no longer be relevant to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098799531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1744, 'last_played': 1614701145}
review:
This is a classic Civ game, but with a classic flaw. The game cheats and cheats hard. By cheating the games AI will settle cities miles away from their territory and right next to yours. Thus forcing you to fight to keep your land free. Then after a few dozen turns they will send in a few stacked armies that almost always will desimate your troops.

Now this cheat isn't impossible to beat, but the deadly troop stack will sooner or later spell doom for you and your civ. Only real way around this cheat is to get an island, stay isolated as long as possible, and then hold out.

In the end having to play the game in isolation is boring and results in this game being a dud.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993836587', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1508701792}
review:
This was one of my first PC games ever. Don't judge it by Civ 6 or even 5
 Each game was not a step forward. More like to the side. Much like the world around us we don't see the changes day to day, but looking back things seem so different than how they are now. Civ 3 is infact a Civ game. Like a board game with extra steps (and I love that about it) Civ 3 is perfect for faster multiplayer and is more stylized than any other game in it's series.
Building a place over 100s of years. Your leader visually changing to time specific outfits. Civ 3 oozes charm and in my opinion a must play game to understand what seperates a Console Experience to a PC one.
I give it a solid pass on any metric you use.

review: Junto com outros jogos que marcaram minha inf√¢ncia esta o civilization 2,como n√£o o achei na steam resolvi comprar o 3,e n√£o me arrependi,para quem gosta de jogos mais antigos,deixando um pouco de lado a quest√£o gr√°fica para relembrar os velhos tempos est√° ai um jogo que demanda muito tempo e muitas estrat√©gias para se tornar supremacia no mundo de civilization.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019352484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1089, 'last_played': 1509941179}
review:
I m a fan of Civilization games since PSX Civilization 2. This game is a unique type of game,which each new game as a new world of potentials of being created out of random.Strong replay features  and different settings to test your wits and charisma as a ruler,this game is close to excellency for me in terms of quality of the experience that grants its players.
Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057998807', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 12802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11273, 'last_played': 1655263742}
review:
A classic country-building game. 

A great grab to play with friends, as LAN is pretty alright considering how old it is.

Also, if you're confused on what the heck to do, trial and error, baby. 
That's how I handled this game as a kid, and that's how you'll learn. It really makes everything feel so much better when you learn how to [strike]stop your financial adviser from bothering you because you've made your country bankrupt by pouring all the money into military[/strike] play by yourself, it's cathartic.

Pick up this game. Play this game. Waste time here.
Simple at first glance, but one of the most deep strategy games I've played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049095741', 'num_games_owned': 564, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2115, 'last_played': 1586039873}
review:
Let me start off by saying it has one hell of a learning curve, it's somewhere between Space Station 13 and Stellaris. Once you get the basics down, you're more or less set. Honestly, the only time you get dicked over is when you didn't think of something. Barbarians raping your city? You need spearmen.

Pros:
- Deep gameplay with plenty of upgrades.
- Every game is different.
- Friend betrayal simulator 2018.
- Flawless networked games.
Cons:
- Steepish learning curve.
- No main menu resolution scaling.

Silver Tier. Some bugs and incompatibility issues, but otherwise a great experience. Good replayablity, and a load of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129263984', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1172, 'last_played': 1637289182}
review:
I played this game... what, 10 years ago? And it's still one of the best installments of the Sid Meir Civilizations franchise. I enjoyed the game, enjoyed the graphics (at the time, haha), and enjoyed the mechanics. If I wanted, I could sit around on a map by myself. I could chill and kill with Gandhi. The only thing- the Aztecs.

I mean good gravy, come on! I'd be sitting around, and they'd declare war. Next thing I know LITERALLY 20 KNIGHTS just flooded into my borders! Always! It was terrible, as I was new to the series at the time...

So, Civilizations III, thank you for starting me in this great series. It's been a fun... well, roller coaster, one I've been happy and lucky to ride.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073643118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 75, 'last_played': 1516670908}
review:
Hands down my favorite Civilization game. Civ 4 is the best but theres always been something about Civ 3 that made it really special. Just recently realized this was on steam so I figured I would pick it up to see how it runs on a modern system.

Its playable for sure and even though all the menus and stuff are formated for 4:3 displays, I was able to run it at 2560x1080. The animation seems to be abit choppy though and I did have to change some compatability mode settings to get it to run. 

I'm not sure if this will get much playtime now as my old Athalon 1800xp ran this game a little better then my Ryzen 1800x seems to be able to now.  Its worth a look if you are into games from this time period.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998119247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 1328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1064, 'last_played': 1516005088}
review: Civilization III is the best strategy game, turn-based or otherwise, that I have ever played. Civ 3 is easily one of the most re-playable games around, especially for people who love empire builders. Another outstanding feature of Civ 3 is the editor, it allows users to very easily change all aspects of their gaming experience in lay-mans terms, unlike python from Civ 4. The game also includes tons of accurate historical information for history buffs, like myself. The only weak points of the game are the multiplayer aspects, with the exception of hotseat, but who needs the real world when you have the entire span of human civilization at your fingertips?

review:
A great game indeed
all other Civilizations by Sid Meier's game are built on this one
there are no differences:armies are only formed when you have generals
you have tile to tile combat
cities are like independent nations
there are no real borders
there is no real civ control

Call to Power was much better but/....they talekd about the ruins on Mars and they were banished:)))
Apolyton is a great company
go find version 2 instead at abandonia and at other places with Hammer of the gods and Simearth and Dune and other great games

author: {'steamid': '76561198095889681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1413845843}
review: Civ 3 is a great entry in the series, but there are some reasons why it doesn't hold up to the newer games. First is the combat and how the only viable defensive strategy is stacking all your units in your cities. The no military unit stacking rule starting in Civ V is such a simple and huge advancement. Second is how bad the AI is. The AI is just terrible compared the newer games. Third is that the quanitity of your cities is better than the quality. It is always the better option to settle as many cities as possible, even within your own borders. What keeps me coming back to this game is the nostalgia, the scenarios, and the simplicity. I love playing the WWII Pacific, New World, and Napoleonic Wars scenarios. For how cheap you can get this game there is no reason a Civ fan should not have this in their library.

author: {'steamid': '76561198246203912', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1570156729}
review: Es un buen juego, con mecanicas que si bien no son faciles, no son lo suficiente mente dificiles que cueste aprender, las opciones de la dificultad de la IA son perfectas a mi parecer, esta lo necesario y nada mas que eso, la jugabilidad me agrada, pese a ser de los que prefieren ver los ejercitos combatiendo en gran escala este juego tiene una manera de resolver los conflictos entre los beligerantes de una manera que no me resulta mala, veo que hay gente que no le gusta el juego porque se aburren, pues es un juego de estrategia, y como la mayoria de este genero te tiene que gustar como tal la gestion de ciudades, y pese a verlo viejo, todavia es algo que seguir√© jugando, en el mapa de campa√±a los graficos no son malos, lo √∫nico que se le nota es en el menu principal como le pasaron los a√±os.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072141831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1514066900}
review:
>things that's existence doesen't make me furious (fastly)
>this
pick one...
Alright, so I really like Age of empires(1,2,3), European wars:Cossacs, and want to get EU4. Well at first, I got Stronghold 2 as a gift, and it was a huge dissapointment. I love AoE,a lot of people said it's just like that, and is a really great,so it was a warning, that Strategy games may have more difference in gameplay and fun than for example m.o.b.a-s do. 
Then Civ3 become free and I was like, ok, free stuff is free, so grab it(I actually have about 10 free games which I've never played). Some of my friends told me that it's like EU4, and it's what AoE is for RTS(So yeah I've expected a lot from this game), mainly this is why I haven't abandoned it after 3 hours.I gave it several chances,but no, it just wasn't even a mediocre level strategy management game, not even the flash game level.
So let's start with the problems like there is no story mode, tutorial, or any kind of concept, you just "let's play". I know it's from 2005 but as I remember common sense already existed back then, and it doesen't make sense to sell a game without a tutorial, even if there is a user guide given, there should a tutorial.
The construct of the interface is not intuitive AT ALL, so you can't say it supports self learning by the player.
And the thing that could save the game but it won't: 

the gameplay:
-it's irritating. it just throws you in a world, have fun do what you want. Ok it's a good idea for Terraria or Minecraft, but there you have no time factor, your opponents won't become stronger over time, observing and being patient won't punish itself.
-it's always on 90% auto pilot, but the auto pilot is a piece of shit, want to create and build useless stuff.
-it's chaotic, the map is filled with stuff but nothing says what is it good for. It's like Dwarf fortress but at least Dwarf fortress is not shallow. And here comes the biggest problem:
- The entire game is assuming that the citizens are sub 70 IQ idiots, and bread and circus is enought, EVEN DURING STARVATION. Also the entire system of building suggests that only the government can build useful stuff and without government control everione is fucked. k the last mistake is done by almost all strategy game but still.
-also the wonders... The entire wondersystem is a disgrace to human history(k, the entire game is a fucking discrace to human history),it says it was all done back then by governmental initiation(socialist porpaganda), and the game starts in a mithologial manner but ends fully materialistic, "ThE IrOn CaStInG ReNdErEd ThE sTaTuE oF ZeUs ObSoLeTe"YOU RENDERED YOURSELF OBSOLETE, MEIER! BTW who is this guy? Is he there like the "Wrigley's Orbit" to avoid copyright stuff, or like aloe vera, becaulse it sounds good(doesen't work).
-(I really hope the character limit isn't to small), so, the next problem is: the cultures. Let's start with the fact that nobody I mean NOBODY has the same culture as 2500 years before, they might act like it, they might say it, but it's bullshit. Also the game says it has effect, IT DON'T. And who the fuck told you that persians had dark skins? Microsoft??? "THEY WUZ KHANGS AND SHIIIEEEET". Man they might made that stupid expansion but at least in 2015, when they were kind of forced to do it this way. Congrat's man, you were cucks before it was cool.
-BTW where are the resources? Where Are the lambs? The iron, and whatever is on the map? I guess they wanted to create a system where it don't go in a magic central depot like in AoE, but they failed. At least they failed while actually trying something(unlike the other aspects of the game where they haven't even tried and still failed).
--------- ALRIGHT, AND THE THING THAT MADE ME TIRED OF THIS FUCKING SHIT: THE CAMERA
no joke, the fucking camera movement is so fucked up beyond belief that it made me get tired of the game and just quit. It jumps,everiwhere THE GAME WANT TO TELL YOU WHAT TO LOOK AT BUT NOT WHERE TO LOOK, it shows everithing for a second then move away(and I turned off everything I could to prevent the automove), and if you move back to let's say 3 units, and move one the camera jumps away to the"next" unit, the game wants to tell you in what order to move your units in. Also the fucking domestic advisor keeps no shit Sherlocking about things that are obvious, and won't help or anithing, just says what I already know. And you have to accept it with a 4*4 pixel shit, and after you click it the camera jumps away from the place to somewhere else KUZ YOLO and forces you to forget the problem you were already aware or to spend half the playtime searching on the map.
-the combat system is basicly a chessgame BUT, you move all units then you opponent moves all units, so there is less tactic there even with the fortify mechanic. There is strengh and hp with randomness which makes it a bromantic duette of KEK and RNGESUS.
-In general things sometimes matter, sometimes not and the entire game is just inconsistent.

Alright so I've got this game for free than why am I crying over it? Well becaulse it was for no money but it still costed me 11 hours, that instead of leaving it when I saw that it's shit I gave it several chances. I should have done what I did with Stronghold 2: Start it, see it's shit, quit, uninstall, have no problem with that game ever again. 
And I'm tired of All the other Tips,and the hyped up shits. NO IT'S NOT GOOD. "B-But muh childhood, muh gamer culture" alright this is already 2 thing I don't give a single fuck about. 
1/a:  if you played it as a child, I hope you had fun, now get out 
1/b: well, you played it as a child it's a GAME FOR CHILDREN THATS WHY.

2/a :Ce n'est pas un argument. French has no culture. Niether games has. It's just a bunch of larping random guy with the illusion they have any kind of taste.
2/b: Gaming culture huh? Well there are games with culture for sure, Undertale,FNAF and so on, check out their culture... you still Genuinely think it's a good thing???? 
2/c: Culture and classics and stuff. Dude, stuff like Doom deserves respect as it had a fully new type among games. Turn based strategy is just Chess on steroids(and HEROin)So the next thing is that just becaulse it's old it doesen't mean it's good, also, you can do something in a shitty way for a long time so again GOTO:2/a(sorry for the halting). Not being a graphicfag is a good and respectworthy thing, but there have to be some real value in the game.
2/numberoffucksigive: O MY GOD IT'S A BLACKHOLE!!!

By the way the game didn't really gave me freedom in any manner just go through the path and that's it. Now if you think outside the box for just a little, you will see how paved the road is. Can you think outside the box? If yes, this game is not for you, this is the ultimate normiegame. 
I just wanna buy EU4 with all DLC for less than 10 times the price of the basegame but it's probably something Swedish developers don't like( KHM... it's a bit Overkill to say I know). Well I played what is thrown at me for free, and I learned one thing...
K, I
 haven't learn anything, I was right all the time, 
if something is for free, it wouldn't worth any money. 

Thank whoever gabe me this game for free, he(and I'll assume his gender no matter what you say, tumblr is down the hall to the LEFT) saved my homies the cost of Civ6(we want to play some strategy stuff toghether but most friends hates AoE).Alright but now I should go to sleep, the last game just made me rage so hard that I couldn't sleep anyway.

Merry Christmas!

review: This game is absolute garbage in the current year. The game broke my monitor and I had to restart my computer in order to attempt to try to play the game again. In addition, there are no settings that let you change your resolution. To attempt to change my resolution, I had to look online to find out what files to open. However, when I tried to look for the settings file, it was not there. I had to spend 20 minutes trying to find out what file to change, but was unable to in the end. Do not buy this game if you own a monitor that was produced past 1993.

review: Ignore the small amount of hours I've put into the Steam version. Realistically this game has drained easily over a hundred hours of my time since it was first released. The Civilization franchises just keeps getting better but this is the one I will always remember most fondly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198329567186', 'num_games_owned': 11, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5019, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3354, 'last_played': 1706005977}
review: I need to be careful not to play this game too often. When I do play, I get sucked in for hours on end; it's so addictive. I used to own the CD-ROM set years ago - a gift from my brother. Over time, the CDs got scratched, and I was wary when buying this game. I remembered the addictive effects it had on me in high school - staying up all hours of the night, every night. This time around, I can handle it better. If anyone out there is considering buying this game, just be careful - set yourself a timer based on the maximum limit you're willing to let yourself play in any given night. Otherwise, you'll keep playing until you crash, and you'll end up missing school, being late for work, and ignoring UFOs passing overhead.

review: Childhood and adulthood... either way it's a fun game. There are things I actually prefer from this version and in terms of replayablity this and V stand out in a way IV and VI dont' quite. The whole game feels well thought out and planned, the gameplay is enthralling for any strategy fan, and this game is one of the absolute kings of the genre. Recommend without hesitation, even to a player coming from V as their only Civ game.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198133086581', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 20061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1494356081}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete

This is really good civilization game. You can have fun with this game as in any other civ series game. This is not as modern as new civ games, so it does not feel as "smooth" as like vic IV or V. Combat mechanics are also a bit random. Overall it is a nice civ game. If you like civ series or overall stategy games I can recommend this to you. It is a nice different experience than the newer ones.

Grade for this: 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198264723096', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 9, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1709898435}
review:
this game is awesome, i would recomend this game for people who like long games and strategy games. 

first off i want to say this game was way ahead of its time and its not complicated, i just went in without reading about it or any civs game and i did use the tutorial, its an easy to learn long game. i would recomend making more civ games for windows 10 laptop that run at 60 fps.


NOTE IT DOES WORK FOR WINDOWS 10 LAPTOP AND NOT FOR MAC!!!


another thing i would like to say is get it when its not on sale worth all 5$ but if you get spend less get it then, there are over 10 different races and maps you can choose from to play on quick easy saves, and great controls.



I have over 1000 hours in this game offline, even though it doesnt say that much online,

author: {'steamid': '76561198069159152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2402, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1511920055}
review:
This is interesting. First, I must mention my first contact with Civilization was acquiring a copy of IV from Bookman's. Had to sell it back a time later, but since this Autumn (Black Friday) Sale showed up with this, IV, and V for cheap, I decided to acquire them all.

Having given this backstory, I must say that III is amusing, if a bit archaic, compared to my memories of IV (I'll get to replaying that soon). However, some of the visuals are beautiful, and the AI can be... interesting. Mostly, I miss Spock's narration, but that is a minor quibble.

All in all, it is an interesting intro to the series (since I don't know where one would find I or II).

author: {'steamid': '76561198130063094', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1512143874}
review:
I played Civ 1 and Civ 2 for years and years growing up and must have put over 1000 hours into each game. I then stopped playing for a good 5 years but tried the modern ones recently. For some reason they just didn't do it for me then I saw this on sale a while back. For me this is the best version of Civilization. Why you ask?

Not as micro management heavy as the 4th, 5th and 6th games but still plenty of city, military and science management to keep you happy. The AI isn't too overkill at the start meaning new players can get a feel for the game and learn the basics early. You still have plenty of options and customisation when starting a game with map editor and random map generation included.

If like me you love strategy games but hate over the top micro management and stomp AI then Civ 3 is the best in the series. Sure it lacks the colourful new graphics of the modern games but it's still very playable and will run on even and lower spec laptop these days.

I have never played multiplayer so cannot comment on that. I just feel the balance and overall difficulty in this game is just right!

Not the most helpful review I know but my opinion! buy this one if you find the new games to intense and confusing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118075501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 103443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1630, 'playtime_at_review': 18525, 'last_played': 1710836863}
review:
Civ III was one of the first strategy games I played & shared with my brother.  In what other game could a fortified spearman from the ancient era be able to successfully defend a city against a tank?  Highly recommend for the nostalgia & fun gameplay.
*Edit* Playing on Windows 8.1, you must view entire beginning credits or press Shift to skip.  Game crashed before able tto see ranking at end of game.  Otherwise, gameplay is smooth.  Still great fun to cream America playing as my fave Cleopatra.

review:
For a game of its age, it has really aged well, and I swear this is not my nostalgia speaking here ^^!

The mechanics are well thought out and balanced and I would even go so far as to claim that some of them should've definitely been in the later games.

Overall I would say that this is a must have strategy if you are a fan of the series and other game like it.

review: It's dated, and I'm sure you'll find as many opinions about the best Civ game as there are Civ players. But this one is good. It's complex, and there are more options, choices, and ways to win than you can shake a stick at--the hallmark of a good strat game. The interface is clunky, and takes some patience but if you learn the keyboard shortcuts (and please, please, think of the children and learn those shortcuts) and you'll do fine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102792496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1432954943}
review:
I played them all but VI(reviews did that game in for me), this is the best of the series in my opinion. The flow and pace of the game is better than Civ V,Naval combat is wonderful and you actually have a good chunk of time to play with the old sailboats. Stratigic bombing can actually be a game changer,like many of the tech advancments. Unless you play it on the lowest dificalty setting the AI can keep up with you tech wise,to the point where they have guns around the time you have guns, they have nukes around the time you have nukes.
The games pace was really thought out, it works so much better then the rest of the Civ games for the most part .  Sure it has dated graphics, but it's a polished game with the best over all gameplay of the series. 

Also, I played this game more then 4.2 hours, I owned it when it came out and the CD's just done with life.

review:
[h1] O MELHOR DA S√âRIE CIVILIZATION!!! [/h1]

Esse jogo √© um daqueles cl√°ssicos que voc√™ sempre voltar√° a jogar. N√£o possui a "infantiza√ß√£o gr√°fica" dos √∫ltimos da s√©rie visto principalmente no V e VI. Jogo Civilization desde quanto me entendo por gamer e repito, esse jogo √© uma obra prima. Recomendo muito. N√£o deixe que o gr√°fico e o ano de lan√ßamento engane seus conceitos. COMPRE e conhe√ßa o Civilization que ganhou o mundo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035383340', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 243, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1510320952}
review: Civilization III is well, the 3rd of the franchise, and a little older than the recent Civilization 5 that's out. But with its older graphics and game play it still rips at nostalgia strings. It's a turn based strategy game for sure. Select a world type, ( how much water and land mass going on) the climate type ( temperate, arid) and enemies/allies.The civilizations you can play, it seems anybody. Russia, Japan, Germany, Inca and American. Each has their own perks by a leader. (I went American and got President Lincoln). Start with the 3 basic types of guys. A settler that makes towns, a worker who works and a warrior that fights/protects your civilization. AND START BUILDING A CIVILIZATION. Grow and expand starting from cave times to relatively modern times. It's a long long game, depending on the victory conditions. Build all the wonders, take every one out, game ends after so many turns... All the civilizations do look the same and color difference for teams. That's about it. And you have to click and move each individual every turn. This can be tedious and annoying, I'm going to admit. The game is casual and relaxed and just a lot of fun. There are saved game files and conquests that were introduced onto this game like Age of Mythology. Set scenarios of historic events and timelines that you control. There is A LOT.  You kinda find out just how hard it was to grow as Rome or as Japan in the beginning of those civilizations. The conquest of Spain over Latin America or the Scandinavia over the Americas.  A fun game, I'd upgrade to Civilization 5, but this is a good start if on sale or free grab. Explore the beginnings of the game kinda thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124938515', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1510660316}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045435292', 'num_games_owned': 718, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1387, 'last_played': 1509465150}
review:
Really loving this game and in general all the Civ series, so I can say I'm biased about this. 16 years old game and you can have as much fun playing this as any of the latest releases. The combat mechanics are a bit too random and it seems to favors the AI some times, but you can say it adds on the total unpredictability of the whole game experience. 
Just a note on the resolution issues this game has due to it's aging. To play at maximum resolution, locate the config file "Conquests\conquests.ini" and add the line "KeepRes=1" at the end.

Civ3 still gets a thumb up from me tho... On to Civ6 !

Para uno que naci√≥ en el 94 y no conoc√≠a bien que era Civilization en general, digo que est√° bien, necesito mejorar y no perder el tiempo en tonter√≠as en este juego y punto. Pero para los nuevos, mejor id a los m√°s modernos y si tene√≠s un cup√≥n que actualmente os lo han dado de Civ VI, dadle un intento, pero ese es el festival de los DLCs y por desgracia no compr√© la edici√≥n deluxe y no me gusta como han implementado la IA siendo Mini Ghandis en el universo donde es como Civilization donde Adolfo es jud√≠o, los aztecas vencieron a los espa√±oles con caballos, los romanos tienen tanques, los babilonios han fundado la XCOM y Gandhi es peor que el ser m√°s perverso que ha engendrado el ser humano. review:
I Got the Game for Free at Humble Bundle, so theres no complaining,
But Dam, blast from the past, i love strategic games and i loved conquering all the shit head npc, 
(since there is no more Multiplayer on this old fuvker), 

BUT after the Crusader eras, i always dominate the field and i just wait for the turns to get by faster so i could unlock the Nuclear Bomb ( I mean everyone who plays civilization just waits waits for this Climax)  WHICH TAKES FOREVER!
Basically you just Press space Bar to wait for it to pass by , this may take over 30 mins just to unlock nuclear BOMBS!
P.S The explosion from their Nukes on this oldie is just sad, its like nutting in a fucking plastic bag , no fucking CLIMAX!,

I give it a meh, but if you want to waste your time on this prehistoric Grandpa, go ahead

author: {'steamid': '76561198080433284', 'num_games_owned': 265, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 1437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 982, 'last_played': 1655515011}
review: This is a great game, though it hasn't aged well. It is still a lot of fun to play: a simpler, more streamlined version of Civilization, without things such as unit promotions and religion... just the essential Civ. It is different enough from newer games to be worth playing, it is not just the same but worse. The old graphics show their age, but in the end are easy to bear. But the user interface... yeah, that is a tough one. If you already are used to old strategy games, you probably can deal with it; but if you are not, figuring out the unintuitive mechanics and the convoluted way of showing and doing things might be a challenge in the beginning and make it hard to enjoy the game itself. If you can get past this barrier, go ahead and give Civ3 a try, but if you want a better experience with a convenient and intuitive UI maybe stick to newer titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198246769620', 'num_games_owned': 1028, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1522466108}
review:
$5 for potentially hundreds of game hours, with even more once you discover the modding community's content? Get it. It doesn't matter if Civ 3 isn't on sale, just get it.

If steam recorded non-steam hours I'm pretty sure it would be in the 500-1000 hour range from when I played it back in the day. Civ 4 is the successor and improves on it, but Civ 3 will run on a potato* and has a comfy OST.

Seriously, if you've read this far you can scroll up and click the "add to cart" button.

* It'd run hot on my first laptop, a $1500 one from 2002 for school. No heat on a computer a little less than half the price from 2015.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151754519', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 19634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1709672511}
review: I feel I have barely scratched the surface of this game, but I already think it's absolutely wonderful. I've only played three and a half rounds, but in that time I had a blast. It can be a bit confusing at first, heck I still find it confusing, but it's easy to see past that. I would like to note that this is the only Civilization game I have played, so I have no basis of comparision for the others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094021692', 'num_games_owned': 1028, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1509140867}
review: Easily the worst game I have ever played. A freind and I tried playing it together and this was just such a train wreck. We started over multiple times. Every single time we get 1 citizen farming on irrigated land with a road and then once the second comes they get miserable and riot, so you boost their happiness with gold, then that new citizen goes to work and just get enough food to survive and this continues on and on until you dont have the gold to keep them happy because you would then be going negative. so you have to make them entertainers which means someone isnt gathering food and thus your population staggers and remains stationary not getting any new people... so you are making no progress. and then it takes you forever to get even the most basic of technologies that other ai civs seem to get almost instanty? whats their secret? is it putting gold towards research? we cant do that it has to go to happiness. do they have specialist researcher? Well they dont seem to even make a turn of difference and doing that would again just eat up a worker and your city wouldnt be growing as you are breaking even on food, the only thing that can counter this is having a special food resource like wheat (and even luxury resources don't seemt to make a difference to happiness) because you would be getting enough food to cover one single person I.E. a specailist entertainer to make the one more citizen you are going to get in the future happy this is a 1-1 ratio so already its pointless... It seems multiplayer is much harder than single player but from what I have seen this is not only the worst civ game but one of the worst games I have ever played in general as you stuggle for hours only to find out your fucked from the beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071339384', 'num_games_owned': 803, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1527221316}
review:
This was given for free to Humble Bundle members recently. First launch crashed. Second launch I relised that screen ratio is 4:3 fixed and zero (in words: 0) display options. Okay, start game anyway... less than 2 minutes into the game the music loops. Mmhh okay, keep playing. Everybody declares war on me, okay, end game. Game crashes upon exit.

Publisher 2K giving away something for free, there you have it: 2 launches = 2 crashes, and audio bugged. Now I know why it was free. And after reading this far, you know, too. ;-)

PS. Somebody in the comments section suggested to change INI setting to fix a display issue (found on Steam forums). That seems to have broken the game even more for me: when installed, the game will not start at all, when rolling back the "fix," the right and bottom borders in game are cut off. Therefore, changing Preferences now is impossible and minimap, End Turn button and menus in game are not accessible any more. Those changes seem to be permanent even after reboots and Steam's own "Verify game integrity."

author: {'steamid': '76561198110945706', 'num_games_owned': 954, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1681, 'last_played': 1519943329}
review:
Got it free from HumbleBundle! :)

The first Civ/Sid Meier's game I have played, so no bias from that. Also one of the first strategy games I have really put time into (And one of the first ones I have played). The graphics of this game aren't the best, but they are good enough to where you can play the game without being confused. Great to waste time alone or with friends. After you get bored you can get Mods (I recommend Space Opera) to extend the fun ever more. 

Here is an arbitrary score. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197965049785', 'num_games_owned': 1464, 'num_reviews': 497, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1508498981}
review:
In what seems like forever ago, I was excited for the release of Civ 3. It was the time in my life when I was relentlessly digging into history books, and it would be great to have a game compliment that. Of course, I had already had games that did that such as Age of Empires 2. But a big strategy game that let me do everything? That seemed shiny. A friend let me borrow of Civ 2 so I could at least get a vague idea of what it was like before Civ 3 released, and then, eventually, I got my hands on the game itself.

Ok... this is probably an excess of nostalgia, but I was trying to convey something important here. Namely that I [i]really[/i] liked Civ 3 when it came out, and played it for countless hours. It was also the only real time where I actually got involved in modding, since the Civ 3 Scenario editor was super easy to use and making historical scenarios was one of the few fun things I had in those days. I didn't use this screen name back then, but I had another and it was synonymous with creating detailed, but accessible, scenarios about events such as World War I, the Eastern Front of WW2, and more.

Civ 3 also was the only Civ game I really got into. Sure, I played 4 and 5 plenty, but they just didn't suit me as much. Naturally, what I really mean by this is that like Civ 4 and 5, 3 had strategic resources that you needed in order to build certain units. Unlike those later Civ games however, the amount of a resource you had didn't limit the number of units you could build that used those resources. So in my games I ended up with enormous empires with scores of cities, thousands of military units, and also that one time I made over 300 ICBM's. While that might seem absolutely crazy (you do know who is writing this, right? :P), it made everything seem large in scale and made the late-game wars huge endeavors that actually felt like it was a world war rather than just a skirmish over a handful of cities. Civ games since have drastically cut down the number of cities wanted or needed for their games, and with it Civ, to me, lost the "epic" quality that made me like Civ 3 as much as I did. Some might prefer how Civ has changed in this regard, but for me there isn't quite anything like the kinds of global wars or the very real sense of nuclear annihilation that Civ 3 had.

So... yeah this "review" is basically just a nostalgia trip. Humble Bundle was giving this game out for free not so long ago, and so I found Civ 3 reinstalled on my PC close to fifteen years after I first played it. Does it work on Steam? Well, I was able to boot it up and poke around a bit just fine. I have heard that others have had problems with getting this running however, which is kind of funny because Civ 3 was a [i]very[/i] stable game in the sense that it almost never crashed.

Giving this a "yes" for all the fun times this game provided me in the distant past. I can't really do otherwise. :3

author: {'steamid': '76561198031426331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1508790302}
review: Got this from the Humble Bundle as something to tide me over until the morons at Direct2Drive get my copy of Civ IV running again.  Lots of fun, great replayability.  It runs pretty well, but there are some quirks.  I can't run it from Steam, have to open the folder and run the .exe.  Music does not work when talking to other Civs, but runs fine otherwise.   I had many hours on this game back when it came out, but I had forgotten how challenging it is.  Graphics are still pretty decent.  I much prefer this to Civ V, which I recently uninstalled, probably never to return.  Only real drawbacks for me are that it is not hex-based, which does let you cheese a bit on some aspects, and the fact that corruption, etc. do not scale well to really large maps.

author: {'steamid': '76561198319999730', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1655325573}
review: This game is fun at times, but also confusing. The UI hasn't aged well. After playing the game more and more, I found a lot of  features that I didn't even know exist, which made the game more fun and easier. All things considered, the game isn't very hard, but because I haven't played it a lot to know all of the little or big features/strategies the game has to offer, I found it a bit challenging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202022263', 'num_games_owned': 746, 'num_reviews': 423, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1508762243}
review:
The player must construct and improve cities, train military and non-military units, improve terrain, research technologies, build Wonders of the World, make war or peace with neighboring civilizations, and so on. The player must balance a good infrastructure, resources, diplomatic and trading skills, technological advancement, city and empire management, culture, and military power to succeed.

I for one find these type of games boring but since I received this game for free (from HumbleBundle) I'm giving it a thumbs up, it's not a bad game for it's time but you've got to have the patience and sadly.... I don't have that.

If I was a real reviewer i'd give this a 9.5/10 buuuuut i'm not so it's having a 5/10.
