review: Para los que recien lo tienen y estan diciendo que el juego es buenisimo, pues lamento decirles que no es asi, si bien es cierto no he jugado tanto tiempo como para dar una critica certera, pero llevo jugando Civilization III muchos a√±os, y la version normal funciona mucho mejor que esta. De partida, cuando te encuentras con otra civilizacion y se comunican, en la interfaz de comunicaci√≥n, se para la musica y el sonido, y cuando la cierras por un instante se escucha la musica que habia de fondo. Segundo, cuando construyes Grandes maravillas nuevas, la estatua de zeus y "Caballeros Templarios", en la vista de la ciudad no aparece, afecta al juego y aparece dentro de las caracteristicas de la ciudad, pero en el mapa de la ciudad no aparece. Tercero, el multijugador no funciona, intente jugar en LAN, y no se puede, de partida no te dice como poder crear una o como saber si ya creaste una sala como para poder empezar a jugar, es muy poco amigable en ese aspecto que le quita bastante valor y gracia al juego, hubiera sido genial que el multijugador funcionara... pero no, no funciona, mi recomendaci√≥n? juegen a la primera version de este juego Sid Meier's Civilization lll aun que sea para pasar el rato, esta mejor hecho que esta version...

author: {'steamid': '76561198057075077', 'num_games_owned': 455, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1508623903}
review: Ich bin leider kein Spieler von Civilization 3 gewesen als es 2001 raus kam, deswegen kann ich es nicht mit dem Nostalgie Bonus bewerten, allerdings habe ich CIV 5 einige Stunden gespielt und will mir auch noch den 6. Teil holen. Von diesem Spiel hier kann ich wirklich nur abraten, es hat ein schreckliches Menu f√ºr heutige Verh√§ltnise, einen Soundtrack den ich sofort ausgeschaltet habe weil er nur aus ein paar Trommelschl√§gen besteht (Im Spiel selber, die Menu Musik ist in Ordnung) und auch sonst motiviert mich einfach rein gar nichts hier auch nur eine Minute mehr zu spielen, als das kurze reinschauen. F√ºr alle die es fr√ºher gespielt haben und einfach wieder die sch√∂nen Erinnerungen aufleben lassen wollen sind 5 Euro ein guter Preis, f√ºr den Rest, CIV 5 ist mittlerweile bestimmt auch in einem Sale mal f√ºr 5 Euro zu haben, es ist sehr schlecht gealtert und einfach nicht mehr zeitgem√§√ü.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996128287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1513724540}
review:
So as I was getting tired with all these milleanial crying about bad graphics, the resolution doesn't change or there is no tutorial etc. Shame on you. 

The game was released in 2001. To me, the graphics look just fine.

As in for the resolution schaisse, i could find a fix LITERALY in one minute. Just googled "Civ 3 widescreen" and blam. There it was. Just modify the Civilization.ini (or in this case, conquests.ini) and add KeepRes=1. REALLY hard wasn't it?
And during the 2001, most people used windows 2000 or older system and had crt monitors.
So that kinda explains why all the problems with newer Windows systems. 

As in with the tutorial, im pretty sure that it was included in an actual manual that had came with the physical copy. Just like Civ 2 did. And in the 2001 it wasn't that common that a computer game didn't have an ingame tutorial. Hell, it was trial and error method on many games. That was what we did with my friends when we were kids and didn't know english yet (allthough we learned a lot from gaming and were top of the class). 

Stop whining about the nonexistent problems and learn to a) solve them yourselves or b) to find information on how to solve them.

Now, thats with all the steaming. In my opinion the game is good for its age and well worth the 5‚Ç¨ price. The "free" makes it even better. I can recommend this to anyone who wants to feel that great nostalgia or get back to the roots of civilization series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198302804856', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 10724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1619694041}
review:
Civ III is an apogee of the former "Civilization" games focus. Why play it now, when Civ V is tuned,fixed, updated so many times - and even price looks fine for almost every pocket? Well, it's all for that focus I'm talking about.

First three of Civilozation games were taking the player back at the dawn of the known history- and to help to notice the flow of time,there was some borderlines across that mighty river of the so-called "4th dimension". Starting with the Civ V this process of moving through timeline were "smoothed", to the point where player gliding from the start to the end of the game without any noticable delay. I'm not saying that's bad- I like Civ V myself, but sometimes you don't want simple transfer from A to B, from the stone to electricage, you want to see cornerstones to each specific era. And with that, Civ V is giving you the better experience. 

 All that i said in the previous passage,is arguable,of course. But here is another trait of Civ III which was intentionally cutted off ( in favor of balance, of course) , the size of armies and all warfare business. 
With all complexity of the game mechanics in the Civ V,armed conquests there looking as they performed 20-30 people at best. In Civ III,we have totally another scale. So,when I want to win a game of Civilization by Assault strategy, I start Civ III. 

The third volume of Civilization is dated, but still deep,still challenging, still holding the billion of possitibilities to build your nation. Make your Way. So I'll mark the game as 9?10, not ideal, but so much enjoyable! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198174884434', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 663, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1508546619}
review:
Bom, essa an√°lise vai ser SUPER curta pois eu realmente n√£o tenho muito o que dizer a respeito de Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III. Al√©m disto, esta minha an√°lise ser√° diferente das outras, n√£o irei falar dos pontos negativos e positivos do game, mas sim falar o que achei dele pelo que vi.

Para come√ßar, caso queira jogar, tenha uma paci√™ncia sensacional, eu tenho, mas esse jogo conseguiu tirar a toda.

Como disse antes, voc√™ necessita de paci√™ncia, mas por que ? Eu n√£o entendi muito bem a jogabilidade do jogo, pois voc√™ controla dois personagens, mas tem rounds para mov√™-los, n√£o consegui entender mesmo.

Ao que me parece, a proposta do jogo √© muito boa, que simplesmente consiste em voc√™ explorar o mundo como era antes de Cristo, tanto que no in√≠cio do jogo, voc√™ escolhe o lugar que quer ficar, quem quer ser, como Rom√¢no, Jap√¥nes, Russo, etc.

Aparentemente, tamb√©m podemos negociar com outros viajantes, ver a cria√ß√£o de lugares, como Nova York, e ter guerras.

O jogo tamb√©m me parece que tem ''Finais'' diversificados, mas como assim ? Aparentemente voc√™ pode acabar morrendo em qualquer lugar no game, o que faz dificultar o jogo, logo, o jogo te d√° a ''op√ß√£o'' de morrer de v√°rias formas diferentes.

''Ent√£o por que n√£o recomendo o jogo ? Se tem o 3 quer dizer que  o jogo √© bom.'' E bem, n√£o posso negar, o jogo realmente deve ter feito sucesso, mas temos que lembrar que somos humanos e temos opini√µes diferentes, e Sid Meier's Civilization n√£o me agradou e n√£o me fez querer continuar a jogar.

Eu peguei este jogo por key em um site, estou realmente feliz de n√£o ter gastado dinheiro.

review:
Locate [b]"conquests.ini"[/b] and add the line [b]"KeepRes=1"[/b] (without the quotation marks).
This should fix the resolution problem for your computer. Tested it myself and some 3 other people. It works and will also work for you.
Enjoy another great game from the series!

author: {'steamid': '76561198142788303', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1508517543}

author: {'steamid': '76561198215270809', 'num_games_owned': 2152, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1518142621}
review:
Yes its 16 years old, its turn-based strategy with city management and diplomacy, it doesn't have eye candy and all the fancy shaders. But its real, deep and beautiful.
Civilization III is a worthy addition to the series. I've played I and II (I still play Civilization I on dosbox) and I appreciate all the improvements from Civilization II (But II still has the best and funniest videos in the series).
Game runs without any issues on Windows 10 and I only added a single line to the config file to play at my maximum resolution. 
So locate "Conquests\conquests.ini" and add the line "KeepRes=1"

...and enjoy another classic masterpiece

author: {'steamid': '76561198154391267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1582471522}
review:
Wann ist ein Spiel gut ?
Wenn man nach √ºber 15 Jahren noch die Tastaturk√ºrzel im Kopf hat !

Sicherlich ist die Grafik nach heutigem Ma√üstab veraltet, darum ist es bei CIV jedoch nie gegangen. CIV spielt sich zu grossem Teil im Kopf ab. Die Karte ist mehr eine schematische Darstellung der Zivilisation, des Entwicklungstandes und des Weltreiches das man erschaffen hat. Richtig zu leben beginnt CIV in der eigenen Birne.
Am Spielablauf hat sich nie etwas ge√§ndert: Siedler ziehen, Stadt bauen, Truppen bauen, Welt erobern. Wenn man die grunds√§tzliche Mechanik verstanden hat mutiert CIV sehr schnell zu einem Grand Strategy Game mit irrer Spieltiefe. Der Technologie-Baum ist riesig, und man kann sein Volk von der Steinzeit ins Atomzeitalter f√ºhren. Die eingebaute "Civilopedia" und ein kurzes Tutorial beantworten die mei√üten Fragen und erleichtern den Einstieg.

CIV macht s√ºchtig und ist ein typisches "nur noch ein Zug"-Spiel. Durchzockte N√§chte inbegriffen.

L√§uft auch in hohen Aufl√∂sungen wenn man in der conquests.ini "KeepRes=1" unten einf√ºgt.
Das Spiel ist auf Englisch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109632201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 69523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23924, 'last_played': 1676789572}
review: One of my very favorite games even to this day! The functionality runs seamlessly with game play and mechanics for a total experience in a world history of your own making. The civilizations are diverse, each with strengths and weakness you need to manage and combine together for the ultimate in strategy and critical thinking. Each individual item has its own entry which you can research and learn real historical facts from. Truly a game that will make want to have "just... one... more... turn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031151026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 29146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9380, 'last_played': 1705493472}
review:
My favorite Civilization title of all time. This game may be old, but I find it's graphics are just right for the genre and it does not have the cartoony look that some later titles are sometimes guilty of. Being an older title, the AI isn't always the smartest and will struggle to perform certain tasks like sea-based invasions. A huge problem with this game is its infamous RNG which has led to powerful units being killed by weaker unit (i.e. spearman kills tank). However, just play without "preserve random seed" enabled and you can just save before each battle and reload quickly to get a better result if you feel you have been cheated. Other features missing include advanced diplomacy beyond war and trade and revolutions occuring in pre-established empires (a feature lacking from most unmodded Civ titles).

The thing that makes this game my favorite Civ is the availablity of mods to customize this game to your heart's content. You can play out just about any scenario you can think of. Although a lot of files were lost when civfanatics changed a while back, there is still plenty of diverse content available. I would highly recommend the WorldWide mod for anyone looking for a much expanded version of the game. Whether you want to make small changes like add in one or two units or a custom civ, or install total conversions and scenarios, the tutorials online make it very easy to add such things in.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Civilization and other empire-building RTS games.


I have logged hundreds of hours on the disk version. The steam version makes it easy for me to carry this game wherever I go without having to bring disks. The only difference (and problem) I have found between the disk and Steam versions is Steam removed a lot of accesory files from the game's files, such as .exe's for vanilla Civ3 and Civ3PTW expansion. Otherwise, I have noticed little difference.

review:
No est√° nada mal, aunque la IA no sea de lo m√°s excepcional sirve para pasar un buen rato. Se echa de menos un tutorial, te ponen en mitad del mapa y debes ir investigando como se juega o en su lugar leyendo los consejos. La historia de las naciones es muy acertada, aunque hist√≥ricamente hay aspectos que se podr√≠an mejorar, las animaciones de los l√≠deres de cada naci√≥n tambi√©n se podr√≠an mejorar, ya que muchos de ellos no coinciden con los retratos recogidos en dicha √©poca, la mayor√≠a son caracterizados por estereotipos, algo que en muchos casos dista mucho de la realidad.

Se echa de menos la traducci√≥n al espa√±ol, votar√≠a negativo solo por esto, pero en este caso no lo hare, al ser una edici√≥n digital y no una f√≠sica como la que se comercializo en espa√±ol, la empresa del juego debe llegar a un acuerdo con la que lo public√≥ en espa√±ol para que les den los derechos de dicha traducci√≥n, normalmente esto es un proceso dif√≠cil y muchas empresas ni se molestan, y menos cuando es un juego de hace tanto tiempo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040694833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3257, 'last_played': 1654745076}
review:
Easily the best version of Civ, old or new. One of my all time favorites. Steam tracks my playtime now, but I promise that from childhood to today, I've lost track of how much I've played this game. So many different strategies, so many cultures, and so many ways to play it. The messed up part is I've only scratched the surface, and I'm still not THAT good at the game. Even on the lowest difficulty, it's a challenge. If you're into strategy games, this is THE strategy game. If you're new to strategy games, start here.

My only major criticism is that it's hard to learn. Later sequels have better tutorials, and I still learn things about this game to this day. Take that as you will.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1503058300}
review:
Tags: TBS - Turn Based Strategy
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri is a more interesting early Civilization game. While Civ IV and onwards all outshine this.

Some people say the game have technical issues, some say the mechanics have issues. I'll be honest I dont care. My problem is mostly that if I am going that far back in the Civ Series, I will keep going to Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri and have a much more immersive and pleasant experience there. Otherwise for the vanilla caveman to space age Civ I would rather play a newer iteration than this

author: {'steamid': '76561198185418747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 3244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1646, 'last_played': 1505557572}
review:
This is a newbie and an idiot's perspective of Civ 3, so get ready for a lot of... well, newbie and idiot stuff and more complaints than anything about a game released 16 fucking years ago. 

Before Civ 3 I'd never played a Civilization game, but would become curious periodically as to what they were about. I couldn't afford Civ 4, 5, or 6, so I bought the one I could. 

And... I'll be honest. I cannot beat the game even with all the settings set as low as they can go with 1000 turns, etc etc. I just can't get through the tech tree fast enough to keep up, I can send an entire army after a city and come back with maybe 2HP knocked off someone in the city, and not know what the hell I'm doing wrong. If you're new to Civilization, I would pick up a different version. 

There's also an issue with the sound; rather than playing a music track when I encounter someone else, the game glitches  with its music tracks and blasts my ears with something fucking awful. High pitched electronic squeaks that absolutely destroy my ears and concentration, possibly leading to me making deals I regret with the civilizations I encounter. This is less a "I'm stupid as hell but don't want to look up a guide" issue and more of an actual issue with the game, or perhaps my sound card is too advanced.

That all said, it's not the kind of shit that makes me want to give up on Civ 3. I still enjoy playing it, and I think others would, too. I likely just need some guidance about what strategies are good ideas for which civilizations, or which one will fit my playstyle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198346639376', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 24146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 34, 'playtime_at_review': 3723, 'last_played': 1710015689}
review:
Pros-
Graphics are Good. Even though it came out in 2001.
Comes with Alot of maps and can be randomly generated too. Example (UK Map, World Map)
There is mods out for the game here is the link - https://www.civfanatics.com/civ3/downloads/
The price of the game is $5 which is pretty good asking price. 
There is an Editor so that you can create your own map or scenerio.

-Mixed (Depends on perspective.)
The turns are pretty long for me at late game if I play on Huge Map. It would take 30 seconds to minute to go through in later stages of the game.

When you download the game you have to manualy set the resolution in the files to 1080p  which would only take a minute. You can find a tutorial online.

The game is less complex compared to CIV 4 or CIV 5. For example you can't edit the details of your goverment like you can in CIV 4 and there is no religion system like civ 4.

Con-
Not really anything I can pinpoint right now.


My Recomendation- You should get if you want a simple turn based strategy game. It's only $5 USD. Also when the game goes on sale it would go down to around 2.50 to 3 dollar range.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990637751', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 7101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2687, 'last_played': 1647026172}
review:
I played Civilization V and Civilization IV, but for some reason I keep getting back to Civilization III.
It is a masterpiece that stands the test of time. It is more realistic and fun with huge maps. No religion, but best Nuclear Weapons, artillery mechanic, interface is great for me and Civilopedia is the best out of all Civilizations for me. Clear and Plain to understand.
Easy game to play, yet it is harder to master.
Advisors and Leaders change clothes, depending on which era it is. Interface is more "realistic" looking and not too cartonish as the newer ones. Music is outstanding.
A lot is early on about how much you expand, but it is also much easier to get steam rolled by opponents if your cities are not defended. Sometimes less better cities is more productive and efficient. Maps play a big role, and the map editor is amazing.
Diplomacy I found the most realistic of all. World war scenario can happen very quick with mutual protections. 
Never attack anyone however with open borders, they will hate you pretty much forever, lol.
If you are not the leading in technology you can still sell them to the one that have none. If you have a technology noone has, sell it to everyone (Like worldmaps) in the same turn. Extra money is great.
Governments are a very good mechanic too. Made no sense to me Civilization IV Police State with free speech.

I recommend this game to all lovers of strategy, history and nostalgic gamers.

Edit. P.S. Ignore my steam play hours, I have probably more than a thousand.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036388574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3290, 'last_played': 1689380078}
review: I have far more hours than is visible on Steam, I would estimate over 1,000. This game was my jam as a child, and hooked me on civilization/city builder games. While it's not perfect (controls aren't as intuitive as the newer versions, and sometimes the RNG in combat seems quite off), it is a ton of fun. Between making your own modifications and various mods I obtained in the past, there is always a new game to play, or new strategy to try. With the Summer sale especially, I highly recommend this game.

The Bysentean Empire Attacked their citys in the plentiful south side of the war with the Ottomens while America.... Did Absolutely Nonthing since how weak America Was, Its kinda Supriseing how they didnt fall, the Bysiteam empire send troops to their citys to capture while the ottomen were like screw it, we dont need more citys we just need them out, lets just  Send Bomber Planes and send a few ships to other cities to bombard, The Sumerians were out numbers and were to weak to stop them and the south is the worlds most plentiful resource of the war so the Sumerians Signed a Treaty for peace to End World War 1

author: {'steamid': '76561197972446074', 'num_games_owned': 1171, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 80016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3779, 'last_played': 1705730744}
review:
I have probably put more time into this game than any other in my life and can call Civ III one of my all-time favorite games.

Long before Steam was a thing when Civ III was new, I spent a lot of time just playing one more turn.

Although the newer Civ games are great (Civ V, VI), the third will always be a classic to me and the one that turned me into a loyal Civ fan.

The soundtrack for this game was amazing, especially the late game music. Although it sounds very dated now, it is very well done and brings back a lot of memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277508081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1498596397}
review:
2 thumbs up, WAY up! Graphics are becoming dated but the fun isnt. Be aware that you may see a sunrise or two due to the "just a few more turns dilemma"

I've bought this game exactly 4 times for myself. The first copy wandered off to a friend who never got around to returning it and after a while I realized I missed it too much as I walked past the"Gold" CD version that was on sale at my local Frys which was promptly purchased. On to copy number 2, Yay! I've played that for a good long time on both Windows and Linux but finally got tired of slapping in the CD every time I wanted to play for its antiquated copy protection. Along came a Steam sale and I said 'Hello' to copy number 3. This version is slightly different than my "Gold" version (d*mn volcanoes) but still enjoyable as ever. Finally, just like clockwork, right after I bought #3 ran across another sale on that other game site that doesnt have any silly DRM on it in the first place and I was the proud owner of copy number 4. 

Add this :
KeepRes=1
to its own line in your ini file "./Civilization III Complete/Conquests/conquests.ini" to get proper widescreen support (non 4:3 aspect). This line used to be in Civ3PTW.ini but apparently got moved to this file at a later version. Depending on the version you have, this might be somewhere else too....perhaps one more directory down at "./Civilization III Complete/Conquests/Conquests/conquests.ini"

For Linux, see WineHQ for more info on how to get the "squaking" bird sound to stop once it starts. The quick fix is to turn off those sounds in options but slightly less enjoyable as it removes all the environment sounds. The short of what the fix entails is you just have to replace the bird sound file with a silent version which is easy enough to craft using something like audacity.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245711240', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1561596048}
review:
This game is great, but not as great as Civ5. It has pretty dated graphics and the leader animations are just downright ugly by today's standards. Some of the features are a little dated, too, like building roads to increase gold output and, of course, insane unit stacks. The music for the game isn't bad by the high standards of Civ, except the opening track which is so annoying I have to mute my speakers whenever it plays. 
This game, despite some of its dated features, is still a heck of a lot of fun. I relish the dated graphics as a "retro" Civ experience from 2001, and even the constant road-building gives your workers something to do in the later game. The "city view," which disappeared in Civ4, is something that I definitely wish would've been continued, as well as the palace view. It's also nice to be able to pass through civ borders without permission like the city-state borders from civ5, although this will anger the offended nation. I got it for $1.75 on sale and considering that's it the complete edition, it's worth every penny. 
The game is fun, cheap, and has a healthy dose of retro/nostalgic feeling for those who have played the newer Civ games. Considering that you can get this for less than two dollars, I definitely recommend this purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049176302', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 246, 'last_played': 1661059043}
review:
Probably the single game I've spent the most time playing over the course of my entire life. It has always been my favorite Civ since it's the one I grew up with. The music in this game is a really high point for me; each era has its own unique soundtrack that's catchy and interesting. The scenarios from Conquest are all pretty fun.

Of course this game has a huge nostalgia factor for me, so it may not be as good to newer players, but it's a great lightweight, cheaper option for an old computer or someone who wants to try a new take on Civ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162485404', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2472, 'last_played': 1687505200}
review:
This is really a fantastic game for $5.  Tons of strategy, tons of replayability, tons of content, and a GREAT soundtrack.   

This may have been released 16 years ago but I can still play it and it feels just as fun as any other strategy game I've ever played if not more.  This game stood the test of time and it's a great buy if you're looking for a cheap strategy game that can run with the best in terms of gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072076329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3607, 'last_played': 1495134441}
review:
Why, oh why did they have to stick to this stupid isometric view like in C2? What was wrong with clarity of top-down view from C1?

I guess in attempt to make the map look more realistic shape of the land is blurred so much, that it's hard to see where it actually ends. The result is quite opposite than desired, and you can't easily tell what kind of terrain is there, what would the city be covering exactly, etc. Horrible! Mountains look artificial as hell, as well ;) or, no - most of the map looks artificial and flat.
Had to play with the grid visible most of the time, otherwise couldn't see shit. Didn't get used to the grid so switched it off from time to time... and again couldn't see crap.

Other than that, it is quite good Civ game and feels like much refined C2. I liked the concept of visible and expanding borders, rather disliked the idea of culture as a winning factor (yeah right, like this could happen in this dimension), loved the concept of strategic resources and linking cities by roads/harbors/airport to use them. C3 has a good "just one more turn" factor too... but too bad you can't see shit most of the time.

Disliked because you have to choose thumb up or down. Otherwise I would rate 4/10. Not a waste of money definitely, but it doesn't have that magic and simplicity of classic C1.

author: {'steamid': '76561198284807561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1489790651}
review: Despite primitive and relatively dull graphics, Civ III plays great,  and is still fun to play, even with Civ IV a V out. It is fantastic game at a great price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086331531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 11630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3481, 'last_played': 1690752789}
review: This is the best Civilization game on the market, and by far the cheapest. The game isn't cartoony at all with its graphics, and is very easy to understand and progress. There are many different styles to play and win, as most Civilization games do have, but the newer games in the series don't handle this as well with the number of errors and bugs they have in their games, as well as the lack of quality that Civilization III has. This game is a must-own for all strategy gamers, no question about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022107013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1348, 'last_played': 1494537556}
review:
Civilization 4 had the best modability features. Civilization 5 was the most expansive all in all to the entire Civilzation series. Civilization 6 looks promising, but it has a ways to go before it's fully expanded (which I don't think all the whining over is warranted. Civ 5 came out in 2010, Gods and Kings came out in 2012, and Brave New World came out in 2013).

But Civilization 3 is probably my favorite out of the series because of how succinct the gameplay is. The userface for each aspect is neat, tidy, and fits in only a few UI pages. It's the way Civilization was meant to be played, IMO: a neat board game too expansive to be Settlers of Catan. I would highly reccomend to anyone who enjoys the Civ series.

review: This is arguably still the best CIv Game. I think Civ 2 seemed to be really good when I tried it but since I haven't played that more than 2 hours I will let you decide if you think Civ 2 is better or not. Anyways Civ 3 has AI which can actually wipe you out and you have to keep trading with the AI constantly on higher difficulty levels to be up to date with the latest technologies. I give this game a solid 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198089930432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 12149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6050, 'last_played': 1622593751}
review:
I bought Civ III from the grocery store. It was in some 10 dollar PC game dump, and I saw the holy grail standing out. I picked it out and never saw anything like it. Had to beg my mom for it. That was 2004. Played it for years off and on, trying to learn everything about Civ III will drive you mad. Little did I know there was a complete edition with so much more content. 


Civ III Complete is the best Civ game. The game concepts are way ahead of it's time, and the way you have to manage you're Civ matters more than any soldier. Just opening the game and reading the Civ-pedia will leave you speechless with history lessons. I learned alot just by reading in-game. 

If you love prior Civ games before III, I reccomend you pick up this game and enjoy the good old days of Civ. This is the high point in Civ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004011207', 'num_games_owned': 241, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1580878755}
review:
When they rebuilt this game for use on modern computers, they -must- have adjusted the code in other ways as well.
There is no other reason why, on the second easiest difficulty, I have lost 28 games in a row due to the AI having massive troops, every Wonder, hordes of cities, and all this faster than I can build, no matter what I focus on.

If I try for city sprawl, the AI builds them faster than I do, and still somehow has enough time to also field a more advanced army because it's tech is better.
If I try for tech, the AI outruns me due to having many more cities feeding it's research.
If I go for military, the AI again has better tech, and more cities feeding the military.

Playing this feels a lot like the original Reach For The Stars game, where the developers outright state the game cheats in it's own favor.

I own the disks for the original game.  I used to play this, and beat it, on much harder difficulties all the time.
I refuse to believe the transition to new computers is responsible for the stupidly hard difficulty by itself.  Not on a turn based game.   Ergo, someone screwed with the code and refuses to admit it.

review:

-Declare war.
-Destroy all but 3 of their cities.
-Offer peace in exchange for all the gold in their treasury and New Orleans.
-They accept.
-Peace.
-2 turns later capture their second-last city.
-Offer peace in exchange for all their gold.

-My mechanized infantry roll into Atlanta and are greeted by Spearmen and Archers.
10/10 would be bully again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995714610', 'num_games_owned': 1278, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1532585983}
review:
Having been a Civilization player since Civnet (yes I am old) this game was a surprise to me when it was first released by infogames in 2000 mind you we had just seen a year of 3 civ games due to legal work arounds etc etc. those being Civilization: call to power (Don't recommend at all) Civilization II Test of Time (pretty much a upped graphics version of Sid Meier's Civilization II with additional scenarios which I still recommend) and Sid Meier's Alpha Centari (AMAZING GAME)

but back to CIv III. The game was a nice upping the ante of Civ II and hitting all of its marks it aimed for including its amazing play the world expansion which allowed a relatively stable way to play multiplayer that CivNet tried and failed to do and Civilization II attempted with its Multiplayer gold expansion)

While I have poured countless hours in to my Disk copy I haven't really touched it since mid way through the life span of Civ IV. but I do still get requests to play multiplayer so it still does have a decent following.

10/10

review:
The game is great itself, but there are couple of flaws, that spoil the pleasure:
- random civilization pick always take same seed, as a result you always have same set of civs
- sounds are bugged
- some buldings does not shown on city view
I contacted tech support, and they told, that will not spend time on this game.
This is no surprise, as it is old.
Still, I spent a lot of hours in this game and enjoyed it a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035477363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1515816927}
review:
Like every Civ , Civ III is easy to start playing, surprisingly deep, full of interesting choices, and creates a feeling of wanting to play just one more turn that makes it hard to stop! Though Civ III's age shows in its graphics and interface, the gameplay feels timeless. Civ III also stands apart from other versions of Civ.  I played countless hours of the base Civ III game many years ago, and even after playing the quite different games Civ 4, 5, and 6, Civ 3 keeps its addictive allure.  

Community mods also make Civ III an even better value. 

Civ III also runs on almost any computer, so It's a great game for a low powered laptop or tablet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043972532', 'num_games_owned': 1020, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 4942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4890, 'last_played': 1501351899}
review:
Firaxis certainly tried their best to make every title in their series feel unique. In fact, this is probably the oldest Civ that aged well, and does not require you actually being around, when it was the most recent, to enjoy it. Also noticeably more monotonous than successors.

Civ3 is good, yada yada, game of my childhood, yada yada, but buy only if Civ5 and 4 are not for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147515986', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1576466614}
review:
Where do I begin? Civilization III is in my opinion, the last, true civ game. Yes I know there are many more sequels, but from civ 4 onwards, the game begins to turn into a strategy game of sorts. It is Civ 1-3 that TRULY give you the feeling of an emperor over a fledling empire. 

This game is not to be missed out on if you are a fan of the Civilization franchize, especially if you want to go back to one of the classics. Civ 5 & 6 are really good in my opinion, but Civ 3 REALLY TRULY steals the show.

For less than what a coffee at starbucks costs, GO BUY IT ALREADY!!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198111277333', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1487875818}
review:
Originally I had some crashes with this game version (Steam), but managed to fix it. The info is at the end of the review. Civilization III Complete was one of the games I spent the most time with, and really enjoyed it. For me, it's easily one of the best 4X games ever made (at least in the time I type it).

If you did not play Civilization 3 in the past and are wondering if you should buy it - below is some basic info that should encourage you to do that.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
The pluses:

+ Lots of civilizations, each plays differently

+ Lots of different units + special military unit for each civilization

+ The AI scripts are demanding (unlike in most modern games)

+ Resources on map force you to play strategically

+ Depending on the size and type of the maps, games might differ quite a lot

+ You can play in really big maps

+ The game has fine mods that you can find on the internet

+ It's hard to stop playing it

------------------------------------------------------
The minuses:
- It's hard to stop playing it

- At higher difficulties the military victory is the most viable option (only)

- When you control most of the map it's just boring killing of the remaining weaklings

- At the industrial age, you probably control most of the map

- At higher difficulties AI is cheating

- Civilizations are not balanced (some are really good, some - really bad)

- After you learn to use workers and diplomacy, it's not that hard (but still fun)

- Old 2D game, so in native desktop resolution units and fonts might be too small

- Old 2D game, so in native game resolution units might be too big (and no widescreen)

======================================

For native desktop resolution in game:

1. Go to the Conquests folder in your Civ 3 folder conquests.ini
2. Put "keepRes=1" in conquests.ini file (without "")

======================================

Those settings should fix crashes in Windows 7 64 bit.

1. Go to the Conquests folder in your Civ 3 folder
2. Rename LSANS.FOT to -LSANS.FOT

If that does not help:
Set Windows compatibility to Windows XP Service Pack 2 and run program as administrator.

If the game runs too slow delete keepRes=1 from ini file (in Windows XP mode the game is slower)

======================================

That's it. You can now go buy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051428193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1600821945}

author: {'steamid': '76561198108235797', 'num_games_owned': 4056, 'num_reviews': 550, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1501694875}
review:
Don't understand what people are whining about.
Of course this game is old, so what? Old is gold (generally, not always, but certainly most of the time).
Would I say that it is better than Civilization V? Yes and no, both has their forces and their weakness and I am certainly not talking about the graphics because I do love the graphics in this game, call me crazy, I prefer the graphics you find in this game than those in Civilization V, it's simple but beautiful, old school some would say.

In my opinion, Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, Civization III and Civilization IV are the best in the Civilization series.
Then you have Civilization V and Civilization II.

Beyond Earth isn't that good, far too little content.


If you love Civilization but haven't played this one, you'll probably love it!
If you're looking for a fantasy civilization then you should give a look at Warlock and Eador which are the closer ones to this series, there are some other such as Age of Wonders but it has its differences, lot of them.

9.2/10

review:
While I do recommend this game, be aware there's a bug that disables you to choose another game limit when starting a new game. This means you're stuck with the default 540 turns limit, which is really annoying. I'm guessing this is a Steam-related bug which I found articles about in the forum dating back to 2010. Clearly, it was never fixed.
Real shame... it is a good game despite its age.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132557116', 'num_games_owned': 121, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1484968879}
review: I'm sorry, but the game is way too buggy, and super slow when playing with others. I was in a multiplayer game with one other person, and we only got to 640 AD after playing for 3 hours straight. Also, as I retired in anger, the game crashed as I tried to close it. Also, unit stacking is possibly the worst feature the Civ series has ever had. You order your units to move, and they move one... by one... by one... until you are in your coffin, 600 years later, and you finally get that last spearman over. Speaking of units, these cities keep on making military units, past your limit, and you are soon in civil disorder because of money. Money should never be a problem in a Civ game, ever! I'd hate to give this game a bad review, as Civilization is one of my favorite game series(es?) of all time. Please, save your five dollars and use it on something else. May I suggest: save 25 more of those dollars for Civ 5? Or, you know, any other game?

review:
Recommended because it's so cheap. Yeah, the game's old and flawed (and not totally stable), but it's still good fun as well. Even if you only play through a few games, at this price it's still worth it. Go ahead and give it a shot.

The one exception to this would be if you're used to playing Civ 4, in which case the issues from this game that that one fixed might be too frustrating for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153166666', 'num_games_owned': 705, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 84, 'playtime_at_review': 1608, 'last_played': 1709797937}
review: What can i say about this version of Civilization? I've played Civ 5 - Brave New World for possibly thousands of hours, and i still go back to Civ 3, another game i've probably played for thousands of hours. Still highly addictive, incredibly difficult and a lot of fun. Very crude, in relation to the newer iterations of the game, but also, stripped from bullsh*t like annoying audio readings ("The meek shall inherit the earth but not it's mineral rights" - yes, i've heard you before! - and what does that even mean?!). You still get a sense of a fully realized game by the end of each game, as is the same with other iterations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014163253', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1484172745}
review:
[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete is a turn based strategy game developed by Firaxis Games and released Oct 30, 2001.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=839645517

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] The "Story" is more so in the individual experience you have playing these types of games. You're put into a random world with random NPC's (unless you try to determine the world and nations by selecting them...) the key defining elements are how you interact with the game's NPC's.

My personal story is I kept to myself, and then people started threatening me, and I'm not going to take any of that from easy difficulty NPC's, so they declared war on me and I fought them until the game ended. [i](Maybe this is why other Nations always think I'm a war monger... but I swear the other guys almost always starts it! ..I just finish it.)[/i]

[b]Gameplay:[/b] I've played Civilization Call to power, and I've played Civilization 4... Civilization 3 is different then both, but difficult to articulate how it's different... the game feels slower paced, I can't wage war as effectively by bombardment as I can in civ call to power or civ4.
The game just hasn't clicked with me in the way Civ5 did immediately. the User interface has a serious case of the 2000's [i](by that, I mean overly complicated, overly difficult, rather confusing.)[/i]

There are scenarios and tons of special mod or DLC packs which are included in Civ3. If you're looking to burn some time playing a strategy game, Civilization 3 can easily eat up that time with the crazy amounts of content it has.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] The dilemma I have with Civ3, is that I prefer Civ5, and Civ call to power... but that doesn't mean Civ3 is bad... it's quite good and chalk full of content. Especially for the low price... But while playing I just find myself thinking "man, I'd rather be playing Civ5".

I think it's nice to have Civ3 as a backup for my laptop when I'm on trips, or for a new/old challenge. [i](It's a new challenge because I haven't played it as much, but it's an older game... BAH, don't think about it)[/i]

review:
My first Sid Meier game honestly and I must say it's actually really fun. 

Now, it didn't run perfectly on my computer, not entirely sure why as everytime I attacked, I COULDN'T SEE THE FIGHT MY COMPUTER JUST FROZE FOR TEN SECONDS AND THEN IT WAS OVER... but I digress, I got over that pretty quick and there was still a lot to do. So much land to conquer and claim as my own. 

A classic, what can I really say that's different from what most have already stated?

Fan of the Civ games? Try it. 

New to the name Sid Meier? Try it. 

Want to conquer the world? Try it.

review:
Before I got this game on steam, I played it for 100s of more hours.  It's one of the best Civ games.

Basically Civ 1 done right with better graphics.  Civ 2 was messed with.  Civ IV while good lost most of the strategy that was in Civ III.  Civ V is just bad:  No unit stacking, no city view, no love.  I haven't played VI yet, so I would say Civ 3 is either the best Civ game or the 2nd best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114186986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1483112318}
review:
Want to change history, dominate the World, rule as a dictator and have fun while while doing so. Than this is your game. Sid meier's Civilization iii offers players variety of choices to shape customise and dominate all other civlizations through out the game. A worthy sequel to the original civilization games, the makers of this game has outdone themselves. 

The game has no rigidiry of storyline as mentioned, there is an innovative tech tree which makes sense, there are plenty of civilizations to choose from, whats more is that the Worlds are randomly procedurally generated. Every time you do some thing worth while within the game you get to create an improvetment to your palace. Which is also neat.

To be faor there are many positives to this game and relatively no negetives. But to name a few:-

Positives

1.The game is easy on the pockets
2.The game can be played by players of any age
3.The game has a neat set of ingame rewards which makes playing it worthwhile

Negetives

1. The game ends abruptly after reaching a certain technology

All in all the game for presentabiltys sake is 7/10. A ghreat game for the entire family to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028643519', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1495232694}
review: So first off I'm going to start by saying even though it might show about an hour or so of playtime it does not mean I have not played this game before. I first came across this game at GameStop and I really hadn't played any games since I was young. But I needed a past time because I was dying of boredom being at home laid up in bed unable to do much. I had severely injured my back and I wasn't going to work anytime soon and the depression started to kick in. So anyways by now the game had been out for about 3 years and it looked interesting so I bought it. Went home and started playing it and it was my first time playing a strategy game so I didn't even know if I was going to like it. I started playing around lunch time by the time I know it was dinner time so took 10 minutes got my food and came back and ate while I played. By the time I knew it was freaking 6am the next day! I had never had lost track of time by that much, but man was I enjoying the game. I thought the graphics were pretty decent, the game play was very good and the UI was also good. Of course it was the first time I've had played a game with an in game Civilopedia and I thought that was awesome. The other thing I miss from Civilization III that has not been added to any other Civilization since is building your capital building when your citizens were happy you were able to add one section at a time until you finished upgrading your building. I thought that was fun, even though it was a very simple and quick thing. By the time Civilization IV came out I had around 3500 hours invested in this game and I still have the original disk I bought, but I went ahead and bought it on Steam because they had a very good deal on Civ III, IV and Colonization which I already have the other two also. But I want to keep those disks from getting any damage and besides Steam keeps a running track of your gaming time. So I can safely say this game is what got me back into gaming and becoming a full time gamer. I DO RECOMMEND THIS GAME, EVEN THOUGH IT'S AN OLDER GAME. Keep gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020972314', 'num_games_owned': 869, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 4421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3822, 'last_played': 1616311110}
review:
Civilization has been one of the main cornerstones of the 4X genre since its first entry in the 90s. I grew up playing tons of Civilization II until my brother got a copy of Civilization III for Christmas, and I've loved it ever since.

PROS:
+Grand strategy based on ruling an empire and balancing multiple facets including your militaristic, economic, industrial, scientific, and diplomatic agendas.
+Impressive number of Civilizations to play as (over 30), each with its own advantages and disadvantages.
+Despite the number of potential Civilizations, each plays with its own distinctive style.
+More peaceful options to win than spaceship-building.
+Numerous scenarios (or Conquests) including WWII in the Pacific, Sengoku-era Japan, Pre- and Post-Columbus America, and the Rise and Fall of the Roman Empire.
+Abnormally good soundtrack.
+Difficult to master, like many good strategy games.
+Introduces new game mechanics over its predacessor like war weariness, forced labor, and corruption.
+Included is a Scenario-maker, which is very comprehensive and allows for the addition of entirely-new civilizations, technologies, and maps.
+There's many of the popular fan-made maps and scenarios already installed with the game.
+Mods! (on CivFanatics)

CONS:
-Loses some of the character from Civilization II (such as wonder movies, animated high councils, and "Our words are backed with NUCLEAR WEAPONS!")
-Doesn't run as well on modern machines. I've had game crashes on the Victory Screen, but I've heard of people not even being able to start the game.
-Tutorial hints hidden in the Preferences menu, so unless you've played Civilization II or IV, this one's pretty hard to learn. Other Civilizations (including this game's direct predacessor) automatically turned on the hints if played on the lowest difficulty, or had menus for learning the game.

Personally, it's my favorite of the grid-based Civilizations, and I always come back for more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254332308', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3348, 'last_played': 1528859653}
review:
All right. I got this game from a friend sometime around 2012, I think. I played it for a bit but honestly, I had trouble getting into it. A lot had changed from Civilization II and I never really caught on to all the differences.

Picked it up during the Steam Black Friday sale on Thanksgiving. I gave it a whirl. At first, I had the same feelings I did last time I played all those years ago. It wasn't CivII, and the strategies that worked for me then were failing me now. It didn't help that there wasn't a tutorial or a manual of any kind, and the Civilopedia is not the most user-friendly interface, although it's critical to understanding all of the game mechanics the AI employs.

I played on Chieftain for a while, just trying to get a handle on the game mechanics, but now I'm bored of chieftain. Too easy. Once you learn and begin to understand the game mechanics, this is a pretty great game. That said, it's virtually impossible to win if you don't constantly expand and build one city after another. I mean, that is all you will do. Build and build and build. If you don't, the AI will and you'll lose. Pretty much the only way to win is to begin building a ton of cities in the early parts of the game.

I did like the implementation of cultural borders, and how borders clash against one another. The cultural conversion tool was also pretty cool, where cities could rebel and join your forces because they realized that their own culture was lifeless. So it's a pretty good game, and definitely worth the price for my 46 hours (and growing).

I do have to say, though, that a couple of the leader choices are really dumb. Mahatma Gandhi was not a leader of the Indian nation. Although he championed the move for India's independence, making him the face of India is weird, because he was a guru and not a general. And Jeanne d'Arc leading the French? She was a teenager and a peasant who, by her own confession, never even used her sword in combat. They could have chosen Charlemagne or Napoleon Bonaparte, but Joan! Kinda silly!

author: {'steamid': '76561198286549399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1503275893}
review:
Still as good of a game as I remember it from my childhood, it's age shows a little, but for $5 (and potentially even less) it still provides that "one more turn" mentality. I probably sunk at least 200 hours into my local libraries copy, so when I saw it was on steam, it was a no brainer purchase.

Having played Civ 5, I have to say that the portraits of the rulers convey far more emotion, at least in my eyes, than the full set pieces of Civ 5. The barbarians have multiple AI options and can be absolutly brutal. Certain civilzations have certain traits which affect what actions trigger golden ages. You get to upgrade your palace in a way that actually changes the way it looks on the city screen. Also there is a city screen where you get a detailed overview of your city and all the wonders you built. As opposed to Civ 5's jam packed 3D model of your city.

Age helps, in a way, since with todays operating systems the turns are lightning fast, even with troop movement.

I know I have my nostagia blinders on, but I really like this game, despite whatever flaws I cannot see. I suspect that anyone who likes these kinds of games and doesn't mind the lack of 4k graphics, will definitely get their money's worth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034329440', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1692925012}
review: My hours played do not reflect my time on this game, because I had it long, long before it was out on Steam.  What game could better deserve the 'Test of Time' award (except, perhaps, Civ 2: Test of Time, but that's not on Steam).  Civ 3 has a timeless appeal that will bring old players back, and give new players (who, perhaps, have played a more recent Civ) a look at the glorious history of the series.  The beginnings of National Wonders, the Worker/Settler split, rivers on tile borders, rather than on tiles.  All these and more began with Civ 3.

You'll need to spend a little effort getting it to display in a modern resolution, but it's totally worth it.

You could be forgiven for thinking Civ V is the best Civ, but III is where it's at!
Beautiful 2.5D graphics that still hold up today, legendary soundtrack and insanely addictive gameplay.
For the price Steam have it at it's a steal!

So don't delay, build the Prymiands in Gettysburg today!

review: Still the best Civ game after all these years. I only wish firaxis would return to the model set by this game including the stacking of units, the single tile cities, the awesome full control easy to use GUI editor, etc.... The Civ series has consistently declined in quality since Civ3, culminating with the current Civ 6 release although the biggest jump down was from 3 to 4 where most of the features were removed to allow them to be slowly introduced in future upgrades and DLCs for the following games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104425330', 'num_games_owned': 645, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2502, 'last_played': 1684980388}
review:
Civilization III is one of my long-time favorites. It's fairly complex, very interesting, (from a historical standpoint). The graphics still look quite appealing, even after 15 years. 

The only advancements I've noticed in modern Civ games include, religion, more complex foreign policy, and better AI. I should also mention multiplayer, as the multiplayer aspect of this game died with Game Spy, unless you were to organize a game with friends.

This is still a great game that I would reccomend to fans of the Strategy genre of games, and, I know this is being overused of recent, but I believe, this is truly a game that stands the test of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035472795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1271, 'last_played': 1426724797}
review: Maybe its nostalgia, or maybe it still stands the test of time. But there's a reason my childhood was spent on this game. The GOAT of Civ and turn based 4X.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136293575', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 51725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 14, 'playtime_at_review': 10735, 'last_played': 1710781009}
review:
I have played a lot of Civ games, from Advanced Civilizations on DOS all the way up to the brand new Civ VI. And this is still my favorite of all of them. It is definitely not the prettiest or most user-friendly civ game, but its grit and punishing difficulty (at the higher settings) give it a realism lost in a lot of the newer Civ games.  That being said the game is a huge leap foward from a lot of its easier counterparts, though it's still not as difficult at Advanced Civilizations, you don't need to mount your C:/ Drive to play it and there is a manual... Stupid RNG no explanation Civil Wars...

Anyway, long story short:
If you are new to the Civilization Franchise I might recommend starting with  Civ V, its an easier more friendly game. That being said, if you are a veteran of the franchise or of the strategy genre, Civ III will give you a more difficult, more immersive, and more brutal experience, and is well worth the $1-$5 it costs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067504589', 'num_games_owned': 751, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1794, 'last_played': 1630240571}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001608620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2038, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1666, 'last_played': 1520126105}
review:
Despite this game's age, despite all the other versiona that have come out since, despite all the time I sink into all of those newer versions, I still come back to this one.

Civilization III is my personal favorite of the entire Civilization franchise, from Civ I to Civ VI, Alpha Centauri and Beyond Earth. For me, this game has truly withstood the test of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157724691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 6156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4374, 'last_played': 1556477954}
review:
Picked this up during a Steam sale a while back. I'd never really been a fan of 4X titles. This game single-handedly changed that:

Pros:
[1] Simple intuitive user interface
[2] Loads of custom maps and scenarios to play out
[3] Loads of civilizations to try out with each feeling slightly different from the others

Cons:
[1] Management of units becomes tedious during last game
[2] Competent but passive AI in lower difficulty settings

A definite must have in any strategy collection.... And it still stands the test of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039465067', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 115326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61200, 'last_played': 1708125551}
review:
Bought it on Steam for nostalgia-reasons.. It's the game that got me hooked on the "Civilization" series. Old but gold.
Civilization IV and V added a lot of great stuff, but also removed some parts i really liked.

Over the years, some awesome and still very playable mods and scenario's came out for this game as well
from Civfanatics i strongly recommend:
- Escape From Zombie Island (both 1 & 2)
- Hegemon! Of the Classical Greek World!
- Age of Imperialism

author: {'steamid': '76561198052520532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2408, 'last_played': 1708710158}
review:
Dart like loading speed and complex stratergy makes this game the best game I have every played and at ~¬£3 (marked down to ~75p at the time of this review) what is not to like. The graphics aren't even noticably early 2000's (I actually had to check that it was released in the early 2000's for this review). This game is as great now as it was when released. I'd give it 10/10 and 
[b]I nominated this game for the test of time award.[/b]
especialy the tukmans test of time mod.
:-)

author: {'steamid': '76561197976999134', 'num_games_owned': 3248, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1668, 'last_played': 1362470400}
review:
I became a PC gamer because of this game. Got it the Gold edition. Took forever to get conquests expansion. I still enjoy playing those scenarios. This game has a ton of micromanagement but still less than a lot of other 4x games. Easy to learn, difficult to master. It still holds up well. Cheap, fun, and runs on anything. Good to play on my laptop when travelling.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198079850941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1479876609}
review:
It's an honest game.
Abe Lincoln contacted me and said "Pay me 140 gold and we will have continued world peace.."
Paid the gold and 3 turns later, America forms an alliance against me and declairs war, when Im just mind my own business farming in my fields. 

9/10 - Would fall for Lincolns lies again

author: {'steamid': '76561198060025462', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1668785743}
review:
There is nothing more satisfying than watching your humble little settlement, turn into a continent wide superpower, with huge armies and nuclear arsenals. A "quick" game of Civ, you tell yourself. Then, next time you look out of your window, the sun is coming back up and you're late for work/school.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198057258683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1479568485}
review:
Yesterday my friend asked me how to beat AI at level 4, then I began to start to remember that is already a very long time when I played CIV3. Middle school, together with my brother and my best friends. We have talked a lot with this game and how it gonna to be. Some are already in CIV4,5,6 realized, but some maybe never. I remembered so many good stuff and decided to play again. However I can't any more. I have forgotten everything about techs and tricks how should I develop, and very soon, war was declared.

It is classic, it is epic, but it is already history. I buy this for my pirated version in the past when I was young. And then is the time to say good bye.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043399596', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1479177223}
review:
Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization III is a 4x strategy game, that means the objective of the game is to eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate to win. First off, the game takes some time to get the hang of the concept, but it also just takes time to play. A game could last anywhere from 30 minutes to multiple years. I first read the manual for the game which did help out. It told me of keyboard shortcuts that I never actually used. It also explained to me the basics of the game so when I started my new game I wasn‚Äôt completely lost. (This is coming from somebody who hasn't played any strategy games.) The first 30 minutes of my first game I wasted my turns walking around then finally building a city. I played as the Iroquois, they are proficient in agriculture, though I started producing warriors and getting very aggressive. My neighbors killed me and within an hour my first game was over. My second game ended much quicker, within 30 minutes my tiny city was captured. I felt very lost within the first turns of my first game. I felt the game didn‚Äôt do a very good job explaining what to do. I just felt a desire to discover the dark parts of the map because it didn‚Äôt look very good to me. However, I did find the advisors that would pop up and tell me information that I found very useful and helpful. In this way the game was able to help me assimilate myself with it‚Äôs complicated mechanics. 
One interesting mechanic in the 4x strategy game is its robust diplomacy system. There are many treaties, alliances, trade opportunities, agreements to be made, and wars to be waged. On my current playthrough I am a militaristic expansionist Roman empire I encountered the Aztecs and began fighting a war with them.  Upon seeing the I could overthrow them the Aztecs asked for a peace treaty which I agreed to. From there on out the Aztec and I created a rite of passage where we would be able to cross each other's land. However, I plan on expanding cities and surrounding them then I will take over their cities and kill them. This diplomacy system is a major part of my strategy to win the game. This will play a consequential role of my playthrough of this game. 
In general I have never been a big fan of strategy games, however I did find myself enjoying this game to a certain extent. I don‚Äôt expect to be putting too much time into the game anymore, but I can say that my time spent with it has not been all negative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166694681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1659590521}
review:
If you're looking for ludicrous and war-mongering AI, as well as the ability to make your civilization happy without a circus and other buildings that provide happiness, this is the game for you!

In all seriousness, this is a great game. It is 100% worth the $1.24 you pay when it goes on sale! It is very easy to manage your cities' happiness and production! With Civ III, you can que production items, unlike Civ V, which makes the game enjoyable. As well as allows you to have very productive cities. The way it makes that aspect of the game more enjoyable is that you don't have to click on the choose production icon every few turns. However, it sometimes likes to just switch to needless outdated military units after it runs out of production items in a que. Another nice feature of this game is the selecting how you want your game to be set up. It allows you to choose how old the earth is when you start the game. As well as has a few more features that are absent in Civ 5.

The only cons to this are the aforementioned AI, and playing it on a newer computer. The AI are typically kind of crazy when it comes to deals, and get really annoyed if you decline them. Which typically leads to war with them eventually. I seem to have a problem where the AI all declare war with me. Also, the AI expand their civilizations really fast, so if you buy this, make sure to settle as many cities as possible in the beginning of the game! Although that really applies to any Civ Game. Finally, Civ 3 seems to run too fast on newer computers, and it will skip through some animations. 

Other than that, this is a really great game! Especially when it is slightly more expensive than a pack of gum!

author: {'steamid': '76561198168829366', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 3654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 93, 'playtime_at_review': 2395, 'last_played': 1709852975}
review:
If you're looking for a Civilization game try either Civ IV or Civ V, both are better than this.

The combat feels too random and the AI seems to be overly aggressive (Something is wrong when someone like Gandhi demands tribute and refusing makes them declare war on you.) The AI also is very expansionist, creating new cities whenever it can.

I found no tutorial, so I had to learn how to play the game myself through trial and error.

On the bright side, it comes with its own scenario editor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157119708', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3983, 'last_played': 1701859678}
review: Personally this is my favorite turn based strategy. The game is playable for anybody and is very addicting if a person likes to be in control of things. What I like the most, is ability to grow really big, to name stuff as one wants and to play on real World maps. Editor is really simple btw. AI is kind of not really good, but it's challenging on high levels due to bonuses to AI. Also, there is a city count limit on a map which is 512 I think and the game has kind of built in minimal turn waiting time. I have tested this with some members on the community, and it seems that game code doesn't allow for faster operation, regardless of PC hardware one is using. No matter what CPU/RAM/GPU one has, two very powerful cores or 8 core CPU (since the game utilizes only one core by default), the speed of the slowest turn will be the same. Which is considerable, when you have full map of civs, dip relations and modern units.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140809545', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 24796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7679, 'last_played': 1692419777}
review:
>Installs custom leaderheads
>Playing as Franklin Roosevelt
>Best friends with the democratic nation of Nazi Germany
>Also best friends with the republican nation of The Soviet Union
>Fascist India approaches me with 20 war elephants
>Gandhi declared war on me again o no
>Signs military alliance against Gandhi with every other nation
>World War 1 lasted for 300 years
>Finally peace
>Next turn
>Gandhi declares war again
>Just finished the Manhattan Project
>Every city told to build at least one ICBM
>Gandhi attempts to take a city with War Elephants
>Stopped by a single Rifleman that I haven't upgraded yet
>Ended up nuking India 20 times in one turn
>Somehow wins with the "peaceful" UN victory


10/10 Would promote peace by completely decimating Mahatma Gandhi's empire again

*****

In all seriousness, though, Civ 3 certainly delivers. You'll most definitely have a fun time, with all these hilarious moments appearing left and right.

The advisors actually have a use, and they have expressions, unlike Civ 4 and 5. (The Science Advisor is literally Sid Meier btw)

There's whole government systems as opposed to civics. Means you can't fine-tune your government, but it takes a bit of load off your shoulders if you're not into figuring out what civics you want.

Also, spearman vs. tank scenarios don't happen *that* often. 118 hours in at the time of writing, and RNG hasn't pulled any serious BS on me.

The only real downside that sticks out to me is the loading lag between each turn that builds up late-game when you play multiplayer matches. That isn't too significant, though, since if you can sit through 2 minutes straight of nothing but an AI doing carpet bombing runs on your capital, you can survive an extra 4 seconds of loading time.

This was a wonderful Christmas gift I got from a good friend of mine. I would most definitely buy the game for someone else, too.
I mean, come on -- hours of endless entertainment for only $1.24? How could you resist?

author: {'steamid': '76561198014752703', 'num_games_owned': 271, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1516824752}
review: Civilization is like pizza. It's bad for your health, addictive, has a base of wheat and lots of tasty stuff on top...and most importantly, even when it's bad, it's still pretty good. This is by far the worst of the square grid Civilization games (so it's still better than V will ever be, but so is shooting yourself in the foot with a hexagonal bullet.) If you're seriously considering buying this, go play Civilization IV instead; it's a much better investment of your money and time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086296893', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1075, 'last_played': 1616463363}
review:
Un verdadero juego de estrategia, no es el mas amigable para empezar a entrar dentro de la estrategia para eso ya tenemos AOE que se basa mas en la conquista militar y el uso de recursos para financiar contrucciones y un ejercito, aqui necesitas tener una vision mas amplia de lo que es manejar una civilisacion en ciencia,  cultura, relaciones exteriores y si militar es exigente dentro de la manera de jugar.
No es el mejor juego de la saga e de decir ese es el 5,  pero devo de decir que si es un titulo que se puede jugar y que te mantiene jugando provando las diferentes culturas y estrategias que pudes tomar en tus partidas, lo recomiendo si de verdad eres seguidor de los juegos de estrategia que no solo se basan en aplastar a tu objetivo de manera belica, aunque lo puedes hacer si asi quieres ;).

author: {'steamid': '76561198135497405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1347, 'last_played': 1697420428}
review:
I've played this game since it came out, on and off, over the years.  It's wonderful.  To me, Civ 2 is the archetype.  This one is Civ 2 with a modern look and sensical changes/additions.

This game can be very relaxing but can also be drenched in anxiety and frustration.  The AI cracks me up...  sometimes they feel like real human thinkers but other times they're just barbarian lunatics!

I'm running this thing on a Macbook Pro through CrossOver software.  With a few tweaks, it works great!  Which is amazing because it's the only way I can play the game via my computer.  I also have Civ IV which is also great, but I find myself playing III whenever I feel the urge.
