review:
This is one of my all time favourite games. I spent hundreds of hours playing this when I was younger, and now that I own it again I will be spending many more hours playing it. It is cheap, part of a great series, and just an overall amazing game. It is definitely worth the money.

Update: Been sinking in some more time into the game lately, and other than some random crashes (I have been cheating a bit lol so that's probably the cause) I still have a lot of fun. This game can still easily draw you into the the forever "One More Turn" syndrome. And as we all know, that's only a good thing lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961124823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 4997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4997, 'last_played': 1443102405}
review:
Building on the classic Civilization II, Civ III introduces several new game mechanics including expanding City borders & also for the first time animated units. The player starts off in the year 4000 BC with a small group of settlers and some basic knowledge of road building, irrigation & farming. After choosing the site of their first City the player then has to explore and expand their empire to other locations. The ideal placement of a City would be close to natural resources & luxuries, this will help increase trade, production & happiness of the citizens. Connecting City's via roads also increases trade and the sharing of resources / luxuries across your empire. During the early game roaming Barbarians may cause problems along your borders and any unprotected units or land will be either captured or pillaged. As you progress through the centuries you will eventually meet other Civilizations. Some of these will be friendly and willing to trade, others more hostile and may attack you completely unprovoked. You have the opportunity to influence the opinions of other empires by your actions towards them, giving them gifts or trading technology is usually a way to get on their good side. Later in the game you can also forge an alliance with certain empires in the form of a mutual protection pact. This is especially useful during times of War to help seal victory over your enemies. The game ends in one of six ways, the most traditional being conquest (destroying all opponents). The Space race victory occurs when any Civilization completes and launches a Space Ship to Alpha Centauri. Other victory types are Cultural, Diplomatic & Domination. If the game ends and no one is victorious by any of these, the game uses a "histograph" to determine the winner by points.

This is one of my all time favourite games, though Civ IV has more depth by adding religion, unit promotions and other special abilities. I still prefer this version to any other.

There are no in game options for changing to widescreen resolutions but if you do the following: goto your Steam/SteamApps/Common/Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete/Conquests folder then find the file called conquests.ini. Right click to edit the file then goto the bottom and add the line Keepres=1 this will force the game to your monitors resolution.

review:
Just like all other civilization games it is super fun to play but amazingly annoying in multiplayer mode. It took me nearly a few days at eight hour runs with a friend just to finish a single game. Its far too drawn out to make the game any kind of fun in multiplayer. For this reason its really REALLY annoying even if you waste ten hours or more on a single game in multiplayer you wont even make it half way to the end of the game.

However this game in single player story mode is another game all together you can bust hour a whole game in a single day and boy is it fun in single player but the whole reason most people play this game is to play with friends so if you are after it to play alone this will suck up your time and will be enjoyable but if you are looking to play with a friend. Forget it!

review:

Well, maybe the original Alpha Centauri, but thanks for not having that game or Civ2 available, Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030305825', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 3293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3105, 'last_played': 1586619136}
review:
Best Civilization game in my opinion.
 It has lots of mods, none of the simplistic, casual-like style of the games that came after it, and a relatively good mutliplayer. The art style still retains that design of late 1990's, early 2000's aesthetic. It doesn't try to be cartoony and I love that. Unfortunately later Civ games were less lucky with that.

After more 10 years, here it stood the test of time....

You can't go wrong with the price of it now. All expansions included and no DLC's or anything. A problem that Civ IV, V and VI face. Well worth your money.

 This is a classic strategy game.

The only thing I feel is lacking is the necessity for a full OST in Steam in a downloadble format! The music is amazing. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LYHbIo-WL8c

Update: They made Civilization III's multiplayer work on Steam without Gamespy (since that is now dead). Therefore cannot recommend Civ 3 enough compared.
If only Civ 3 had a remastered version.

review: 6/10, very enjoyable game. Would rate higher but it's very historically inaccurate, racist and a stolen concept. There are too many fictional characters with silly names such as 'Abu Bakr' and 'Shaka' (which is racist because the latter is an African American and they named him Shaka after the character in Land of the Lost). Also, the game is obviously a rip off of Shogun Total War 2, there's even a character called Shogun Tokugawa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001752554', 'num_games_owned': 5789, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 3660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3660, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
The third installment in the Civilization series which is getting pretty old these days, with it's successor Civilization IV and V.  This is another one of those titles that you might have grown up with as a kid and have had nostalgic value to you. This is at least the case for me. I remember that the game took a chocking 700 MB of space on my hard disk and it was generally tanking my late 90's computer. I have sunk a huge amount of hours into this game and for me this is the best game in the series.

Civilization is probably the most dominating Turn-based strategy game in the gaming industry. The Total Wars games for example are RTS/TBS hybrids, while CIV is completely TBS. True Civilization enthusiasts probably rank Civ3 pretty low, compared to Civ2, Civ4 and Civ5 which were very well received for their times. For me however, Civilization 3 is the favorite among the ones I've played (Civ3, Civ4 and Civ5). Again - because of it's nostalgic value.

All Civ games start out the same way unless you play a scenario or campaign. You start off with a settler and a warrior of some sorts. The settler can build a city, and as you find a suitable location for your capital - let your Civilization begin! Beware though, once you have started a game you won't be able to leave for at least 4 hours. This game is honestly best played during the night and is mostly a single-player experience.

There is a Campaign/Scenario mode, where you play historical events or just silly settings. As well as a multiplayer mode, but I have never enjoyed these ones at all. Nothing beats that random map mode, select the terrain, the climate, map size and your opponents/allies. Let the history get rewritten as you choose the path of the righteous, or the path of the tyrant. Through exploding expansion, racing technology, crushing warfare and cunning diplomacy you must stand victor as the one and only dominating superpower.

[b]I only recommend picking this up if you have a personal connection to it, or if you are entirely out of gameplay from modern titles.[/b]

[u]Note: You might want to check out [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/8930/]Civilization V[/url] ([url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/mendozacheers/recommended/8930/]Review[/url]) as it's a modern take to the genre and series.[/u]

author: {'steamid': '76561197993479043', 'num_games_owned': 1097, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1498343579}
review: Civ III may not hold up to Civ IV or Civ V, but Civ III is a great game regardless. It has a wealth of customization that the series is known for, and is my personal favorite in the series. I spent so many hours in this game when it wasn't on Steam. I'd play the same world for what would be milleniums in game time, creating an absolutely massive empire only for Gandhi to nuke it all to dust. It's five dollars, so it's definitely worth the price now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964153663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 246, 'playtime_forever': 16920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10025, 'last_played': 1414318268}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization III, the sequel to the great Civilization II, a game that by some is still to this day considered to be the best of the series, has the heavy duty challenge of not only living up to the standards set by it's predecessors but also to innovate the franchise enough that players of the previous installment can be bothered to upgrade.

It starts out with a somewhat mixed feeling. Some of the great ideas from Alpha Centauri has been brought over creating a much more versatile playing field with a living map and more unique factions but many of Alpha Centauri's greatest assets, such as the ability to build your own units and terrain elevations are notably absent. and others, such as unique factions, are only half implemented.

These improvements however do still manage to increase the interactivity of the game substantially particularly when combined with the many new features, such as culture, that Civ III brings to the table.

Factions are not longer defined simply by their city names but now have a few unique units of little consequence and civilization traits of great consequence. Unique units are simply beefed up versions of regular units that give a faction a small military advantage during the time period in which the unit is present, this can be a nice boost if you happen to go to war in that time but it can also be ignored completely if the time for war is not right. The traits each faction receives now however are of a much greater importance and can range from getting a free technology every age to a half off cost on religious buildings. These traits are big enough in effect that they tend to define your entire game.

A new and important feature in Civ III is culture. Each city generates culture through it's various buildings and the culture in turn defines the size of it's borders. A heavily cultured city can even envelop the city of an opponent and flip it to your side. While the realism or historical accuracy of such a device is laughable at best it does provide players with a new means of expansion and a way to deal with those pesky resource stealing late game cities that the AI is so fond of placing in whatever unoccupied corner of your empire it can find.

Graphically Civilization III is passable as always, the city view is pleasant but the rest of the game gives only a mediocre visual experience. Nothing pretty but nothing that'll ruin your gaming experience either. The soundtrack is still mostly orchestral epics and works very well although the rest of the sound effects in the game are pretty forgettable.

All in all Sid Meier's Civilization III is a good sequel. It doesn't create quite the same feeling of amazement and enjoyment that going from Civ I to Civ II does but it manages to provide a good solid experience with enough innovation to justify the purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052647892', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 48739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36381, 'last_played': 1709071602}
review:
This game would be perfect but for a few really aggravating glitches that ultimately let it down.

I have played this game for years and it still astonishes me now how much the AI will F you up the anal passage if you have got ahead of it, what it will do is the AI will mysteriously get a wonder that they should no shape or form have.  That is one thing that is a massive aggravation.

Then there is the AI has the ability to build mass amounts of settlers, military gear, etc, etc from the start.  Now I am good at this game, played for years and I still can not get archers and defensive units in numbers after a few rounds.  Basically the AI cheats, anyone who says AI and machines do not cheat, hang yourself now before I hang you and it is ultimately this games let down, its only let down is the AI will F you over.  Sure you deal with it, but it is the way the AI goes about it.  It is not subtle in the slightest and as far as I am concerned further proof that computers cheat and have been thinking for themselves for quite sometime.

Because of the massive aggravating glitch F's this game has, it only gets a 6/10.  Sort the glitches out and this is a 10/10 game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038631530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1357459200}
review:
Well I was hoping for a different experience from Civ IV.  I was hoping that Civ IV was that point where the devs went through a 'lets temporarily sell out and fuck up the franchise for a while' phase, but it turns out Civ III is shitty as well.

Okay, it's not as silly as Civ IV.  In may ways, I still despise Civ IV, but I'll admit it's a nitpick.  I'd give it the same rating otherwise, because it's almost the same game.  Civ IV's interpretation of religion is silly.  Read the other review for more about that.

Okay, enough about fucking Civ IV, lets talk about Civ III.  But what is there to talk about really?  I tried to have fun, but it was the dullest 5 hours on chieftain (easiest difficulty) of moving around a bunch of soldiers and workers (that's all this game is, soldiers and workers and building ROADS) with the scandinavian vikings that I used to conquer the Aztec empire (ultimately a game of city tag), while fending off Japanese and Romans, I've ever had.  Eventually, I resigned, because Sumeria was really big, Persia entered a 'golden age', and I had to end it at some point.

There was no way to end this game properly without playing for another 8 hours, and that was a standard size map.  The one thing I sorta appreciated was how the enemy leaders poke fun at you for quitting.  The victory screen scores, such as 'children per family', 'population', and 'average lifespan', are mostly purely for flair and meaningless.  

Final Score - 38/100

author: {'steamid': '76561197960940977', 'num_games_owned': 817, 'num_reviews': 379, 'playtime_forever': 2686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2686, 'last_played': 1338793200}
review:
Hearing good things about this, I tried it for the first time in 2011. I enjoyed it initially; the learning curve was interesting, and I wanted to know how good I could get at it. Some great features stood out, and I even played it with a friend on LAN.

But it being so dated, and lacking modern user-friendly polish that so many development teams easily manage these days, it regretfully doesn't stand up to modern games. I'd spend ages in a match and only realise far into it that I was going to lose, and couldn't see the skill behind doing better next time.

I'd give this one a miss, unless you love RTS turn based games or lost your original disks, since it's cheap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032273592', 'num_games_owned': 581, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1589089073}
review: I didn't give this game a fair try back in the days when it was new.  The game was visually an improvement over Civ II, and the interface was actually functional.  I just felt the combat system was poorly done, diplomacy didn't feel right, and the game has a few design quirks.  Fast forward to now, I decided to buy the complete edition, which updates the game.  What I find now is a game that truly stands between the majesty of Civ II and Civ IV.  The Civ experience is there, and it's well represented.  The graphics haven't aged all that well, and the interface isn't as nice as the later games, but the gameplay remains classic Civ.  The complete edition adds the feature of customizing the game in ways never seen before or again in a Civ game, such as turning down (or up) AI aggression.  It is a good, cheaper entry into the world of Civ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024965497', 'num_games_owned': 495, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2424, 'last_played': 1689828136}
review: The best of the franchise.  I started playing the original shortly after it came out, it blew my mind.  CIV2 made minor enhancements, but was largely the same game.  The first time I played CIV3, I hated it.  The strategies I had developed for 1&2 no longer worked (the catapult is quite different, for example) and it took me a few minutes to grok the culture concept.  Once I did (and learned the unit differences), I never went back.  The AI is sooo much better than before and unlike CIV4 (which despite buying and forcing myself to play, I never enjoyed), you still get to micromanage a great deal (but you can also automate quite a bit - the ability to choose is awesome).  Buy it on sale if new to the franchise & start with a tiny world.  If you are used to another CIV game, don't wait for a sale, buy it now & get to know the differences in the tech tree as well as the unit differences - I bet you'll like it!

review: This game may be over ten years old now, but if you ask me, it still holds up brilliantly today. Easy(ish!) to learn, difficult to master. Peppered with the best in-game encyclopedia this side of Mass Effect, a fantastic selection of community-created content, and you get to live out history pretty much exactly the way you want to. What's not to like? :) Before Civ 3, strategy games were boring. Well, hold onto your hats, because this re-writes the whole damn rule book. Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027032983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 0, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 0}
review:
Zsenialis korokre osztott strategia. Tipikus szindromat valt ki az emberbol: csak meg egy kort.

Alap otelet, hogy az emberi tortenelmet jatszuk vegig egy civilizaciot iranyitva. Rengeteg kor, kutatas eredmenye utan lehet kivivini a tucanyi gyozelem tipus eleresevel a vegso gyozelmet. Kiirtas, kulturalis gyozelem, vilaghatalam, urverseny, ENSZ-elnok, stb. Ezekbol lathato, hogy nagyon sokfele modon jatszhato.

Grafika 2D-s, de fel sem tunik majd. Zene egyszeruen zsenialis.

A mesterseges intelligencia pedig az egyik legjobb. Nagyon eros, okos, tanulekony. Ugyanazt a poen nem sutod el a gepnel tobbszor, es neha genyo dolgokat tud csinalni - akar csata, akar diplomacia.

Kotelezo darab!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030208409', 'num_games_owned': 377, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 3766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3766, 'last_played': 1349766000}

review: this game wasn't too bad except that it doesn't work on vista, and it doesn't tell you that ahead of time, so i can't play it at all; but when i had windows xp it was pretty good. my favorite civ game is still civ 1 though, these latter civ games are too newfangled and have too many dumb options while taking away civ1 options that were not dumb: for instance, where's my pc speaker sound? that was the best feature in civ1 and no other civ game but civ1 has pc speaker sound.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027324852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3084, 'last_played': 1370770313}
review: EVen though this game is old, it is full of great gameplay. With Civ 3 Complete you can play multiplayer, which allows you to share your conquests with your friends. This is what makes civ 3 a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984239784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2263, 'last_played': 1479689508}
review: Many believe this to be the best Civilization game in the series, and I have to agree. No other Civ has the same amount of sheer content as this one: From civs to leaders, buildings, wonders, scenarios, you name it. Also, the leader's personalities shine, and the diplomacy system is much deeper than in the newer iterations, you can basically tell Ghandi to go fuck himself if he pisses you off. In general, the game is deeper than both its successors, but the tutorial does a good job of teaching you the basics. The rest can be learned through experience. The only thing that I feel could turn someone off is the graphics, which look a bit outdated by now, but if you're willing to look past the surface, hours upon hours of fun await.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973200565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 0, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 0}

review: Screw the new Civ Games. This is by far the best strategy game ever made. The Civilization series has lost its way since this edition, which is the pinnacle of its achievement.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011220599', 'num_games_owned': 837, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 0, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 0}
review: A classic.  For anyone looking to get into the Civilization series for cheap this is the one to buy.  If you already own Civilization IV or Civilization V just leave it be.
